See IRS.Treasury.gov/rpo for an online searchable database of tax return preparers with a PTIN who hold professional credentials recognized by the IRS or who hold an Annual Filing Season Program Record of Completion.

This publication discusses who may represent a taxpayer before the IRS and what forms or documents are used to authorize a person to represent a taxpayer. Usually, attorneys, certified public accountants (CPAs), and enrolled agents may represent taxpayers before the IRS. Enrolled retirement plan agents, and enrolled actuaries may represent with respect to specified Internal Revenue Code sections delineated in Circular 230. Under special and limited circumstances, other individuals, including unenrolled return preparers, family members, employees, and students can represent taxpayers before the IRS. For details regarding taxpayer representation, see Who Can Practice Before the IRS , later.
Many of the terms used in this publication, such as "enrolled agent" and "practitioner" are defined in the Glossary towards the end of this publication.

The following individuals are subject to the Regulations contained in Circular 230. However, any individual who is authorized generally to practice (a recognized representative) must be designated as the taxpayer's representative and file a written declaration with the IRS stating that he or she is authorized and qualified to represent a particular taxpayer. Form 2848 can be used for this purpose.

Because of their special relationship with a taxpayer, the following individuals may represent the specified taxpayers before the IRS, provided they present satisfactory identification and, except in the case of an individual described in (1) below, proof of authority to represent the taxpayer. 1. An individual. An individual can represent himself or herself before the IRS and does not have to file a written declaration of qualification and authority. 2. A family member. An individual can represent members of his or her immediate family. Immediate family includes a spouse, child, parent, brother, or sister of the individual. 3. An officer. A bona fide officer of a corporation (including a parent, subsidiary, or other affiliated corporation), association, or organized group can represent the corporation, association, or organized group. An officer of a governmental unit, agency, or authority, in the course of his or her official duties, can represent the governmental unit, agency, or authority before the IRS. 4. A partner. A general partner can represent the partnership before the IRS. 5. An employee. A regular full-time employee can represent his or her employer. An employer can be, but is not limited to, an individual, partnership, corporation (including a parent, subsidiary, or other affiliated corporation), association, trust, receivership, guardianship, estate, organized group, governmental unit, agency, or authority. 6. A fiduciary. A fiduciary (trustee, executor, personal representative, administrator, receiver, or guardian) stands in the position of a taxpayer and acts as the taxpayer, not as a representative. See Fiduciary under When Is a Power of Attorney Not Required , later.

A student who works in a Low Income Taxpayer Clinic (LITC) or a Student Tax Clinic Program (STCP) must receive permission to represent taxpayers before the IRS by virtue of their status as a law, business, or accounting student. Authorization requests must be sent to the Taxpayer Advocate Service. If granted, a letter authorizing the student's special appearance and detailing any conditions related to the appearance will be issued. Students receiving an authorization letter generally can represent taxpayers before any IRS function or office subject to any conditions in the authorization letter and must be under the direct supervision of an individual authorized to practice before the IRS. If you intend to have a student represent you, review the authorization letter and ask your student, your student's supervisor, or the Taxpayer Advocate Service if you have questions about the terms of the authorization.

Any attorney who is not currently under suspension or disbarment from practice before the IRS and who is a member in good standing of the bar of the highest court of any U.S. state, possession, territory, commonwealth, or the District of Columbia may practice before the IRS.
Any enrolled agent in active status who is not currently under suspension or disbarment from practice before the IRS may practice before the IRS.

Any enrolled retirement plan agent in active status who is not currently under suspension or disbarment from practice before the IRS may practice before the IRS. The practice of enrolled retirement plan agents is limited to certain Internal Revenue Code sections that relate to their area of expertise, principally those sections governing employee retirement plans.

Any individual who is enrolled as an actuary by the Joint Board for the Enrollment of Actuaries who is not currently under suspension or disbarment from practice before the IRS may practice before the IRS. The practice of enrolled actuaries is limited to certain Internal Revenue Code sections that relate to their area of expertise, principally those sections governing employee retirement plans.

Under certain circumstances, a student who is supervised by a practitioner at a law school or equivalent program providing tax services for low income taxpayers may request authorization to represent a taxpayer before the IRS. For more information, see Authorization for Special Appearances , later.

An unenrolled return preparer is an individual other than an attorney, CPA, enrolled agent, enrolled retirement plan agent, or enrolled actuary who prepares and signs a taxpayer's return as the paid preparer, or who prepares a return but is not required (by the instructions to the return or regulations) to sign the return. Unenrolled return preparers may represent taxpayers only before revenue agents, customer service representatives, or similar officers and employees of the Internal Revenue Service (including the Taxpayer Advocate Service) and only during an examination of the tax returns they prepared and signed prior to December 31, 2015. Unenrolled return preparers may not represent taxpayers before appeals officers, revenue officers, counsel or similar officers or employees of the Internal Revenue Service or the Department of the Treasury. Unenrolled return preparers may not execute closing agreements, extend the statutory period for tax assessments or collection of tax, execute waivers, or sign any document on behalf of a taxpayer. If an unenrolled return preparer does not meet the requirements for limited representation, you may authorize the unenrolled return preparer to inspect and/or request your tax information by filing Form 8821. Completing Form 8821 will not authorize the unenrolled return preparer to represent you before the IRS. For more information, see Form 8821 and its separate instructions. Annual Filing Season Program Record of Completion. Only unenrolled return preparers with a valid PTIN and who hold a record of completion for BOTH the tax return year (2015 or thereafter) under examination and the year the examination is conducted may represent under the following conditions: Unenrolled return preparers with the necessary record(s) of completion may represent taxpayers only before revenue agents, customer service representatives, or similar officers and employees of the Internal Revenue Service (including the Taxpayer Advocate Service) and only during an examination of the tax year or period covered by the tax returns they prepared and signed. Unenrolled return preparers may not represent taxpayers, regardless of the circumstances requiring representation, before appeals officers, revenue officers, counsel or similar officers or employees of the Internal Revenue Service or the Department of the Treasury. Unenrolled return preparers may not execute closing agreements, extend the statutory period for tax assessments or collection of tax, execute waivers, or sign any document on behalf of a taxpayer. If an unenrolled return preparer does not meet the requirements for limited representation, you may authorize the unenrolled return preparer to inspect and/or request your tax information by filing Form 8821. Completing Form 8821 will not authorize the unenrolled return preparer to represent you before any IRS personnel. For more information, see Form 8821 and its separate instructions.

Generally, individuals lose their eligibility to practice before the IRS in the following ways. Not meeting the requirements for renewal of enrollment (such as continuing professional education). Requesting as an enrolled agent to be placed in inactive retirement status. Being suspended or disbarred, or determined ineligible for practice, by the Office of Professional Responsibility for violating the regulations contained in Circular 230 or the standards in Revenue Procedure 81-38. Losing their state license to practice as an attorney or a certified public accountant, irrespective of the basis for the license revocation.

Enrolled individuals who request to be placed in an inactive retirement status will be ineligible to practice before the IRS. They must continue to adhere to all renewal requirements. They can be reinstated to active enrollment status by filing an application for renewal and providing evidence that they have completed the required continuing professional education hours for the enrollment cycle.

All individuals practicing before the IRS are subject to disciplinary proceedings and may be censured, suspended, disbarred or monetarily penalized for violating any regulation in Circular 230. This includes engaging in acts demonstrating incompetence or disreputable conduct. For more information, see Incompetence and Disreputable Conduct under What Are the Rules of Practice , later. Practitioners who are suspended or disbarred in a disciplinary proceeding are not allowed to represent taxpayers before the IRS during the period of suspension/disbarment. A practitioner can seek reinstatement from the Office of Professional Responsibility at the earlier of a specified period of suspension or after five years of disbarment. See What Is Practice Before the IRS , earlier. If the practitioner seeks reinstatement, he or she may not practice before the IRS until the Office of Professional Responsibility grants reinstatement. The Office of Professional Responsibility may reinstate the practitioner: If the practitioner's future conduct is not likely to be in violation of the regulations, and If granting the reinstatement would not be contrary to the public interest. Subject to other conditions for a reasonable period.

The IRS website IRS.gov/Tax-Professionals/Enrolled-Agents/Become-an-Enrolled-Agent provides complete information on the steps to be taken to become an enrolled agent. For complete rules on earning an Annual Filing Season Program Record of Completion, see IRS.gov/Tax-Professionals/General-Requirements-for-the-Annual-Filing-Season-Program-Record-of-Completion.

The rules governing practice before the IRS are published in the Code of Federal Regulations at 31 C.F.R. Subtitle A, Part 10 and released digitally as Treasury Department Circular No. 230 (Circular 230). The regulations can be accessed at IRS.gov/Tax-Professionals/Circular-230-Tax-Professionals. An attorney, CPA, enrolled agent, enrolled retirement plan agent, or enrolled actuary authorized to practice before the IRS (referred to hereafter as a practitioner) and an appraiser has the duty to perform certain acts and is restricted from performing other acts. In addition, a practitioner cannot engage in disreputable conduct (discussed later). Any practitioner who does not comply with the rules of practice or who engages in incompetent or disreputable conduct is subject to disciplinary action. Also, unenrolled return preparers must comply with the rules of practice and conduct to exercise the privilege of limited practice before the IRS. There are two specific sets of rules that apply, both are contained in Circular 230: 1. Duties and restrictions relating to practice (Subpart B of Cir. 230), and 2. Conduct considered to exhibit incompetence or disrepute (Subpart C, Section 10.51 of Cir. 230).

Individuals subject to Circular 230 must promptly submit records or information sought by a proper and lawful request from officers or employees of the IRS, except when the practitioner believes on reasonable grounds and good faith that the information is privileged. Communications with respect to tax advice between a federally authorized tax practitioner (See Internal Revenue Code (IRC) sec. 7525) and a taxpayer generally are confidential to the same extent that communication would be privileged if it were between a taxpayer and an attorney if the advice relates to: Noncriminal tax matters before the IRS, or Noncriminal tax proceedings brought in federal court by or against the United States.

This protection for tax advice communications does not apply to any written communications between a federally authorized tax practitioner and any person, including a director, shareholder, officer, employee, agent, or representative of a corporation if the communication involves the promotion of the direct or indirect participation of the corporation in any tax shelter.

Individuals subject to Circular 230 must exercise due diligence when performing the following duties. Preparing or assisting in the preparing, approving, and filing of returns, documents, affidavits, and other papers relating to IRS matters. Determining the correctness of oral or written representations made by him or her to the Department of the Treasury. Determining the correctness of oral or written representations made by him or her to clients with reference to any matter administered by the IRS.

A presumption that due diligence has been exercised will apply in situations where there has been reliance on the work product of another person if reasonable care was used in engaging, supervising, training, and evaluating the person, taking proper account of the nature of the relationship between the Circular 230 individual and the person.

Individuals subject to Circular 230 may not take acknowledgments, administer oaths, certify papers, or perform any official act as a notary public with respect to any matter administered by the IRS and for which he or she is employed as counsel, attorney, or agent, or in which he or she may be in any way interested.

Individuals subject to Circular 230 may not endorse or otherwise negotiate any check (including directing or accepting payment by any means, electronic or otherwise, into an account owned or controlled by the practitioner or any firm or other entity with whom the practitioner is associated) issued to a client by the government in respect of a Federal tax liability.

Individuals subject to Circular 230 may be disbarred or suspended from practice before the IRS, or censured, for incompetence or disreputable conduct. A monetary penalty may also be imposed, in addition to any other discipline, on both individuals and their firms. The following list contains examples of conduct that is considered disreputable. Further examples are shown in Circular 230, Sec. 10.51(a). Being convicted of any criminal offense under the internal revenue laws or of any offense involving dishonesty or breach of trust. Knowingly giving false or misleading information in connection with federal tax matters, or participating in such activity. Soliciting employment by prohibited means as discussed in section 10.30 of Circular 230. Willfully failing to file a federal tax return, evading or attempting to evade any federal tax or payment, or participating in such actions. Misappropriating, or failing to properly and promptly remit, funds received from clients for payment of taxes or other obligations due the United States. Directly or indirectly attempting to influence the official action of IRS employees by the use of threats, false accusations, duress, or coercion, or by offering gifts, favors, or any special inducements. Being disbarred or suspended from practice as an attorney, CPA, public accountant, or actuary, by the District of Columbia or any U.S. state, possession, territory, commonwealth, or any federal court, or any federal agency, body, or board. Knowingly aiding and abetting another person to practice before the IRS during a period of suspension, disbarment, or ineligibility of that other person. Using abusive language, making false accusations or statements knowing them to be false, circulating or publishing malicious or libelous matter, or engaging in any contemptuous conduct in connection with practice before the IRS. Giving a false opinion knowingly, recklessly, or through gross incompetence; or engaging in a pattern of providing incompetent opinions on questions arising under the federal tax laws.

The Secretary of the Treasury, or delegate, after notice and an opportunity for a proceeding, may censure, suspend, or disbar an individual subject to Circular 230 from practice before the IRS if the individual is shown to be incompetent or disreputable, fails to comply with the regulations in Subpart B; or with intent to defraud, willfully and knowingly misleads or threatens a client or prospective client. Censure is a public reprimand. Individuals subject to Circular 230 include any attorney, certified public accountant, enrolled agent, enrolled retirement plan agent, or enrolled actuary engaged in taxpayer representation or advice-giving activity, as well as any Annual Filing Season Program Record of Completion holder who represents taxpayers and any appraiser engaged in appraising asset values for federal tax purposes.

A power of attorney is your written authorization for an individual to receive your confidential tax information from the IRS and to perform certain actions on your behalf. If the authorization is not limited, the individual generally can perform all acts that you can perform, except negotiating or endorsing a check. The authority granted to enrolled retirement plan agents, enrolled actuaries and unenrolled return preparers holding records of completion is limited. For information on the limits regarding annual filing season program record of completion holders, see Revenue Procedure 2014-42 and IRS.gov/Tax-Professionals/Return-Preparer-Office-RPO-At-a-Glance.

Attorneys, certified public accountants, and enrolled agents may perform the following acts: 1. Represent you before any office or employee of the IRS. 2. Sign an offer or a waiver of restriction on assessment or collection of a tax deficiency, or a waiver of notice of disallowance of claim for credit or refund. 3. Sign a consent to extend the statutory time period for assessment or collection of a tax. 4. Sign a closing agreement.

The IRS has a centralized computer database system called the CAF system. This system contains information on the authority of taxpayer representatives. Generally, when you submit a power of attorney document to the IRS, it is processed for inclusion on the CAF system. Entry of your power of attorney on the CAF system enables IRS personnel, who do not have a copy of your power of attorney, to verify the authority of your representative by accessing the CAF. It also enables the IRS to automatically send copies of notices and other IRS communications to your representative if you specify that your representative should receive those communications. You can have your non-IRS power of attorney entered on the CAF system by attaching it to a completed Form 2848 and submitting it to the IRS. Your signature is not required; however, your attorney-in-fact must sign the Declaration of Representative(see Part II of Form 2848).

The IRS will accept a copy of a power of attorney that is submitted by facsimile transmission (fax). If you choose to file a power of attorney by fax, be sure the appropriate IRS office is equipped to accept this type of transmission. !This is an Image: taxtip.gif Your representative may be able to file Form 2848 electronically via the IRS website. For more information, your representative can go to IRS.gov/eServices. If you complete Form 2848 for electronic signature authorization, do not file Form 2848 with the IRS. Instead, give it to your representative, who will retain the document.

Submit any update or modification to an existing power of attorney in writing. Your signature (or the signature of the individual(s) authorized to sign on your behalf) is required. Do this by sending the updated Form 2848 or non-IRS power of attorney to the IRS office(s) where you previously sent the original(s), including the service center where the related return was, or will be filed. A recognized representative may substitute or delegate authority if you specifically authorize your representative to substitute or delegate representation in the original power of attorney. To make a substitution or delegation, the representative must file the following items with the IRS office(s) where the power of attorney was filed. 1. A written notice of substitution or delegation signed by the recognized representative. 2. A written declaration of representative made by the new representative. 3. A copy of the power of attorney that specifically authorizes the substitution or delegation.

If you want to revoke a previously executed power of attorney and do not want to name a new representative, you must write “REVOKE” across the top of the first page of the Form 2848 with a current signature and date immediately below this annotation. Then, you must mail or fax a copy of the power of attorney with the revocation annotation to the IRS, using the Where To File Chart in the Instructions for Form 2848, or if the power of attorney is for a specific matter, to the IRS office handling the matter. If you do not have a copy of the power of attorney you want to revoke, you must send the IRS a statement of revocation that indicates the authority of the power of attorney is revoked, lists the matters and years/periods, and lists the name and address of each recognized representative whose authority is revoked. You must sign and date this statement. If you are completely revoking authority, write "remove all years/periods" instead of listing the specific matters and years/periods.

If your representative wants to withdraw from representation, he or she must write “WITHDRAW” across the top of the first page of the Form 2848 with a current signature and date immediately below the annotation. Then, he or she must provide a copy of the power of attorney with the withdrawal annotation to the IRS in the same manner described in Revocation by taxpayer above. If your representative does not have a copy of the power of attorney he or she wants to withdraw, he or she must send the IRS a statement of withdrawal that indicates the authority of the power of attorney is withdrawn, lists the matters and years/periods, and lists the name, TIN, and address (if known) of the taxpayer. The representative must sign and date this statement. A power of attorney held by a student will be recorded on the CAF system for 130 days from the receipt date. If you are authorizing a student to represent you after that time, you will need to submit another updated Form 2848.

!This is an Image: caution.gif For partnership tax years beginning after December 31, 2017, the Bipartisan Budget Act of 2015, which repealed the TEFRA partnership audit and litigation procedures and the rules applicable to electing large partnerships and replaced them with a new centralized partnership audit regime, has eliminated the role of “tax matters partner” and replaced it with “partnership representative.” Pursuant to Treasury Regulation section 301.9100-22T, certain partnerships can elect to have the new regime apply to partnership returns for tax years beginning after November 2, 2015, and before January 1, 2018.

If Form 2848 is incomplete, the IRS will attempt to secure the missing information either by writing or telephoning you or your representative. For example, if your signature or signature date is missing, the IRS will contact you. If information concerning your representative is missing and information sufficient to make a contact (such as an address and/or a telephone number) is on the document, the IRS will try to contact your representative. In either case, the power of attorney is not considered valid until all required information is entered on the document. The individual(s) named as representative(s) will not be recognized to practice before the IRS, on your behalf, until the document is complete and accepted by the IRS.

The IRS uses the latest encryption technology to ensure your electronic payments are safe and secure. You can make electronic payments online, by phone, and from a mobile device using the IRS2Go app. Paying electronically is quick, easy, and faster than mailing in a check or money order. Go to IRS.gov/Payments to make a payment using any of the following options. IRS Direct Pay: Pay your individual tax bill or estimated tax payment directly from your checking or savings account at no cost to you. Debit or credit card: Choose an approved payment processor to pay online, by phone, and by mobile device. Electronic Funds Withdrawal: Offered only when filing your federal taxes using tax preparation software or through a tax professional. Electronic Federal Tax Payment System: Best option for businesses. Enrollment is required. Check or money order: Mail your payment to the address listed on the notice or instructions. Cash: You may be able to pay your taxes with cash at a participating retail store.

We can help you resolve problems that you can’t resolve with the IRS. And our service is free. If you qualify for our assistance, you will be assigned to one advocate who will work with you throughout the process and will do everything possible to resolve your issue. TAS can help you if: Your problem is causing financial difficulty for you, your family, or your business, You face (or your business is facing) an immediate threat of adverse action, or You’ve tried repeatedly to contact the IRS but no one has responded, or the IRS hasn’t responded by the date promised.

Low Income Taxpayer Clinics (LITCs) are independent from the IRS. LITCs represent individuals whose income is below a certain level and need to resolve tax problems with the IRS, such as audits, appeals, and tax collection disputes. In addition, clinics can provide information about taxpayer rights and responsibilities in different languages for individuals who speak English as a second language. Services are offered for free or a small fee. To find a clinic near you, visit TaxpayerAdvocate.IRS.gov/LITCmap or see IRS Publication 4134, Low Income Taxpayer Clinic List PDF.

Go to IRS.gov/Account to securely access information about your federal tax account. View the amount you owe, pay online or set up an online payment agreement. Access your tax records online. Review the past 18 months of your payment history. Go to IRS.gov/SecureAccess to review the required identity authentication process.

The fastest way to receive a tax refund is to combine direct deposit and IRS e-file. Direct deposit securely and electronically transfers your refund directly into your financial account. Eight in 10 taxpayers use direct deposit to receive their refund. IRS issues more than 90% of refunds in less than 21 days.

Due to changes in the law, the IRS can’t issue refunds before mid-February 2018, for returns that properly claimed the earned income credit (EIC) or the additional child tax credit (ACTC). This applies to the entire refund, not just the portion associated with these credits.

Go to IRS.gov/Tools for the following. The Earned Income Tax Credit Assistant (IRS.gov/EIC) determines if you’re eligible for the EIC. The Online EIN Application (IRS.gov/EIN) helps you get an employer identification number. The IRS Withholding Calculator (IRS.gov/W4App) estimates the amount you should have withheld from your paycheck for federal income tax purposes. The First Time Homebuyer Credit Account Look-up (IRS.gov/HomeBuyer) tool provides information on your repayments and account balance. The Sales Tax Deduction Calculator (IRS.gov/SalesTax) figures the amount you can claim if you itemize deductions on Schedule A (Form 1040), choose not to claim state and local income taxes, and you didn’t save your receipts showing the sales tax you paid.

The IRS doesn’t initiate contact with taxpayers by email or telephone to request personal or financial information. This includes any type of electronic communication, such as text messages and social media channels. Go to IRS.gov/IDProtection for information and videos. If your SSN has been lost or stolen or you suspect you’re a victim of tax-related identity theft, visit IRS.gov/ID to learn what steps you should take.
hyp: The AGI limit for 2025. You can find information about the 2025 contribution and the AGI limit for 2025 in Publication 590-A. Tax changes in 2025. When you calculate how much income tax you want to withhold from your salary and when you calculate your estimated tax payment, consider the tax changes that will take effect in 2025. For more information, see Publication 505. Increased Alternative Minimum Tax Limit (AMT) exemption. The AMT exemption is increased to $85,700 ($133,300 if you are a married joint taxpayer or a qualifying surviving spouse; $66,650 if you are a married separate taxpayer). The income level at which the AMT exemption begins to decrease is increased to $609,350 ($1,218,700 if you are a married joint taxpayer or a qualifying surviving spouse). New reporting requirements for Form 1099-K. The U.S. Relief Plan Act (ARP) for 2021 changes the reporting requirements for third-party settlement organizations. Starting in 2024, the reporting threshold for Form 1099-K is lower. See Chapter 8 below. Updates to Form 1099-K reporting requirements. In 2024, payment card companies, payment applications and online marketplaces will need to send you a Form 1099-K when your business transactions in the year exceed $5,000. In the calendar year 2025, the threshold will be reduced to over $2,500; for Form 2021, the threshold will be lower.

This helps you determine your tax status, whether you can report any dependants, and whether your income is taxable. The following sections describe the standard deductions, the types of expenses you can deduct, and the various tax benefits that can reduce your tax. Throughout the book, examples are given of how the tax law applies in typical situations. Throughout the book, flowcharts and tables are provided to show tax information in an easy-to-understand way. Many of the topics discussed in this book are discussed in more detail in other IRS publications. References to other publications are provided for your reference.

If you run your own business or have other self-employed income (e.g., as a nanny or selling handicrafts), please refer to the following publications for more information: Publication 334, Taxation Guide for Small Businesses; Publication 225, Taxation Guide for Farmers; and Publication 587, Household and Commercial Use.

The four chapters of this section provide basic information about the tax system. This information will guide you through the first steps of filling out your tax return. It also provides information about dependents, and discusses record-keeping requirements, IRS e-file, certain penalties, and two ways of paying taxes in the year: withholding tax and pre-evaluation tax. The supplementary schedules for Forms 1040 and 1040-SR discussed in these chapters include: Schedule 1, [Additional Income and Income Adjustments]; and Schedule 3, [Other Payments and Refundable Credits].

The five chapters of this section discuss various types of income and income adjustments. They also explain which income is taxable and which is not and discuss some adjustments that can be made to income when calculating total income after adjustments. The schedules for Forms 1040 and 1040-SR discussed in these chapters include Schedule 1, Additional Income and Income Adjustments; Schedule 2, Part II, Other Taxes; and Schedule 3, Part II, Other Payments and Refundable Credits.

After determining the total adjusted income, you can subtract the deductions used to calculate the taxable income. You can subtract the standard or listed deductions and, if eligible, the eligible operating income deductions. Listed deductions are deductions for certain expenses listed in Schedule A (Form 1040). Three chapters in this part discuss standard and listed deductions. For factors to consider when deciding on standard and listed deductions, see Chapter 10. The supplementary tables for Form 1040 and Form 1040-SR discussed in these chapters are: Schedule 1, Additional Income and Income Adjustments; Schedule 2, Part II, Other Taxes; and Schedule 3, Part I, Non-refundable Tax Credits.
Two chapters in this section explain how to calculate your taxable income. They also discuss taxable benefits that are deducted directly from your income and thus reduce your taxable income.

Taxpayers have the right to ask the tax system to consider facts and circumstances that may affect their potential liability, ability to pay or to provide information on time. If a taxpayer encounters financial difficulties, or the IRS fails to resolve his tax issues appropriately and on time through its normal channels, he has the right to obtain assistance from the Taxpayer Advocacy Service (TAS).
The taxpayer is entitled to pay only the tax lawfully due, including interest and fines, and to have the IRS collect all taxes properly.

Taxpayers have the right to retain an authorized representative of their choice to deal with the IRS on their behalf. If they are unable to afford a representative, they have the right to seek assistance from the Low Income Taxpayers Service (LSTS).

We accept most taxpayer returns. If we ask questions about your return or choose to review it, it does not mean you are dishonest. The questions or reviews may or may not result in additional taxes. We may close the case without making changes; or you may receive a refund. The process of choosing to review a return usually begins in one of two ways. First, we use computer programs to identify potentially incorrect returns. These programs may look at tax returns (such as Forms 1099 and W-2) for previous reviews or for certain issues determined in compliance cases. Second, we use information from external sources to indicate that the returned amount may be incorrect. These sources may include newspapers, public records and individuals. If we determine that the information is accurate and reliable, it can be used to select the returns to be reviewed.

If you do not agree with the reviewer's recommended change, you can appeal to the IRS Independent Appeals Office. Most disputes can be resolved without expensive and time-consuming court proceedings. Your rights to appeal are detailed in Publication 5, Your Right to Appeal and How to Prepare a Protest If You Disagree, and Publication 556. If you do not wish to go through the IRS Independent Appeals Office or disagree with its findings, you can bring your case to the U.S. Tax Court, U.S. Federal Court of Appeal, or U.S. District Court in your place of residence. If you bring the case to court, keep sufficient records to show your tax obligation, cooperate with the IRS and meet certain other conditions, the IRS will have the burden of proof. If the court agrees with you on most issues in your case and finds our position to be substantially unreasonable, you may be reimbursed for some of the administrative and litigation costs. Unless you attempt to resolve your case through administrative means, including the appeals system, and provide us with the information necessary to resolve the case, you will not be eligible for reimbursement of these costs.
In general, both of you are responsible for paying the full amount of taxes, interests and fines.

If we do contact others, such as neighbors, banks, employers or employees, we are usually required to tell them limited information, such as your name. We are prohibited by law from disclosing information beyond what is necessary to obtain or verify the information we are looking for. Our need to contact others may continue as long as your case requires such activities. If we do contact others, you have the right to request a list of those we have contacted. You can make a request by phone, in writing or in person.

If you believe you have paid too much tax, you may claim a refund. In general, you must apply within 3 years of filing the original tax return or within 2 years of the date of payment of the tax, whichever is later. The law generally provides that if you do not receive a refund within 45 days of filing the tax return or requesting a refund, you may receive interest on the refund. More information about tax refunds is provided in Bulletin 556. If your refund is due but you have not filed a tax return, you must usually file a tax return within 3 years of the date of filing or of the date on which the refund is due, or of the date on which the refund is due, or of the date on which the refund is due, or of the date on which the refund is due, or of the date on which the refund is due, or of the date on which the refund is due, or of the date on which the refund is due, or of the date on which the refund is due, or of the date on which the refund is due, or of the date on which the refund is due, or of the date on which the refund is due, or of the date on which the refund is due, or of the date on which the refund is due, or of the date on which the refund is due, or of the date on which the refund is due, or of the date on which the refund is due, or of the date on which the refund is due, or of the date on which the refund is due, or of the date on which the refund is due, or of the date on which the refund is due, or of the date on which the refund is due, or of the date on which the refund is due, or of the date on which the refund is due, or of the date on which the refund is due, or of the date on which the refund is due, or of the date on which the refund is due, or of the date on which the refund is due, or of the date on which the refund is due, or of the date on which the refund is due, or of the date on which the refund is due, or of the date on which the refund is due, or

The IRS provides the following lists, publications and additional information. Internet: IRS.gov/Help/Tax-Law-Questions and How-to-Get-Help. Forms and Publications: IRS.gov/Forms and IRS.gov/OrderForms.

After receiving all the statements of wages and income (Forms W-2, W-2G, 1099-R, 1099-MISC, 1099-NEC, etc.); statements of unemployment benefits (via mail or in digital form); and statements of interest, dividends and retirement (Form 1099), you have a choice of filling in the tax return yourself or hiring a tax professional to do so.

Through the online account, you can access a variety of information to help you through the tax filing season. You can get your archive, view your most recently filed returns, and get your total adjusted income. Go to IRS.gov/Account to create or access your online account.

If you have a bank account, please visit IRS.gov/DirectDeposit for more information on where to find a bank or credit union that can open an online account for you. If you have a bank account, please visit IRS.gov/DirectDeposit for more information on where to find a bank or credit union that can open an online account for you.

Check out your options for filling and filing your tax returns online or in your local community (if you are eligible) and see what they include. Direct File. Direct File is a permanent option for filing your personal federal tax returns directly and securely online for free. Direct File is an option for taxpayers in participating states who have relatively simple tax returns to file for certain types of income and to file for certain credits and deductions. While Direct File is not used for filing state taxes, if you live in a participating state, Direct File will guide you through the use of state-supported tools that can be used to fill and file state taxes for free. Visit IRS.gov/DirectFile for more information, software updates and frequently asked questions. Free Tax Returns. The program allows you to use software or free tax return forms to fill and file federal personal income tax for free. However, free tax returns may not be available. Visit IRS.gov/FreeFile to see if you are eligible for free online federal tax returns, electronic tax returns and direct deposit or payment options. VITA. Free Tax Returns Service (VITA) provides free tax assistance to taxpayers who need assistance filling their tax returns. Visit IRS.gov/VITA to download the IRS2Go app for free, or call 800-906-9887 for information about free tax return preparation. TCE. Tax Counseling for Seniors (TCE) provides free tax assistance to all taxpayers, especially those aged 60 and over. TCE volunteers are specialized in the unique needs of seniors with regard to pensions and retirement. Please contact the IRS for more information.

IRS does not proactively contact taxpayers via email, text messages (including shortened links), telephone or social media channels to request or verify personal or financial information. This includes requests for personal identification numbers (PINs), passwords or similar information about credit cards, bank or other financial accounts. Visit IRS.gov/IdentityTheft for information on identity theft and data security for taxpayers, tax professionals and businesses. If your SSN is lost or stolen, or you suspect you have been a victim of tax-related identity theft, you can learn what to do. Obtain an Identity Protecting Personal Identification Number (IP PIN) An Identity Protecting Personal Identification Number (IP PIN) is a set of six digit numbers assigned to taxpayers to help prevent their social security numbers from being misused on fraudulent federal income tax returns.

U.S. taxes must be paid to the IRS in U.S. dollars. Digital assets are not accepted. Visit IRS.gov/Payments for information on making payments using any of the following methods. IRS Direct Pay: Pay your personal tax return or assessment tax directly from your check or savings account, without any charges to you. Debit or credit card or digital wallet: Choose an approved payment processor, pay online or over the phone. Electronic withdrawal: Arrange payments when filing federal taxes using tax return software or through a tax professional. Electronic Federal Tax Payment System: This is the best option for businesses. Registration is required. Check or money order: Mail your payment to the address listed in the notice or instructions. Cash: You can pay taxes in cash at the retail store responsible for filing them. On-the-day wire transfer: You can wire your taxes from your financial institution on the same day. Contact your financial institution for availability, fees, and time frames, etc.

If you are unable to pay your taxes in full on the day, you can apply for an online payment agreement (IRS.gov/OPA) to pay your taxes in monthly instalments. Once the online process is completed, you will be notified immediately whether your agreement has been approved. If you are pre-qualified for a tax settlement offer, you can see if you can pay your taxes at a lower rate. For more information on tax settlement offers, please visit IRS.gov/OIC.

You can use the attached form LEP (Form 1040), a request to change language preference, to indicate that you would like to receive notices, letters or other written communications from the IRS in another language. You may not receive written communications in the language you requested immediately. The IRS' commitment to LEP taxpayers is part of a multi-year schedule to provide translations starting in 2023. You will continue to receive communications, including notices and letters in English, until they are translated into your preferred language.

TAS can help you solve problems that you cannot solve with the IRS. Be sure to try to solve your problem with the IRS first, but if you can't, go to TAS. Our service is free. TAS helps all taxpayers (and their representatives), including individuals, corporations and tax-exempt organizations. If your IRS problem is causing you financial difficulties, if you have tried but failed to solve your problem with the IRS, or if you feel that the IRS system, process or procedure is not working properly, you may be eligible for TAS assistance. For assistance on general tax topics at any time, visit www.TaxpayerAdvocate.IRS.gov. This website can help you solve common tax issues and situations, such as what to do if you make an error on your tax return or receive an IRS notification. TAS is dedicated to solving large-scale (systemic) problems that affect many taxpayers. You can report system problems at www.IRS.gov/SAMS. (Please make sure you do not include any personally identifiable information.)

This booklet provides general information on federal tax laws applicable to self-employed or statutory employees. It lists information on operating income, operating expenses and tax credits to assist small business owners in filing their income tax returns.

If you are engaged in a trade or business as a sole proprietor or independent contractor, you are self-employed. You do not have to engage in a regular full-time business activity to become self-employed. Besides having a full-time or formal business, engaging in a dual-professional activity may also be considered self-employment.... a trade or business.... a trade or business is usually an activity carried out for profit. The facts and circumstances of each case determine whether an activity is classified as a trade or business. As long as you have a profit motivation, you do not have to actually make a profit in the trade or business. You do need to make continuous efforts to promote your business interests. Limited Liability Corporation (LLC). An LLC is an entity incorporated under state law by filing a charter. Generally, for income tax purposes, a single-member LLC is not considered an entity separate from its owner and reports income and deductions on its owner's federal income tax return. For example, if a single-member LLC does not engage in agriculture and the owner is an individual, the owner can use Form C. A sole proprietor.... a sole proprietor is a person who owns a non-corporate business. If you are an individual and the only member of an LLC in the country, unless you choose to treat the LLC as a limited liability company, you are also a sole proprietor for income tax purposes. Independent contractor.... individuals engaged in an independent trade, business or profession that provides services to the public, such as doctors, dentists, veterinarians, lawyers, accountants, contractors, subcontractors, public messengers or auctioneers, are usually considered independent contractors. However, whether they are independent contractors or employees depends on the facts of each case. The general rule is that if the person who pays for the work has the right to control or only direct the outcome of the work, they are independent contractors.

If you and your spouse jointly own and operate a corporation and share profits and losses, you are partners in the corporation, whether or not you have a formal partnership agreement. Please do not use Form C. Please file Form 1065 [US Joint Venture Income Return]. For more information, see Publication 541 [Joint Venture]. Exceptions -- Joint Income. If you and your spouse are wholly owner of a corporation that is jointly owned under the State, Foreign or U.S. Territorial Common Property Act, you can treat the corporation as a sole proprietorship or joint venture. States that have common property law include Arizona, California, Idaho, Louisiana, Nevada, New Mexico, Texas, Washington and Wisconsin. Your change of status on the return will be treated as a change of entity. For more information on joint venture law, see Publication 555. Exceptions -- Joint Qualifying Joint Venture (QJV). If you and your spouse are each the only substantial members of a jointly owned and operated corporation and you file a joint tax return for the tax year, you can jointly elect to be treated as a jointly qualifying joint venture (QJV) rather than a joint venture for that tax year. This option avoids the complexity of Form 1065, but still allows your spouse to earn the Social Security income points on which your retirement benefits are based. For an explanation of "participating substantially", see Form G (Form 1040), Notes on Row G. Only spouses who are joint owners (and not on behalf of a state-owned legal entity) own and operate a joint venture.

What you need to know.. Table A lists a list of questions you need to answer to help you meet your federal tax obligations. Each question is followed by a discussion section that you can find in this publication. The Mission of the Internal Revenue Service (IRS).. To provide the best service to American taxpayers by helping them understand and meet their tax obligations and to enforce the law with honesty and fairness for all. Comments and suggestions.. We welcome your comments on this publication and your suggestions for future versions. You can send us your comments at the following address: IRS.gov/FormComments. Or, you can write to Internal Revenue Service, Tax Forms and Publications, 1111 Constitution Ave.NW, IR-6526, Washington, DC 20224. Although we cannot respond to every comment we receive, we appreciate your feedback and will consider your suggestions when we revise the tax forms, instructions and publications. Please do not send tax questions, returns or payments to the above addresses. Get answers to your tax questions.. If you have an unanswered tax question in this publication or in the How to Get Tax Assistance section at the end of this publication, please visit the IRS Interactive Tax Assistant page at IRS.gov/Help/ITA You can find the topic by using the search function or by looking at the categories listed. Get tax forms, instructions and publications. Go to IRS.gov/Forms Download current and previous year's forms, instructions and publications. Order tax forms, instructions and publications. Go to IRS.gov/OrderForms Order current forms, instructions and publications; call 800-829-3676 Order previous year's forms

For more information, see the description of Form 8886 or Abuse of Tax Avoidance Schemes and Transactions. The SB/SE Tax Center serves taxpayers who file Form 1040, Form 1040-SR, Schedule C, Schedule E, or Schedule F, or Form 2106, and small business taxpayers with assets of less than $10 million.

After calculating your operating income and expenses, you can calculate the net profit or loss of your business. You can subtract operating expenses from your operating income to calculate your net profit or loss. If your expenses are less than your income, the difference is net profit and forms part of your income on Schedule 1 (Form 1040), line 3. If your expenses exceed your income, the difference is net loss. You can usually deduct net losses from your total income on Schedule 1 (Form 1040), line 3. However, in some cases, your losses are limited. This chapter summarizes three of these situations. Other situations that may limit your losses are explained in the Notes to Schedule C, lines G and 32. If you have more than one business, you must calculate the net profit or loss for each business on a separate Schedule C.

Your trade or business losses may be limited. If there are losses, use Form 461 to determine the amount of your excess operating loss. Your excess operating loss will be included as income in Schedule 1 (Form 1040), line 8p, and treated as a net operating loss (NOL), which you must carry over and deduct in the following year. For more information on the limits for excess operating losses, see Form 461 and its explanation.

If you do not conduct your business for profit, there are limits on the amount of deductions you can report. You cannot offset losses from your business against other income. This limit applies to your hobby or major sport or entertainment activity. For more information on non-profit activities, see Hobby or Business: What to Know About Side Businesses.

Only the first $168,600 of your combined salary, tips and net income in 2024 is taxed at a 12.4% rate of self-employment tax social security component, social security tax or railway employee retirement tax Tier 1 component (any combination of the three). All your combined salary, tips and net income in 2024 are taxed at a 2.9% rate of self-employment tax health insurance component, health insurance tax or railway employee retirement tax health insurance component (any combination of the three). If your salary and tips are taxed at a Social Security tax or railway employee retirement tax Tier 1 component or both, and the total amount is at least $168,600, you do not pay a 12.4% rate of self-employment tax social security component on your net income. However, you must pay a 2.9% rate of self-employment tax health insurance component on all your net income.

Non-tax residents are not required to pay self-employment taxes unless a valid international social security agreement (also known as a sum-up agreement) determines that they are covered by the U.S. social security system. However, residents of the U.S. Virgin Islands, Puerto Rico, Guam, the Northern Mariana Islands, or American Samoa are required to pay self-employment taxes, as they are treated as U.S. residents for self-employment tax purposes.

If any income from a trade or business (except a partnership) is common-property income under state law, it shall be included in the income of the spouse engaged in the trade or business who is liable to self-employment tax.

Do not include in income subject to self-employment tax the income or losses from the disposal of property that is neither stock nor held primarily for the purpose of selling to customers. It is not important whether the disposal is a sale, exchange or involuntary conversion.

If you are self-employed and will reduce or cease your business activity, your income for self-employment tax shall include any payments you receive from insurance or other sources for the loss of business income. If you are not employed when you receive the payment, the payment is still related to your business and shall be included in your income for self-employment tax, even if your business is temporarily stalled.

If you work for a church or eligible church-controlled organization that has elected to be exempt from social security and health insurance taxes (except for ministers, members of religious groups, or Christian Scientology practitioners), you will be required to pay self-employment tax when you receive a salary of $108.28 or more from that church or organization. For more information, see Bulletin No. 517, Social Security Taxes and Other Information for Clergymen and Religious Workers.

If you are a crew member on a vessel fishing for fish or other aquatic life and you meet all of the following conditions, your income is subject to self-employment tax. 1. You do not receive any remuneration for work other than your catch share or share of the proceeds from the sale of the catch unless the remuneration meets all of the following conditions. 1. Your remuneration for each trip does not exceed $100. 2. You are remunerated only when a minimum catch is reached. 3. Remuneration is used only to pay for other employment costs (e.g., as a deputy, engineer or cook), and additional cash remuneration is traditional in the fishing industry. 2. You will receive a catch share or share of the proceeds from the sale of the catch. 3. Your share depends on the catch. 4. The ship's crew is usually less than 10 people. (If the average number of crew members on all trips over the last 4 calendar quarters is less than 10, the crew is usually considered to be less than 10).

If you are a state or local government employee who is paid only on a fee basis and your services are not covered by a federal-state social security agreement, you will be required to pay self-employment tax.

If both of the following conditions are true, you are required to pay self-employment tax: 1. You are a U.S. citizen employed in the United States, Puerto Rico, Guam, American Samoa, the Commonwealth of Northern Mariana Islands or the U.S. Virgin Islands by: 1. a foreign government, 2. a wholly-owned agency of a foreign government, or 3. an international organization. 2. Your employer does not have to withhold social security and health insurance taxes from your salary or your income.
If you are a self-employed U.S. citizen or resident as defined by tax law residing outside the United States, you must pay self-employment tax in most cases.

You may want to use the optional method (discussed later) when you have a loss or small net profit and any of the following applies: You want to earn credits for social security benefits You incur creditable child or dependent care costs (the optional method may increase your earned income and therefore increase your credit) You are entitled to the Low Income Family Benefit (EIC) (the optional method may increase your earned income and therefore increase your credit) You are entitled to the Additional Child Tax Credit (ACTC) (the optional method may increase your earned income and therefore increase your credit)

Using the optional method may increase your self-employment tax. Paying more self-employment tax may result in higher benefits when you retire. Because half of the self-employment tax deduction on Form 1040 or 1040-SR is deducted, using the optional method may also reduce your adjusted gross income (AGI), which may affect your credits, deductions, or other items subject to the AGI limit. Calculate your AGI using and not using the optional method to determine whether the optional method is beneficial to you. If you use either or both of the optional methods, you must calculate and pay self-employment tax according to these methods, even if you pay less or no tax using the regular method. The optional method may only be used to calculate your self-employment tax. To calculate your income tax, include your actual income in your total income, regardless of which method you use to determine self-employment tax.

Use the non-farm option only for income from non-self-employment. You can use this method if you meet all of the following test requirements. 1. You are a continuous self-employed person. This means that you have had a real net income from self-employment of $400 or more for at least 2 of the 3 tax years preceding your use of this method. For this purpose, the net income in the previous year can come from farm or non-farm income, or both. 2. You have used this method for less than 5 years. (There is a 5-year limit on the use of this method.) The years do not have to be consecutive. 3. Your non-farm net profit is: 1. less than $7,493, and 2. less than 72.189% of your total non-farm income.
Your gross non-farm income is usually the sum of the following amounts: Schedule C (Form 1040), line 7; and Schedule K-1 (Form 1065), box 14, code C (from non-farm associated enterprises).
The following example shows how to calculate net income when the total non-farm income does not exceed $10,380 per year.
The following example shows how to calculate net income when the total non-farm income exceeds $10,380.

Use Form SE (Form 1040) to calculate and file your self-employment tax.If you file Form 1040 or 1040-SR, enter the self-employment tax on line 4 of Schedule 2 and attach Form SE to your form.If you file Form 1040-SS, enter the SE tax on line 3 and attach Form SE to your form.If you are required to pay self-employment tax, you must file Form 1040, 1040-SR or 1040-SS, as applicable, even if you do not file a federal income tax return.

We accept the returns of most taxpayers. If we ask questions about your return or choose to review it, it does not mean you are dishonest. The questions or reviews do not necessarily result in an increase in your tax. We may close your case without amendments, and you may receive a refund. The process of selecting returns for review usually begins in one of two ways. First, we use computer programs to identify returns that may be incorrect. These programs may be based on tax returns (such as Forms 1099 and W-2); research into past reviews, or certain issues determined for other special items. Second, we use information from compliance programs that indicates that the amounts on the returns may be incorrect. These sources may include newspapers, public records, and individuals. If we are sure the information is accurate and reliable, we may use it to select returns for review. Bulletin 556, Tax Return Review, Appeals, and Refund Applications, explains the rules and procedures we follow in our reviews. The following sections outline how we conduct our reviews.

If you disagree with the change proposed by the auditor, you can appeal to the IRS Independent Appeals Office. Most disputes can be resolved without expensive and time-consuming court proceedings. Your right to appeal is described in detail in Publication 5, Your Right to Appeal and How to Prepare a Protest if You Disagree, and Publication 556. If you do not want to use the Appeals Office or disagree with its findings, you can file a case with the U.S. Tax Court, the U.S. Federal Claims Court, or the U.S. District Court in your place of residence. If you file a case with the court, it will be the duty of the court to prove certain facts, provided you maintain sufficient records to demonstrate your tax obligations, cooperate with the IRS and meet certain other conditions. If the court agrees with you on most of the issues in your case and finds our position substantially unreasonable, you may be entitled to some compensation for administrative and litigation costs. Unless you attempt to resolve your case through administrative means, including the appeals system, and you provide us with the information required to resolve the case, you will not be entitled to compensation for these costs.

In general, you and your spouse are jointly and severally responsible for all taxes, interest, or fines due on your joint tax return. To seek exemption from any obligation related to your spouse (or former spouse), you must apply for a waiver using Form 8857, Request for Innocent Spouse Waiver. In some cases, Form 8857 may need to be filed within 2 years of the date the IRS first attempts to charge you tax. Do not file Form 8857 with Form 1040 or 1040-SR. For more information, see Bulletin 971, Innocent Spouse Waiver and Form 8857, or call the Innocent Spouse Office toll-free at 855-851-2009.

However, if we do contact other people, such as neighbors, banks, employers or employees, we usually need to tell them limited information, such as your name. We are prohibited by law from disclosing any information beyond what is necessary to obtain or verify the information we are seeking. We may continue to contact others as long as your case requires further action. If we do contact others, you have the right to obtain a list of those contacts. You can make your request by telephone, in writing or in person.

If you believe you paid too much tax, you can claim a refund. You must usually claim a refund within three years of the date you filed your original tax return or two years from the date you paid your tax, whichever is later. For more information on tax refunds, see Bulletin 556. If you are entitled to a refund but have not filed a return, you must file a refund application within two years of the tax being paid to receive the refund. The law generally provides that interest will be charged on your refund if it is not issued to you within 45 days of the date you filed your return or claimed your refund.

Once you have received all your salary and income returns (W-2, W-2G, 1099-R, 1099-MISC, 1099-NEC, etc.); unemployment benefit returns (via mail or in digital format) or other government payments (Form 1099-G); and interest, dividends and pensions returns from banks and investment companies (Form 1099), you have several options for filling out and filing your tax return.

Taxpayers who need accessibility information can call 833-690-0598. The Accessibility Helpline can answer questions about current and future accessible products and services in alternative media formats (e.g., Braille, large print, audio, etc.).

Through the online account, you can access a variety of information to help you through the tax filing season. You can get your rss, view your most recently filed returns, and get your total adjusted income. Go to IRS.gov/Account to create or access your online account.

The safest and easiest way to get your refund is to file it electronically and choose Direct Deposit, which securely transfers your refund electronically directly to your financial account. Direct deposits also avoid the risk of your check being lost, stolen, destroyed or not delivered to IRS. Eight out of ten taxpayers use direct deposits to get their refund. If you do not have a bank account, visit IRS.gov/DirectDeposit for more information on where to find a bank or credit union that can open an online account for you.

Your options for filling and filing your tax return online or in your local community (if you are eligible) include the following: Direct File. Direct File is a permanent option for filing your personal federal tax return directly and securely online for free. Direct File is an option for taxpayers in participating states who have relatively simple tax returns to file for certain types of income and to file for certain credits and deductions. While Direct File is not used for filing state taxes, if you reside in a participating state, Direct File will guide you through the use of state-supported tools that can be used to file and file state taxes for free. Visit IRS.gov/DirectFile for more information, program updates and frequently asked questions. Free File. This program allows you to use tax return software or free file forms to complete and file federal personal income tax returns for free. However, free filing may not provide state tax returns. Visit IRS.gov/FreeFile to verify your eligibility for free online federal tax returns, electronic tax returns and direct deposit or payment options. VITA. Free Tax Return Service (VITA) provides free tax assistance for taxpayers with low and medium incomes, disabled people and those who need help filling their own tax returns. Visit IRS.gov/VITA to download the IRS2Go app for free, or call 800-906-9887 for information about free tax return services. TCE. Tax Counseling Services for Seniors (TCE) provides free tax assistance for all taxpayers, especially those over 60. TCE volunteers are dedicated to answering questions about pensions and retirement specific to seniors.

The IRS does not contact taxpayers via email, text messages (including shortened links), telephone or social media channels to request or verify personal or financial information. This includes requests for personal identification numbers (PINs), passwords or similar information for credit cards, bank or other financial accounts. Visit IRS.gov/IdentityTheft, the IRS Identity Theft Center website, for information on identity theft and data security for taxpayers, tax professionals and businesses. If your Social Security Number is lost or stolen, or you suspect you are a victim of tax-related identity theft, you can learn what steps to take. Obtain an Identity Protection Personal Identification Number (IP PIN). An Identity Protection PIN is a six-digit number assigned to a taxpayer to help prevent his or her Social Security Number from being misused in federal income tax return fraud. When you have an Identity Protection PIN, it prevents others from using your Social Security Number to file a tax return. For more information, visit IRS.gov/IPPIN.

U.S. taxes must be paid to the IRS in U.S. dollars. Digital assets are not accepted. Go to IRS.gov/Payments for information on making payments using any of the following methods. IRS Direct Pay: Pay your personal tax bill or estimated tax directly from your check or savings account, without additional charges. Debit or credit card or digital wallet: Choose an approved payment processor, pay online or over the phone. Electronic withdrawal of funds: Provides arrangements for payments when filing federal taxes using tax filing software or through a tax professional. Electronic Funds Transfer System (EFTPS): Best for businesses. Requires registration. Check or money order: Mail your payment to the address listed on the notice or notice. Cash: You can pay your taxes in cash at participating retailers. On-the-day wire transfer: You may be able to make on-the-day wire transfers from your financial institution. Contact your financial institution for feasibility, cost and timeframe.

Visit IRS.gov/Payments for more information on your options. Apply for an Online Payment Agreement (IRS.gov/OPA) to meet your tax obligations in monthly instalments (if you are unable to pay your taxes in full on the day). Once you complete the online process, you will be notified immediately whether your agreement has been approved. Use the Pre-Qualification for a Deal to determine if you can settle your tax liability at a lower amount than the tax you owe. For more information on the Pre-Qualification for a Deal, visit IRS.gov/OIC.

You can use the attached form LEP (Form 1040), Request for Change of Language Preference, to indicate that you would like to receive notices, letters, or other written communications from the IRS in another language. You may not immediately receive written communications in the language you requested. The IRS' commitment to LEP taxpayers is part of a multi-year schedule to provide translations starting in 2023. You will continue to receive communications, including notices and letters in English, until they are translated into your preferred language.

TAS can help you solve problems that you cannot solve with the IRS. Be sure to try to solve your problem with the IRS first, but if you can't, go to TAS. Our service is free. TAS helps all taxpayers (and their representatives), including individuals, corporations and tax-exempt organizations. If your IRS problem is causing you financial difficulties, if you have tried but failed to solve your problem with the IRS, or if you feel that the IRS system, process or procedure is not working properly, you may be eligible for TAS assistance. For assistance on general tax topics at any time, visit www.TaxpayerAdvocate.IRS.gov. This website can help you solve common tax issues and situations, such as what to do if you make an error on your tax return or receive an IRS notification. TAS is dedicated to solving large-scale (systemic) problems that affect many taxpayers. You can report system problems at www.IRS.gov/SAMS. (Please make sure you do not include any personally identifiable information.)

The Small Business Administration (SBA) provides small business owners with training and education programs, advisory services, financial planning and contractual assistance. The SBA also provides publications and videos on a variety of business topics.
You can visit the SBA website at SBA.gov. When you visit the SBA website, you can find a variety of information of interest to small business owners.
You can go to SBDC for help with your small business. To find a location near you, visit the SBA website or call the SBA Answer Desk.

In general, use your SSN as your taxpayer identification number (TIN). You must write this number on each of your personal income tax returns, such as Form 1040 and its annexes. To apply for an SSN, use Form SS-5, Application for a Social Security Card. This form is available at the Social Security Administration (SSA) offices or by calling 800-772-1213.

If you have employees, you must obtain an SSN for each employee. Please record the name and SSN as shown on each employee's social security card. If the name of the employee on the card is incorrect, the employee should apply to the SSA for a new card. If the name of the employee changes due to marriage or divorce, this may occur. Form W-4 [Certificate of Employee's Withholding Tax Exemption], which is completed by each employee in order to deduct the correct federal income tax from the employee's salary. If your employee does not have an SSN, the employee must file Form SS-5 with the SSA.
If your self-employed net income is less than $400, but you meet any other returning requirements listed in the Form 1040 notes, you will still have to file a 2024 income tax return.

Paperless filing is easier than you think and is available to most taxpayers who file electronically, including first-time taxpayers who are 16 or older at the end of 2024. If you are using tax filing software or a tax professional and filing electronically, you will sign your return using the IRS e-file self-selected PIN. If you choose to file a married joint tax return, you and your spouse will each need to create a PIN and enter it as your electronic signature. To create a PIN, you will need to obtain your adjusted gross income (AGI) from your original 2023 income tax return (not from an amended return, Form 1040-X, or after receiving any math error notification from the IRS). You will also need to provide your date of birth (DOB). Make sure your DOB is accurate and matches the information on your records filed with the SSA before you e-file. To do this, check your annual social security benefit return. If you use a self-selected PIN, you don't need to sign and mail any documents—even Form W-2. For more information on the self-selected PIN method, visit IRS.gov.

You can choose to have your refund mailed to you or deposited directly into your check or savings account. With IRS e-file, the time to issue your refund is half that of paper filing. Most refunds are issued within 21 days.

As for paper returns, if you (or your spouse, if you file jointly) are in arrears with a number of past due payments, such as federal, state, student, or child support taxes, you may not be able to get a full refund. If the refund you claimed has been used to offset the debt, you will receive notice. You can file a cumulative spouse relief by filling out Form 8379, Cumulative Spouse Allotment, or Form 8857, Innocent Spouse Relief Application, to recover part or all of the joint tax refund that has been transferred to pay your spouse's sole debt.

The IRS will not be able to issue returns for low-income family benefits (EIC) or additional child tax credits (ACTC) until mid-February 2025. This applies to the entire refund, not just the portion related to the tax credit.

If your tax return shows you are owed, you must pay your tax by the due date of your tax return (ignoring any extensions) to avoid penalties and interest on late payments. For the calendar year 2024, please pay by April 15, 2025. You have many options for making payments, including scheduling electronic withdrawals from your check or savings account, or making payments via debit or credit card. For more information on payment options, please visit IRS.gov/Payments.
If your AGI in 2024 is $84,000 or less, you can use the free tax software and submit your tax return using e-file.

This public-private partnership between the IRS and tax software providers has made about a dozen branded commercial software products and e-files available to taxpayers free of charge. Visit IRS.gov/FreeFile for details. You can review each software provider's free use criteria, or use online tools to find out which free software products are suitable for your situation.

The IRS also provides electronic versions of the paper IRS forms. These electronic forms can also be e-filed for free. Free fillable forms are best suited for people who want to file their own tax returns. There are no income restrictions for using these forms. Free fillable forms allow basic math calculations. This only supports federal tax returns.
For the 2024 calendar year, your return is due on the 15th of the 4th month after the end of your fiscal year. If you file late, you may have to pay penalties and interest.

Federal income tax is pay-as-you-go. You pay tax when you earn or receive income during the year. Employee income tax is usually withheld from your paycheck. If you have not paid tax by withholding, or have not paid enough tax in this way, you may have to pay an estimated amount of tax.
Other options include including the tax overpayment on your 2023 tax return in your 2024 estimated tax, or mailing a cheque or money order with a 1040-ES payment voucher attached.

1. To register for EFTPS, please visit EFTPS.gov, or call 800-555-4477. 2. You may be automatically registered for EFTPS when you apply for a new EIN. 3. The benefits of EFTPS include: 1. Reduced chance of payment errors. 2. Instant confirmation of each transaction.

Self-employment tax is primarily a social security and medical insurance (Medicare) tax on individuals who work for themselves. It is similar to the social security and health insurance tax that is withheld from the wages of most wage earners. If you earn income as a statutory employee, you do not have to pay self-employment tax on that income. Social security and health insurance tax is withheld from that income.

As a self-employed person, you have the same rights to social security benefits as a wage earner. Your self-employment tax ensures that you are covered by the social security system. Social security insurance provides you with retirement benefits, disability benefits, pensions and health insurance benefits. Make sure that you declare all your self-employment income. If you do not declare all your self-employment income, your social security benefits may be reduced when you retire.

In 2024, you will receive one Work Point (up to four Work Points) for each $1,730 of your taxable income ($1,810 in 2025). Therefore, if your taxable income (self-employment income and wages) in 2024 is $6,920, you will receive four Work Points ($6,920 ÷ $1,730). For an explanation of the number of points you need to be insured and the benefits that the social security plan can provide to you and your family, please consult your nearest Social Security office. False statements made in order to obtain or increase social security benefits may result in a fine and/or a dismissal.

In general, the IRS will only give you credit for self-employed income that is reported on a tax return filed within 3 years, 3 months and 15 days after the tax year in which you earned the income. If you file a tax return or make an adjustment to your self-employed income after that time, the IRS may change its records, but only remove or reduce the amount. The IRS will not change its records to increase your self-employed income.

Only the first $168,600 of your combined salary, tips and net income in 2024 is subject to a 12.4% Self-Employment Tax Social Security component, Social Security Tax or Railroad Employee Retirement Tax Tier 1 component (any combination of the three).
