All your combined salary, tips and net income in 2024 are subject to a 2.9% Self-Employment Tax Health Insurance component, Health Insurance Tax or Railroad Employee Retirement Tax Health Insurance component (any combination of the three). If your salary and tips are subject to Social Security Tax or Railroad Employee Retirement Tax Tier 1 component or both and total at least $168,600, you do not pay the 12.4% Self-Employment Tax Social Security component on any of your net income. However, you must pay the 2.9% Self-Employment Tax Health Insurance component on all net income. and and and and and and and and and and and and and and and and and and and and and and and and and and and and and and and and and and and and and and and and and and and and and and and and and and and and and and and and and and and and and and and and and and and and and and and and and and and and and and and and and and and and and and and and and and and and and and and and and and and and and and and and and and and and and and and and and and and and and and and and and and and and and and and and and and and and and and and and and and and and and and and and and and and and and and and and and and and and and and and and and and and and and and and and and and and and and and and and and and and and and and and and and and and and and and and and and and and and and and and and and and and and and and and and and and and and and and and and and and and and and and and and and and and and and and and and and and and and and and and and and and and and and and and and and and and and and and and and and and and and and and and and and and and and and and and and and and and and and and and and and and and and and and and and and

If you have both wages and self-employed income, the maximum amount of additional health insurance tax on self-employed income is reduced by the amount of wages that are subject to additional health insurance tax (but not less than zero).

For more information, see Publication 15 (Notice E) Employer Tax Guide. This publication explains your tax liability as an employer. Do not use the non-refundable and refundable portions of the Family First Coronavirus Response Act (FFCRA) and the U.S. Rescue Plan Act of 2021 (ARP) on eligible sick leave and vacation pay on your employment tax return to reduce your social security and health insurance tax deductions. Instead, report the credits as income. To help you determine whether someone who works for you is your employee, see Publication 15-A. The information in this publication can help you determine whether someone is an independent contractor or an employee. If you mistakenly classify an employee as an independent contractor, you may have to pay employment tax plus a penalty. An independent contractor is self-employed. Normally, you do not have to withhold or pay any tax on payments made to an independent contractor.

If you make or receive payments in your business, you may have to report these payments to the IRS on a Tax Information Return Form. The IRS will compare the payments shown on the Tax Information Return Form with the individual's income tax return to see if these payments are included in their income. You must provide the recipient or payer with a copy of each Tax Information Return Form to be filed. In addition to the forms below, you may need to use other forms to report several types of payments or transactions. For more details on the Tax Information Return Form and when to file it, see General Information on Several Tax Information Return Forms.

You must file Form W-2 to report payments made to your employees, such as wages, tips and other compensation; as well as withholding taxes, social security and health insurance taxes. You can file Form W-2 online. For more information on Form W-2, see the general notes on Form W-2 and Form W-3.

If you receive more than $10,000 in cash in one transaction or two or more related business transactions, you must file Form 8300. Cash includes US dollars and foreign currencies. Cash also includes a number of financial instruments such as bank notes, travellers' cheques and money orders. Cash does not include checks withdrawn from a person's personal account (personal checks). For more information, see Bulletin 1544.

Failure to file a Form 8300, filing (or causing others to file) a false or fraudulent Form 8300, or constructing a transaction to avoid filing the requirement, are subject to civil and criminal penalties, with the maximum sentence being five years in prison.

You must calculate your taxable income and file an income tax return for the annual accounting period (called the tax year). Similarly, you must consistently use accounting methods that clearly reflect your income and expenses during the tax year.

If you file your first income tax return using the calendar tax year and then start your business as a sole proprietor, you must continue to use the calendar tax year unless you get IRS approval to change it or are allowed to change it without IRS approval. For more information, see Change your tax year later. If you use the calendar tax year, you must keep books and records and report your income and expenses for the period from January 1 to December 31 of each year.

A fiscal year is a consecutive 12-month period ending on the last day of any month (except December). A fiscal year of weeks 52 to 53 is a fiscal year of weeks 52 to 53, but not necessarily ending on the last day of a month. If you use a fiscal year, you must keep books and records and report income and expenses using the same fiscal year. For more information about the fiscal year, including the fiscal year of weeks 52 to 53, see Bulletin 538.

Your accounting policy is a set of rules that determine when and how you report income and expenses. Your accounting policy includes not only the complete accounting policy you use, but also the accounting treatment you use for any significant items. When you file your first income tax return (including your company's Schedule C), you choose an accounting policy for your company. If you want to change your accounting policy thereafter, you usually need to get the approval of the IRS. See Change your accounting policy.
You must use the same accounting method to calculate and record your taxable income. Similarly, you must use an accounting method that clearly reflects your income.

You can use different accounting methods for accounting for corporate and personal items. For example, even if you use cash to calculate personal items, you can still use accrual to calculate your corporate income.

If you have two or more separate and distinct enterprises, you may use different accounting policies for each of them, provided that the accounting policies clearly reflect the income of each of them. They are separate and distinct only if you maintain complete and separate books and records for each of them.

Most individuals and many sole proprietors without inventory use cash because they find it easier to keep cash records. However, if inventory is required to account for your income, you will usually have to use accrual for items you buy or sell, unless you are a small business taxpayer (see definition later in this chapter).

In the cash system, include in your total income all items of income that you actually or presumably received during the tax year. If you acquire property or services, you must include their fair market value in your income.

Without limitation, you have a presumptive receipt when a sum is credited to your account or made available to you. You do not have to possess the sum. If you authorize someone to act as your agent and collect the income on your behalf, you are deemed to have received the income when your agent receives it.

You cannot keep a check from one tax year to the next, or defer the occupation of a similar property from one tax year to the next, in order to avoid paying income tax. You must receive or provide the property to you without restriction for the year in which you received or provided the property.
If a valid cheque is received in the tax year, it is presumed that income was earned in that year, even if the cheque was not cashed or deposited until the following year.

If your debt has been paid by another person or cancelled by the creditor, you may want to include part or all of this debt relief as income. If you earn income in this way, you presumably earn income when the debt is cancelled or paid. For more information, see Cancelled Debts under Income Classes in Chapter 5.

If you include an amount in your income but you have to repay all or part of that income in a subsequent year, you can usually deduct the repayment in the year in which you repay the income. If you repay more than $3,000, special rules apply. For details on the special rules, see Repayment in Chapter 8 of Bulletin 17.

This includes business expenses that you object to as liabilities. However, you may not be able to deduct expenses that have been paid in advance, or you may have to capitalize some of the costs, as explained later in the Unified Capitalization Rules.

Under the accrual accounting system, you usually report income in the year in which it is earned, and deduct or capitalize expenses in the year in which they are incurred. The purpose of accrual accounting is to align income and expenses in the appropriate year.

Under the accrual basis, you include an amount in your total income that you can reasonably accurately determine in the tax year in which all the events that determine your entitlement to the income occur, usually in the tax year in which the taxpayer has the applicable financial statements or such other financial statements as the Secretary may designate, and it is deemed to pass the all events test for the total income item no later than the date of consideration in the applicable financial statements or other such financial statements.
The following are special rules that apply to advance payments, estimated income and changes in the payment schedule for services.

If you include a reasonably estimated amount in your total income and the exact amount is later determined to be different, consider the difference in the tax year in which you determine the exact amount.

If you provide services at the basic rate specified in the contract, you must calculate your income at the basic rate even if you agree to charge at a lower rate before completing the service and receiving the difference.

Generally, you report the advance payment as income in the year in which you receive it. However, if you receive an advance payment, you may choose to include it in your income in the next tax year. You cannot include any payment after that tax year. For more information, see Bulletin 538 and Section 451.

In your business, where the production, purchase or sale of goods is a factor in generating income, unless you are a small business taxpayer, you usually have to consider inventory at the beginning and end of the tax year. If you have to account for inventory, you usually have to use accrual accounting for the items you buy and sell. For more information, see Inventory later.

You cannot deduct business expenses and interest you owe to an associate until you make the payment and the corresponding amount is included in the total income of the associate using the cash accounting system. As a result of this rule, please establish the relationship at the end of the tax year in which the expense or interest is also deductible. If, under this rule, the expense or interest is not deductible, the rule will continue to apply even if your relationship with the person ends before the expense or interest can be included in the total income of the person. Associates include your immediate family members, including siblings (in full or half-breed relationship), your spouse, your ascendants and your immediate descendants. For a list of other associated persons, see section 267 of the Internal Revenue Code.

Generally, you can use cash, accrual and special accounting methods combined, provided that the combination clearly reflects your income and expenses and you use it consistently. However, the following restrictions apply. If you must account for inventory when you account for income, you usually use accrual for the items you buy and sell. (But see Inventory later.) You can use cash for all other income and expense items. If you use cash when you calculate income, you must use cash when you report expenses. If you use accrual when you report expenses, you must use accrual when you calculate income. If you use a combination that includes cash, treat it as cash.
In general, if your business produces, purchases or sells goods, you must maintain inventory and use accrual accounting for the goods you buy or sell.

If you are a small business taxpayer, you may choose not to retain inventory, but you must still use some accounting method for inventory that clearly reflects income. If you choose not to retain inventory, and your accounting method for inventory treats it as non-incidental materials or supplies, or is consistent with your financial accounting treatment of inventory, you will not be considered to have failed to clearly reflect income. In general, if you produce, purchase or sell goods in an enterprise, you must retain inventory and use accrual accounting for purchases and sales of goods.

If you (a) have an average annual gross income of $30 million or less in the previous three tax years and (b) are not a tax shelter (as defined in section 448(d)(3)), you qualify as a small business taxpayer. If your business did not continue for all three tax year periods used to calculate average gross income, calculate average gross income for the period of its continuation. If your business has a predecessor entity, include the total revenue of the predecessor entity for the three tax year periods in the calculation of average gross income. If your business (or predecessor entity) uses a shorter tax year in any of the three tax year periods, calculate annualized total revenue of your business for the shorter tax year that is part of the three tax year periods. See Bulletin 538 for more information.

At the beginning and end of each tax year, you must price your inventory to determine your cost of sales (Table C, line 42). To determine the value of your inventory, you need to use methods to identify the items in your inventory and methods to price them. The inventory pricing rules cannot be the same for all types of businesses. The method you use to price your inventory must be consistent with the generally accepted accounting principles for similar operations and must clearly reflect revenue. Your inventory practices must be consistent over the years.

Under the unified capitalization rules, the direct costs and some of the indirect costs of the production or resale activity must be capitalized. Report these costs on the basis of the production or purchase of the property for resale, rather than as a current deduction. When you use, sell or otherwise dispose of the property, you can recover the cost through depreciation, sale or cost of sale.

Unless the purpose of producing property is for use outside your business or profitable activity, you may be subject to the unified capitalization rules if you engage in any of the following activities: a. producing real or tangible movable property. For this purpose, tangible movable property includes films, recordings, videotapes, books or similar property; b. acquiring property for resale; c. purchasing property for resale; d. purchasing property for resale; e. purchasing property for resale; f. purchasing property for resale; g. purchasing property for resale; h. purchasing property for resale; h. purchasing property for resale; h. purchasing property for resale; h. purchasing property for resale; h. purchasing property for resale; h. purchasing property for resale; h. purchasing property for resale; h. purchasing property for resale; h. purchasing property for resale; h. purchasing property for resale; h. purchasing property for resale; h. purchasing property for resale; h. purchasing property for resale; h. purchasing property for resale; h. purchasing property for resale; h. purchasing property for resale; h. purchasing property for resale; h. purchasing property for resale; h. purchasing property for resale; h. purchasing property for resale; h. purchasing property for resale; h. purchasing property for resale; h. purchasing property for resale; h. purchasing property for resale; h. purchasing property for resale; h. purchasing property for resale; h. purchasing property for resale; h. purchasing property for resale; h. purchasing property for resale; h. purchasing property for resale; h. purchasing property for resale; h. purchasing property for resale; h. purchasing property for resale; h. purchasing property for resale; h. purchasing property for resale; h. purchasing property for resale; h. purchasing property for resale; h. purchasing

A number of income or expense items are treated in a special way. These include: Discounts, discussed in Issue 225, Chapter 7. Bad books, discussed in Issue 453, Deductions from bad books. Depreciation, discussed in Issue 225, Chapter 7. Depreciation, discussed in Issue 946, How to depreciate property. Sale on instalment, discussed in Issue 537, Sale on instalment. Accounting for long-term contracts. See Article 460.

A sale on instalment is a sale of a property when at least one payment is received after the tax year in which the sale was made. If you are financing a buyer to purchase your property rather than having the buyer take a loan or mortgage from a third party, you are most likely selling on instalment. For more information on installment sales, see Bulletin 537.

In general, when this happens, each asset is treated as being sold separately for the purpose of determining the treatment of gains or losses. Both parties involved in the sale of a business must report to the IRS how the sale price is distributed among the business assets. Use Form 8594 [Asset Acquisition Notice under Section 1060] to provide this information. Both parties must attach Form 8594 to their respective federal income tax returns for the year in which the sale occurred. For more information on business sales, see Bulletin 544.

The cost or purchase price of a property is usually the basis for calculating the gain or loss from sale or other disposition. However, if you acquire property through a gift, inheritance or otherwise other than purchase, you must use a basis other than its cost. For more information on the basis, see Bulletin 551, Asset Base.

In general, the realized value of the property you dispose of is the sum of all cash you receive plus the fair market value of all property or services you receive. Your realized value also includes any liabilities incurred by the buyer, any liabilities you have and any liabilities attached to the property you dispose of, such as property taxes or mortgages.

For tax purposes, the gain or loss you realize from the disposal of property is usually a recognized gain or loss. The recognized gain must be included in total income. The recognized loss can be deducted from total income. However, the gain or loss realized from a number of property transactions is not recognized. See Non-taxable transactions above. Similarly, you cannot deduct losses from the disposal of property held for personal use.

You must classify your losses as ordinary or capital gains or losses. You must do this in order to calculate net capital gains or losses. In general, if you dispose of capital assets, you will record capital gains or losses. Normally, every asset you own and use for personal purposes or investments is capital asset. A property you use in your business is not capital asset. The gain or loss from disposal of that property is ordinary gain or loss. However, if you hold the property for more than one year, you may be able to treat the gain or loss as capital gain or loss. These gains and losses are referred to as 1231 gains and losses. For more information on ordinary and capital gains and losses, see Chapters 2 and 3 of Bulletin 544.

If you record a capital gain or loss, you must determine whether it is long-term or short-term. The gain or loss is long-term or short-term depending on how long you owned the property before you disposed of it. The time you owned the property before you disposed of it is called the holding period.
Use Form 6252 [Income from Sale of Installment Receipts]. You may also want to use Form 4797 and Schedule D (Form 1040).

The tax credit applies to the start-up costs of a new qualifying fixed-benefit or fixed-payment plan (including a 401(k) plan), SIMPLE plan or simplified employee retirement plan (SEP). For more information, see Publication 560, Retirement Plans for Small Businesses.
The tax benefit applies to wages paid to eligible employees on family leave and sick leave, subject to certain conditions. For more information, see Form 8994.
The tax credit is generally applied to each eligible low-income building that is put into use after 1986. For more information, see Form 8586.
The tax benefit provides incentives for businesses to hire individuals from target groups with extremely high unemployment or other special employment needs. For more information, see Form 5884.
The tax benefit provides incentives for companies to continue to pay salaries to employees who have served more than 30 days in a U.S. uniform service unit. For more information, see Form 8932.
This tax benefit applies to eligible expenses you pay for employee childcare services and eligible expenses you pay for childcare resources and referral services. For more information, see Form 8882.
This tax benefit applies to the cost of several health insurance policies you provide to several employees. For more information, see Form 8941.

This chapter explains operating income, how to account for operating income on your tax return, what items are not considered income, and provides criteria for choosing an occupation. If any income you earn is related to your business, it is operating income. If it is clear that no income payments are made without a business, there is a link. Even if you are not active on a formal full-time basis, you may still have operating income. Income from work outside your regular occupation may be operating income. For example, you may be operating a co-working business as a second job. You should report most of your operating income on Form C, such as income from the sale of your products or services. However, you should report income from the sale of business assets (such as land and office buildings) on other forms than Form C. For information on selling business assets, see Chapter 3.

Operating income includes the amounts received in your business and correctly shown on the 1099-NEC. This includes the amounts declared as non-employee compensation in box 1 of the 1099-NEC. For more information, see the notes on the back of the 1099-NEC you receive.

If you have NIL income (including non-cash income) from any source in excess of $600, you should receive a Form 1099-NEC or Form 1099-MISC from that source, showing the amount of income you must report on your tax return.

If you are a business owner, you may receive a Form 1099-K to reflect the total dollar amount of all reportable payment transactions. This may not be the amount you should report as income, as it may not include all income items and may include items not listed in your income items (such as sales tax).

The income you report on Form C may be eligible operating income, which entitles you to a deduction on Form 1040 or 1040-SR line 13. To calculate your deduction (if any), refer to Form 8995-A or 8995.

Unless exempted by law, you must report all income from your business, including income that is not reported to you on the payer's Form 1099. In most cases, your business income is presented in the form of cash, checks, and credit card charges. However, business income may also be presented in other forms, such as property or services. These and other types of income are explained below. If you are a U.S. citizen and you have business income from sources outside the U.S. (foreign income), you must report this income on your tax return unless you are exempt from taxation under U.S. law. If you reside outside the U.S., you may be able to opt out of reporting some or all of your business income from a foreign source. For more information, see the Tax Guide to U.S. Citizens and Residents Abroad and the Definitions of Tax Law, Issue 54.

Barter means the exchange of property or services. When you receive total income, you must include in total income the fair market value of the property or service you receive in exchange for other property or service. If you exchange services with someone else and you have agreed in advance on the value of the service, the value is considered to be the fair market value unless it can be shown that the value is different.

If you are a real estate dealer who earns income from renting property, or an owner of a property such as a hotel, motel, etc., which provides services to guests (maid services, etc.), report rental income and expenses on Form C. If you are not a real estate dealer or an owner as described in the previous sentence, report rental income and expenses on Form E. For more information, see Bulletin No. 527, Residential Rental Business.

If you are a self-employed trailer park owner who provides trailer parking spaces and facilities and substantial services for the convenience of tenants, you are liable to self-employment tax on the rental income from the trailer park. If the services are provided primarily for the convenience of tenants and not usually for the maintenance of occupied parking spaces, you are generally considered to provide substantial services to tenants. These services are substantial if the compensation for the services constitutes a substantial part of the tenant's rent. Examples of services provided not usually for the convenience of tenants include the maintenance and maintenance of the entertainment hall provided by the parking lot, the distribution of monthly electronic newspapers to tenants, the operation of laundry facilities, and the assistance of tenants in buying or selling trailers. Examples of services provided usually to keep the site available for tenants' use include municipal sewage treatment, electrical connections and road maintenance.

If you provide services to residents, you are liable to self-employment tax on the rental income you collect for the use or stay of the hotel, hostel or apartment by the residents. In general, you are considered to provide services to residents if the services are primarily for the convenience of the residents and are not services that are normally provided with the rental of rooms for residential use only. One of the services that are normally not provided for the convenience of the residents is maid service. However, the provision of heating and lighting, cleaning of stairs and lobbies, and garbage collection are services that are normally provided for the convenience of the residents.

Advances collected under a lease that does not impose any restrictions on the use or enjoyment of the property by the occupants are income in the year in which you earn it. This is usually the same regardless of the accounting method or period you use.
If your tenant makes payments to others under an agreement to pay off your debts or obligations, include these payments in your total income when the tenant makes the payment.

The amount of money you receive for the lessee's performance of the obligation to restore the leased property to its original state, in excess of the adjustment base for the repair of the leased property destroyed, damaged, demolished or broken by the tenant, is income.

If you are engaged in the business of renting movable property (equipment, vehicles, furniture, etc.), include the rent you receive in your total income on Schedule C. The advance rent and other payments discussed in the discussion of Real Estate Rentals above may also be received from the rental of movable property. If you receive any such payments, include them in your total income as described in the relevant discussion.
Interest earned on receivables you accept in the ordinary course of business is operating income. If you are engaged in lending, interest earned on loans is operating income.

If a loan due to you cannot be recovered in the tax year and you use accrual accounting, you usually have to include in gross income the qualifying statutory interest accrued until the loan is not recoverable. If the accrued interest you previously included is not recoverable, you can deduct the bad account. See Bad accounts in Chapter 8.

If little or no interest is charged on an installment sales contract, you may want to treat a portion of each payment as unspecified interest. See Publication 537, Unspecified Interest and Original Issue Discount (OID).

In general, dividends are operating income for a stock dealer. However, for most sole proprietors and statutory employees, dividends are non-operating income. If you hold shares as a personal investment separate from your business activity, dividends from shares are non-operating income. If you receive dividends from business insurance premiums deducted in the previous year, you must declare all or part of the dividends as operating income on your tax return. For the amount you have to declare, see the section on Reclaiming previous deductions, which is listed below under Other income.
The general rule and the exceptions to the general rule for the inclusion of cancelled obligations in income are explained below.

In general, if your debt is cancelled or relieved, except as a gift or bequest, you must include the cancelled amount in your total income for tax purposes. If the debt was incurred in your business, report the cancelled amount on line 6 of Schedule C. If the debt is a non-commercial debt, report the cancelled amount on line 8c of Schedule 1 (Form 1040).
Some exceptions to the general rule covering cancelled debts are discussed below.

If you owe a seller a debt on the property you purchased and the seller reduces the amount you owe, you will usually not receive any income from the decrease in the debt. Unless you are bankrupt or insolvent, treat the amount reduced as a purchase price adjustment and reduce your property base.
If the repayment of the debt results in a deduction, you will not receive income from the cancelled debt.

The exclusions in cases 2 to 5 do not apply if the cancelled debt was incurred in the insolvency case and is not included in income. If the debt was incurred when you were insolvent and you are insolvent, the exclusions in cases 3 and 4 do not apply.
For the purposes of this discussion, debts include any debts you must incur or attach to your property.

You may choose not to include the cancelled portion of the eligible real estate commercial debt (up to a certain limit). If you choose to do so, you must reduce the base of the depreciable old real estate by the amount not included. This reduction is made at the beginning of the tax year following the tax year in which the cancellation occurred. However, if you dispose of the real estate earlier, you must reduce its base immediately before the disposal.

Eligible real estate commercial liabilities include the refinancing of debt described in (3) above, but only to the extent of the refinanced debt. If you are the owner of an omitted entity (e.g., a sole proprietorship), please refer to Eligible Real Estate Commercial Liabilities in Chapter 1 of Bulletin 4681 to determine whether you qualify for the exclusion. The amount you exclude cannot exceed any of the following: 1. The difference, if any, between: 1. The outstanding principal of the eligible real estate commercial liability (immediately prior to cancellation); 2. The fair market value of the commercial real estate secured for the liability (immediately prior to cancellation) less the outstanding principal of any other eligible real estate commercial liability secured for the liability immediately prior to cancellation; 3. The total base of amortising real estate you held immediately prior to cancellation. These adjusted bases are determined after any downward adjustment due to cancellation of the debt in bankruptcy or insolvency or cancellation of the eligible farm debt. Do not consider the purchase of amortising real estate in the proposed cancellation.
The following discussion explains how to treat other types of operating income that you may receive.

If you receive restricted stocks or other property in return for services, the fair market value of the property in excess of your cost is included in your income on Schedule C after the restriction is lifted. However, you may elect to pay tax in the year in which you receive the property. For more information on how to include restricted property in your income, see Publication 525, Taxable and Non-Taxable Income.
In the following cases, you will return the discounted old deduction. This means that you will include in your income some or all of the discounted old amounts you deducted in the previous year.

If, in a tax year following the tax year in which you put the listed property into use, your commercial rate for the listed property (as explained in Chapter 8, Depreciation) drops to 50% or less, you may be required to return part of the depreciation deduction. You can include in your income on Schedule C the amount of the part of the depreciation you deducted in previous years. Use Form 4797, Part IV, to calculate the amount to be included on Schedule C. For more information, see What is a Business Requirement?, in Chapter 5 of Bulletin 946. This chapter explains how to determine whether the property is used for more than 50% of your business.

If you apply the Section 179 deduction (explained in Chapter 8, Depreciation) to an asset and before the end of the recovery period and the commercial rate falls to 50% or less, you must refund part of the Section 179 deduction. You can include the part of the deduction you applied in your income on Schedule C. Use Form 4797, Part 4, to calculate the amount included on Schedule C. Refer to Chapter 2 of Bulletin 946 for information on when you can refund the deduction.

If you receive income from the sale or dealing of depreciable property, you may want to treat all or part of the income from depreciation as ordinary income. Calculate the income from the rebate of the depreciation in Part Three of Form 4797. For more information, see Chapter 4 of Bulletin 544.

Please report bills and other evidence of debt issued to you in connection with the sale or transaction of property held as trading inventory or primarily for sale to customers on Form C. Normally, you report them at the principal amount (less any unspecified interest) or issue price (for debt instruments with an OID) as stated on them when you receive them.

If you reduce or discontinue your business, report on Form C any payments you receive from insurance or other sources for lost business income. Even if your business is inactive when you receive the payment, report the payments on Form C.

You must include in your total income any compensation you receive during the tax year for any of the following damages related to your business: Patent infringement. Breach of contract or duty of good faith. Antitrust damages.

You may be entitled to a deduction from your income if it compensates for your actual economic loss. Your deduction is the lesser of the following amounts: The amount of damages you received or accrued in the tax year less the amount you paid or incurred in that tax year to recover damages. The loss you incurred from the damages that have not yet been deducted.

If you receive any discounts, include them in income in Schedule C. However, if you have correctly treated the discounts as a reduction in the related expense item, capital expenditure or cost of sales, do not include the discounts.

If you recover a bad account or any other item deducted in a previous year, include the recovered amount in your income on Form C. However, if all or part of the amount deducted in an earlier year did not reduce your tax, you may exclude the amount that did not reduce your tax. If you do not include the partial recovery in your income, you must include a calculation on your tax return showing how you calculated the amount excluded.
In some cases, the property or money you receive is not income.
The increase in the value of your property is not income until you have realized the value increase through sale or other taxable disposition.

If a tenant builds a building or improves your property, the value increase of the property as a result of the improvement is not your income. However, if it is proven that the improvement is a way of paying rent to you, the value increase is income.
The amount borrowed through a goodwill loan is not income.
State and local sales taxes that you must collect and pay to the state or local government and that are levied on the buyer are not income.

The sending of goods to sell on your behalf is not a sale. The ownership of the goods remains with you (the sender). Therefore, if you transport goods by sending, you do not incur any profit or loss until the sending sells the goods. The goods you send by sending are included in your inventory until they are sold. Do not include in your inventory the goods you receive by sending. When you sell goods sent to you or receive profits or commissions on the goods, include these profits or commissions in your income, depending on the accounting method you use.

Some medical assistance exemption payments reported to you on Form 1099-MISC or Form 1099-NEC may not be taxable. For more information on how to report these payments, see the instructions on Form C (Form 1040).

If you entered into a lease after August 5, 1997 and you receive a building allowance (in the form of cash or a rent relief) from the landlord in either of the following cases, you may not include the building allowance in your income: a) under a short-term lease of retail space; b) for the purpose of building or improving eligible long-term real estate in the retail space for the use of your business; c) for the purpose of building or improving eligible long-term real estate in the retail space for the use of your business.

Short-term leases, i.e., leases of retail space (or other occupancy or use agreements) for 15 years or less. The following rules apply to determining whether the lease term is 15 years or less. When calculating whether the lease term is 15 years or less, consider the renewal option. However, do not consider any renewal option executed at the fair market value determined at the time of renewal. If two or more consecutive leases are part of the same transaction (or a series of related transactions) for the same or roughly similar retail space, they are considered to be the same lease.

You are a direct seller if you meet all of the following conditions: 1. You engage in any of the following types of transaction or business: 1. You sell or solicit the sale of consumer goods at home or elsewhere but not in a retail store, or sell or solicit the sale of consumer goods to any buyer on a purchase-to-sale or deposit-to-commission basis at home or elsewhere but not in a retail store; 2. You deliver or distribute newspapers or shopping news (including any service directly related to the transaction or business); 2. The vast majority of the payments you make for the aforementioned services (whether paid in cash or not) are directly related to sales or other results other than hours worked (including the provision of services); 3. You provide services under a written contract with the person to whom you provide the services, and that contract provides that you are not considered an employee for federal tax purposes.

If you are a licensed real estate agent or direct seller and both of the following apply, you must report your income on Form C. As a real estate agent or direct seller, all of your service fees are essentially directly related to your sales or other output, not to the number of hours you work. You provide services under a written contract, which stipulates that you are not considered an employee for federal tax purposes.

If you are an option or commodity trader, you must report on Schedule C the gains and losses you incur from trading or selling Section 1256 contracts (regulated futures contracts, foreign exchange contracts, non-equity options, dealer stock options and dealer securities futures contracts) or property related to these contracts (e.g., stocks used to hedge options). For more information, see Sections 1256 and 1402(i).

If you engage in the business of buying and selling securities or commodities for your own account, you are a securities or commodity dealer. As a securities or commodity dealer (including if you have made the option as a securities or commodity dealer to calculate at market price under section 475(f)), your gains or losses on the disposal of securities or commodities are not reported on Schedule C. For more information on securities or commodity dealers, see Publication 550, Investment Income and Expenses and Item 429 - Securities Traders.

As a former self-employed insurance agent, you do not report on Form C the fees you receive from an insurance company for providing services to it. You receive payment after the agreement to provide services to the company expires. You do not provide any services to the company after the agreement expires and before the end of the year in which you receive payment. You contract to not compete with the company for at least one year from the date of the expiration of your agreement. The amount of the payment depends primarily on the number of policies sold or credited to your account by you in the last year of your agreement, or the extent to which those policies remain valid for any period after the agreement expires, or both. The amount of the payment does not depend on the length of service or any extent of the total income from services provided to the company (whether eligibility for payment is dependent on the length of service or not).

Income paid by insurance companies to retired self-employed insurance agents on the basis of a percentage of pre-retirement commissions is reported on Form C. Similarly, renewal commissions or deferred commissions for pre-retirement sales activities are usually reported on Form C. However, renewal commissions paid to surviving insurance agents are not reported on Form C.

The rules apply to payments from state funds to elected taxpayers as a fixed percentage of taxes collected. A civil servant includes any elected or appointed position in a wholly-owned body of the United States or its territories, the District of Columbia, the state or its sub-political unit, or any of the above. If a civil servant of a state or local government is paid on a cost-only basis and his or her service qualifies for social security insurance under a federal-state agreement, but is not covered by such insurance, he or she shall declare on Form C the expenses incurred from the public.

The accounting treatment of revenue for income tax purposes may sometimes differ from that for financial purposes. This section discusses some of the more common differences that may affect business transactions. Calculate operating revenue for the tax year and your usual accounting method (see Chapter 2). If the sale of products is a factor in your business's income generation, you will usually use inventory to clearly reflect your revenue. Real estate dealers cannot use inventory. For more information on inventory, see Chapter 2.
You must pay tax on all income you earn. You cannot avoid tax by paying it to a third party.

If you use another method, your credit balance at the end of the tax year is your operating income. Under this method, you cannot reduce the cost of sales by the amount of the cash discount received. When estimating the value of inventory at the end of the tax year, you cannot subtract the invoice price of the goods in stock at the end of the tax year from the average or estimated discount received for the goods.

If the buyer of your property has placed part or all of the purchase price in trust, do not include any part of the purchase price in your total income until you have actually or presumably received the purchase price. However, after the terms of the contract and trust agreement have been fulfilled, you will generate taxable income even if you do not accept the purchase price until the following year.

If you receive insurance or other types of compensation for accident or theft losses, you must deduct this compensation from the loss when calculating the deduction. You cannot deduct the compensable part of the accident or theft loss. For information on accident or theft losses, see Bulletin No. 547.

If you manufacture or purchase goods for sale, you may deduct the cost of sales from your total income on Schedule C. However, to determine these costs, you must estimate the value of your inventory at the beginning and end of each tax year. This chapter applies to you if you are a manufacturer, wholesaler, or engaged in any business in which you produce, purchase, or sell goods for income. This chapter does not apply to personal service businesses, such as doctors, lawyers, carpenters, or painters. However, if you engage in personal service businesses and also sell materials and supplies normally used in your business, or collect the cost of such materials and supplies, this chapter applies to you. There are some exceptions that are suitable for small business taxpayers. These circumstances may change the way you calculate the cost of selling your business. For more information, see Chapter 2.

If you donate inventory (i.e., property you sell in the course of business), you can report a donation deduction of the lesser of its fair market value on the date you donated the inventory and its inventory base. The base of the donated inventory is any cost incurred in an earlier year due to the inventory that should have been included in your initial inventory in the year of the donation. You must deduct your donation deduction from your initial inventory. This is not part of the cost of sales. If the cost of the donated inventory is not included in your initial inventory, the inventory base is zero, so you cannot report a charitable donation deduction. Treat the inventory cost as you normally do. For example, include the purchase price of the inventory purchased in the year and donated in the cost of sales in the year. Special rules may apply to some food stock donations. See Bulletin 526.

The difference between the stated price of the goods and the actual price you pay for them is called a trade discount. When calculating the purchase cost, you must use the price you paid (rather than the stated price). Please do not show the discount as a separate item in total revenue. Car dealers must record the cost of inventory cars and deduct any discounts that the manufacturers have given as trade discounts.

Cash discounts are amounts that your supplier allows you to deduct from your purchase invoices in order to make timely payments. There are two methods of accounting for cash discounts. You can post the cash discount to the credit of a separate discount account or deduct it from the total purchases during the year. Whichever method you use, keep it in place. If you want to change the method of calculating inventory cost, you must file Form 3115. For more information, see Chapter 2 Changes in Accounting. If you post cash discounts to the credit of a separate account, you must include the balance of the credit in your operating income at the end of the tax year. If you use this method, you cannot reduce your sales costs through cash discounts.

If you withdraw goods for personal or household use, you must deduct the cost from the total amount of the goods you purchase for sale. Please record the cost of the goods you withdraw for personal or household use on the credit of the purchase or sale account. You must also deduct the amount from your withdrawal account. The withdrawal account is a separate account that you should keep to record the operating income you withdraw to cover personal and household expenses. As mentioned above, you also use the withdrawal account to record goods withdrawn for personal or household use. This account is also called a withdrawal account or personal account.

Direct labor costs are the wages you pay to employees who work full-time directly on the product to be produced. These costs also include the part of the wages you pay to part-time employees who work directly on the product (if you can determine that part).

Indirect labor costs are the wages you pay to employees who perform general factory functions that have no immediate or direct connection to the production of a sellable product, but are an essential part of the production process.
Containers and packaging as part of the product are part of the cost of sale. If the containers and packaging are not part of the product, then these costs are transportation or sales expenses.
The inbound freight, inbound express and inbound handling costs of the raw materials, supplies and goods you purchase for sale are all part of the cost of sales.

Administrative costs include rent, heat, lighting, electricity, insurance, depreciation, tax, maintenance, labor and supervision.Â Administrative costs incurred as direct necessary expenses of your manufacturing business are included in your cost of sales.

Line 40 subtracts the value of your end-of-year inventory (including, where appropriate, the allocable portion of raw material and supply costs, direct labor costs, and management costs). The end-of-year inventory is also called the end-of-period or final inventory. Your final inventory usually becomes the beginning inventory of the next tax year.

Calculate net income first before calculating gross income. Use total income (line 1) minus any refunds and allowances (line 2) to calculate net income (line 3) on Schedule C. Refunds and allowances include cash or credit refunds, discounts and other allowances deducted from actual sales prices provided to customers during the year. Then, subtract the cost of sales (line 4) from net income (line 3). The result is your gross operating income.

If the sale of goods is not a revenue-generating factor in your business, you do not have to calculate the cost of selling. Your gross is equal to your net income (total income minus any refunds, discounts or other allowances). Most professions and businesses that sell services (rather than products) can calculate their gross directly from net income in this way.

At the end of each business day, make sure your records are in line with the actual cash and credit receipts for that day. You may find that using cash machines is helpful in recording revenue. You should also use an appropriate invoice system and open a separate bank account for your business.

Please check to make sure your records show the correct amount of sales tax collected. If you are a seller of goods or services and collect state and local sales taxes from buyers, you must include the amount collected in your total revenue. If you collect state and local taxes from buyers and remit them to the state or local government, you do not usually have to include these amounts in your revenue.

If you are taking any inventory items for personal use (for yourself, for family, or as personal gifts), make sure to remove these items from the cost of sales. For details on how to adjust the cost of sales, see Chapter 6. Goods charged from sales.

Check to make sure you have adequate point-of-sale inventory procedures. These procedures should ensure that all items are included in the inventory and that appropriate pricing techniques are used. Use inventory forms and adding paper as the only evidence of inventory. Inventory forms are available at office supplies stores. These forms contain columns for recording the description, quantity, unit price and value of each inventory item. Each page has blank spaces for recording the person who actually counted, priced, deferred and validated the calculations. These forms help you to verify the accuracy of the total inventory. These forms also provide permanent records to confirm its validity. Inventory has been discussed in Chapter 2.

If you are a retailer or wholesaler, you can check the accuracy of your gross figures. First, divide your net revenue by gross. The resulting percentage measures the average price difference between the cost of selling a product and the price at which it is sold. Then, compare this percentage with your pricing policy. If the two percentages differ slightly or not at all, your gross figures are accurate. If the two percentages differ significantly, it may indicate that you have not accurately calculated sales, purchases, inventory or other cost items. You should determine the reason for the difference.

You run a retail business. Typically, you increase prices on goods so that you can make a 331/3% margin on your sales. Your net income (total income minus rebate and allowances) on your profit and loss statement is $300,000. Your cost of sales is $200,000. This gives you a $100,000 margin ($300,000 − $200,000). To test the accuracy of your performance for the year, you divide net income ($300,000) by margin ($100,000). The resulting 331/3% proves that your 331/3% margin is correct.

If your company has income from sources other than normal business, enter the income on line 6 of Schedule C and add it to the gross. The result is the total operating income. Examples include income from interest-bearing checking accounts, income from sales of scrap, income from various fuel tax concessions and refunds, and amounts recovered from bad accounts.

SEP, SIMPLE and eligible plans provide you and your employees with some tax relief to save for retirement. You can deduct the contributions you make to the plan on behalf of your employees on Schedule C, line 19. If you are a sole proprietor, you can deduct your own contributions to the plan on Schedule 1 (Form 1040), line 16. If the contributions to the plan do not cover the expenses of a trustee, you can also deduct those expenses. Income from contributions is usually tax-free until you or your employees receive a plan allocation. You may also be able to file for tax relief if you start a new qualifying fixed-benefit or fixed-payment plan (including a 401(k) plan), SIMPLE or SEP. For details on this tax credit and the tax credits for automatic enrollment and military spouse participation, see Form 8881 and its separate description. Under some plans, employees may have you pay a small amount of your pre-tax salary to the plan. Until your employees receive a plan allocation, these amounts (and income from them) are usually tax-free. For more information on small business retirement plans, see Publication 560. Publication 590-A, Personal Retirement Arrangements (IRA) Contributions, discusses other ways to get tax relief and save for retirement.

You cannot claim a rent deduction for unreasonable rent. Normally, the question of reasonability arises when you are associated with the landlord. Rent paid to an associate is reasonable if it is the same as the amount you would pay to a stranger using the same property. Rent is not unreasonable simply because it is calculated as a percentage of total income. Associates include your immediate family, including siblings (in full or half-breed relationship), your spouse, your ancestors and your immediate descendants. For a list of other associates, see section 267 of the Internal Revenue Code.

You can deduct on Form C the state taxes your business directly incurred and levied on gross income (other than net income). If you list your deductions item by item, you can deduct other state and local income taxes on Form A (Form 1040). Please do not deduct federal or local income taxes.

You can deduct social security taxes, health insurance taxes and FUTA taxes paid as an employer from your funds. Employment taxes have been briefly discussed in Chapter 1. You can also deduct payments made as an employer to the state unemployment compensation fund or to the state disability benefit fund.

You can deduct on Form C any taxes levied by the state or local government on movable property used in your business. You can also deduct registration fees for the use of property within the state or local territory.

Please consider any sales tax you pay on a service or on the purchase or use of property as part of the cost of the service or property. If the service, cost or use of the property is a deductible operating expense, you may deduct the tax as part of the service or cost. If the property is purchased for resale, sales tax is part of the cost of the goods. If the property is depreciable, add sales tax to the depreciation base. For information on the property base, see Bulletin 551. Please do not deduct state and local sales taxes levied on the buyer. You must collect and formally pay these sales taxes to the state or local government. Please do not include these taxes in your total income or sales.

You can usually deduct the amount of travel and meals you report for your employees. The amount you deduct and how you do it depends in part on whether you report your expenses on a Realized Sales Plan or a Non-Realized Sales Plan. For more information, see Publication 15. This publication explains Realized Sales Plans and Non-Realized Sales Plans and whether you report the amount on your employees' W-2 forms.

You can deduct the cost of using these vehicles and other types of transportation between the airport or station and your hotel or between your hotel and the place of work where you leave home on business.
You may deduct the cost of shipping luggage and samples or display materials between your regular and temporary workplaces.

To qualify under the Common Use Test, you must have a specific area of your residence in continuous commercial use. If you only occasionally or incidentally use the area for commercial purposes, you do not qualify for the test, even if you do not use the area for any other purpose.

You may also be able to deduct the following expenses. Advertising. Bank charges. Donations to commercial organizations. Educational expenses. Loss-reduction-related expenses. Interview expense allowance. Licensing and regulatory fees. Mobile machinery. Re-employment services. Fines and penalties you pay for late performance or non-performance of contracts. Repair and maintenance of real or tangible movable property. Repayment income. Supplies and materials. Utilities.

You cannot generally deduct as operating expenses: Bribes and rebate; Charity donations; Removal fees or losses; Business, social, sports, lunch, sports, air and hotel club fees; Entertainment expenses; Real estate or tangible property improvements. An improvement is an amount paid for work to improve, restore or make the property suitable for a new or different use. Lobbying fees. Fines and fines paid to government agencies or departments for breaching laws. Personal, living and household expenses. Political donations. Settlements or payments related to sexual harassment or sexual assault (if the settlement or payment is subject to a nondisclosure agreement). Nor can you deduct attorneys' fees related to the settlement or payment.

If someone owes you money and you cannot pay it back, you have a bad debt. There are two types of bad debt - business bad debt and non-business bad debt. Business bad debt is usually a debt that arises from the conduct of your business or business. You may be able to deduct business bad debt as an expense on your company's tax return.

If you incur a debt for a commercial reason, the debt is directly related to your business. Business bad debt is primarily generated by selling goods to customers. Business bad debt may also be generated by providing loans to suppliers, customers, employees or vendors. Goods and services for which customers have not paid are shown in your ledger as receivables or bills of lading. If you cannot collect any part of these receivables or bills of lading, the uncollectible part is business bad debt. You can only deduct bad debt on these receivables and bills of lading if the amount you owe is included in your total income for the year in which you declare the deduction or for the previous year.

If you apply for a bad account deduction on your income tax return and subsequently recover all or part of it, you may have to include all or part of the refund in your total income. You include only the amount you actually deducted. However, you can exclude the amount of the deduction that did not reduce your tax. Report the refund as "Other income" on the appropriate business form or schedule. For more information, see Refunds in Bulletin 525.

All other bad accounts are non-business bad accounts and may be deducted as short-term capital losses on Form 8949 and Schedule D (Form 1040). For more information on non-business bad accounts, see Section 166 and its provisions.

If you use accrual accounting, you usually report income when it is earned. If you have already included uncollectible amounts in your income, you can make a bad account deduction for uncollectible receivables.

If you use cash accounting, you usually report income when you receive payments. If you do not include in your income amounts owed to you by others that you have not received and cannot recover, you cannot make bad account deductions for these.

If you sell a business but keep its receivables, these liabilities are business liabilities, because they are generated by your trade or business. If these receivables subsequently become worthless, the loss remains a business bad debt.

The losses caused by the debts of the enterprises acquired from the deceased are determined in the same way as the debts acquired by the enterprises acquired. If the debts become worthless are closely related to the deceased's trade or business, the executor of the deceased's estate shall treat any losses caused by the debts as business bad debt. Otherwise, the losses of these debts shall become non-business bad debt of the deceased's estate.
If you liquidate your business and some of the receivables you have kept become worthless, they will be considered business bad debts.
A business bad debt is a debt you have to a customer, supplier, employee or dealer for business purposes and you are trying to collect it but are unable to.

If a political party (or other organization that accepts donations or spends money to influence elections) owes you money and the debt becomes worthless, you can only declare a bad account deduction if all of the following conditions are met: 1. You use an accrual accounting method. 2. The debt is incurred as a result of your sale of goods or services in the normal course of trade or business. 3. More than 30% of the receivables due in the year of sale are from sales to the political party. 4. You have made substantial and sustained efforts to collect the debt.
If, based on the facts and circumstances, the loan you provide to the company is actually an investment in capital, you cannot declare the bad deduction.

If your business partnership breaks down and one of your former partners becomes insolvent, you may have to pay more than your pro-rata share of the partnership's debt. If you pay any part of the insolvent partner's share of the debt, you can claim a bad debt deduction for the amount you paid for the insolvent partner's share.

The debt you guaranteed is eligible for business bad debt if it subsequently becomes worthless and meets all of the following requirements: You made the guarantee in the course of trade or business. You have a legal obligation to pay the debt. You guaranteed before the debt became worthless. You meet this requirement if you reasonably expect that you will not be required to pay the debt if the borrower fails to repay it in full. You received reasonable remuneration for making the guarantee. You meet this requirement if you guaranteed in the ordinary course of business or for a bona fide commercial purpose.
If you have paid off a secured loan, you can make a deduction in the year of payment, unless you have a right against the borrower.

When you pay off a secured loan, you may have the right to take the place of the lender. You become the creditor of the debt. If you have the debt or other rights to demand payment from the borrower, you cannot claim the bad debt deduction until those debt or rights have become partly or wholly worthless.
If two or more debtors jointly owe you money and you cannot collect it from one of them, you cannot deduct the corresponding amount as bad debt.
If the sale price of the mortgaged or pledged property is lower than the debt, the unpaid, uncollectible balance of the debt is bad account.

The debt becomes worthless when it is impossible to repay the amount owed. This can happen on or before the due date. To prove the debt is worthless, you only need to prove that you have taken reasonable steps to collect it, but that it is not recoverable.

If you receive property in partial settlement, deduct the debt by the FMV of the property, and the FMV will be the base of the property. If the remaining debt becomes worthless, you can deduct it as a bad account. If you later sell the property at a price higher than its base, any proceeds from the sale will be attributed to the value increase of the property. This is not a repayment of the bad account. For information on selling assets, see Law 544.

You can deduct certain bad debt that is partially uncollectible in the tax year. Your tax deduction is limited to the amount you have cleared from the books in the year. You do not have to clear and deduct part of the debt that is worthless every year. You can defer the clearing to a later year. However, after the year in which the debt becomes completely worthless, you cannot deduct any part of the debt. There are two rules to consider with regard to clearing debt: Significantly modified debt. There are exceptions to the clearing rule for debt that has been substantially modified and the holder has recognized the profit. For more information, see Rule 1.166-3(a)(3). Unpermitted deductions. In general, you can only declare a partial bad debt deduction in the year that you cleared from the books. If the IRS does not allow you to deduct in a tax review and part of the debt becomes worthless in a subsequent tax year, you can deduct the amount you cleared in the year plus the amount that was not allowed to be cleared in the previous year. Unless a rollover is recorded in your books, the clearing in the previous year will meet the clearing requirement for the following year.

If a debt becomes worthless in the current tax year, you can deduct its entire amount minus any amount you deducted in a previous tax year when the debt was only partly worthless. You do not have to make a physical sale on the books to declare a bad account deduction for a debt that is completely worthless. However, you may want to make a physical sale on the books. If you do not do so, and the IRS later determines that the debt is only partly worthless, you will not be able to deduct the debt in that tax year because the deduction for a partially worthless bad account is limited to the amount that was actually sold. See Partially worthless debt above.

Local commercial transportation does not include expenses incurred when you leave home overnight for business. These expenses can be deducted as travel expenses and are discussed in Travel and Meals below. However, if you use your own car to leave home overnight for business, you should calculate your car deduction according to the rules in this section. In general, your tax domicile is your usual business address, regardless of where your home is located. This includes the entire city or general area in which you conduct your business or work.

In addition to using the standard mileage rate, you can deduct any business-related parking and transit charges. (Parking charges paid for parking at the workplace are non-deductible commuting expenses.)

You can write off a property if it meets all of the following requirements. It must be your property. It must be used for business or generate income. Since inventory is not held for your business, you can never write off inventory (explained in Chapter 2). It has a useful life far beyond the year it was put into use. The useful life must be determined, meaning that it must be for property that wears out, rots, wears out, becomes obsolete or loses value by natural causes. Since land does not wear out, wear out or become obsolete, you can never write off the cost of land. It cannot be an exceptional property. This includes property put into use and disposed of in the same year.

You may choose to treat some repairs or replacements in your transaction or business as depreciable improvements. You may choose to do so if you treat these amounts as capital expenditures in the books and records that are commonly used to calculate income and expenditure.

You can generally deduct the premiums paid for the following types of insurance related to your business: 1. Fire, theft, flood or similar insurance; 2. Credit insurance covering business losses; 3. Group hospitalization and medical insurance for employees, including long-term care insurance; 4. Liability insurance; 5. Professional liability insurance covering professional negligence and personal liability for injury or damage to patients or customers; 6. Labour indemnity insurance as required by state law, but covering any claims for personal injury or work-related illnesses suffered by employees of your business, whether or not faulty; 7. If contributions to the state unemployment insurance fund are considered taxable under state law, they are deductible as tax; 8. Management fees insurance covering business fees for the longer period of incapacity caused by your injury or illness; 9. Auto and other vehicle insurance covering liability, damages and other losses for vehicles used by your business. If you drive a vehicle partly for personal use, deduct only the premium applicable to the commercial part of the vehicle. If you calculate your car premium using standard mileage rates, you cannot deduct any car premiums; 10. Life insurance covering your employees (if you do not benefit directly or indirectly from a life insurance policy); 11. Business interruption insurance covering lost profits in the event of your business being shut down due to fire or other causes.

You cannot deduct insurance premiums for the following types of insurance. 1. Self-insured reserves. You cannot deduct the amounts entered into reserves for self-insurance. This applies even if you cannot purchase business insurance against certain business risks. However, your actual losses are allowed to be deducted. For more information, see Bulletin 547. 2. Decrease in income. You cannot deduct insurance premiums for policies to cover decreased income due to illness or disability. However, see item 8 above. 3. Certain life insurance and annuities. 1. For policies issued before June 9, 1997, you cannot deduct insurance premiums for such policies if you are a direct or indirect beneficiary of life insurance coverage for yourself, your employees or any person with an economic interest in your business. If a policyholder is obliged to repay a loan you issued with the proceeds of the policy, you are a potential beneficiary of the policy. If a person is the owner or part owner of your business and lends to your business, that person has an economic interest in your business. 2. For policies issued after June 8, 1997, you generally cannot deduct insurance premiums for any life insurance policy, savings policy or annuity policy if you are a direct or indirect beneficiary. No deduction is allowed regardless of who the policyholder is. 4. Insurance for obtaining loans. If you purchase life insurance for yourself or another person with an economic interest in your business to obtain a business loan or to secure a business loan, you cannot deduct insurance premiums as business expenses. You cannot deduct insurance premiums as interest on a business loan or as financing.
You may be able to deduct the amounts paid for health and dental insurance and qualifying long-term care insurance for you and your family.

If you have obtained an insurance plan established or considered established in your company through the Health Insurance Marketplace and you are applying for a premium tax benefit, please refer to Form 8962 and its separate explanation and use Publication 974.

Some taxpayers are required to limit their deductions for commercial interest expenditures. Refer to the instructions on Form 8990 to determine whether you want to limit your deductions for commercial interest expenditures, who must file Form 8990, and how some businesses can opt out of the limits for commercial interest expenditures. You cannot deduct interest paid on a personal loan on Form C. If the loan is partly for business and partly for personal use, you must separate the interest on the personal part and the business part.

Other considerations are: How to allocate interest between personal and commercial uses. Limits on commercial interest. When interest is deducted. Rules for loans below the market rate. (This is usually a loan that charges no interest or interest at a rate lower than the applicable federal rate.)

If the fees of lawyers and professionals (e.g., the fees of an accountant) are ordinary and necessary expenses directly related to the operation of your business, you can deduct them on Form C. However, you cannot normally deduct the fees of lawyers paid for the acquisition of business assets. Add these costs to the base of your property. If the fees include payments for work of a personal nature (e.g., making a will), you can only declare the commercial deduction for the part related to your business.

For tax purposes, a foreigner is a person who is not a U.S. citizen. A foreigner is divided into a non-tax resident and a tax resident. This publication will help you determine your status and provide you with the information you need to file a U.S. tax return. A tax resident is generally taxed on the same basis as a U.S. citizen on their global income. A non-tax resident is taxed only on their income from the U.S. and on certain income related to the conduct of trade or business in the U.S.

Termination of the 1979 Tax Agreement with Hungary. On July 15, 2022, the U.S. Treasury Department (the Treasury) announced that it had notified Hungary on July 8, 2022 that the U.S. would terminate the tax agreement with Hungary. In accordance with the termination provisions of the treaty, the termination takes effect on January 8, 2023. For withholding taxes, the treaty ceases to apply on January 1, 2024. For other taxes, the treaty ceases to apply for tax periods beginning on or after January 1, 2024. Qualifying disability trusts. In 2023, the exemption for qualifying disability is $4,700.

Non-tax residents (and some tax residents) from countries with which the United States has an income tax agreement may be eligible for certain benefits. Most agreements require non-tax residents to be residents of the agreement country in order to qualify for benefits in the year of claim. However, for some students, trainees, teachers or researchers, some agreements require only non-tax residents to have lived in the agreement country or in the United States prior to their arrival.

You can access the text of the most recently signed U.S. Income Tax Agreements, Protocols and Tax Information Exchange Agreements (TIEA) along with the accompanying Treasury Department Tax Agreements Technical Notes (which will be made publicly available), as well as the U.S. Income Tax Agreements templates, at Home.Treasury.gov/Policy-Issues/Tax-Policy/International-Tax.

Non-agreed income is the total income of a resident defined by non-tax law that is not restricted by the tax treaty. To determine the tax on income subject to the lower rent tax treaty rate, calculate the tax on agreed income at the lower rate applicable to that income under the treaty. To determine the tax on non-agreed income, calculate the tax at a flat rate or progressive rate of 30%, depending on whether the income is effectively linked to your trade or business in the United States. Your tax liability is the sum of the tax on agreed income plus the tax on non-agreed income, but not more than the tax liability calculated before the tax treaty entered into force.

The following paragraphs summarize the exemptions provided under the tax treaty for personal services income, remittances, scholarships, grants and capital gains. The conditions for claiming exemptions vary from tax treaty to tax treaty. For more information on the conditions under specific tax treaties, please download the full text of most U.S. tax treaties at: IRS.gov/Businesses/International-Businesses/United-States-Income-Tax-Treaties-A-to-Z. The site also provides technical notes for many of the treaties.

Under most income tax treaties, non-taxable residents of the treaty countries and dual-status residents who provide temporary services in the United States and are equally beneficial to the treaty country (see Chapter 1) may be eligible for exemption from U.S. tax on part or all of their personal income if they meet the requirements of the applicable treaty provisions.

Some income tax treaties contain "independent personal services" clauses, which allow residents of the treaty countries to be exempt from U.S. taxation on income earned as independent contractors or self-employed persons in the United States for a period of up to a certain number of days and without a fixed base regularly available in the United States.

Under many income tax treaties, temporary visits to the United States for the primary purpose of teaching at a university or other recognized educational institution are exempt from U.S. income tax on salaries received for teaching for the first two or three years after arrival. Many treaties provide exemptions for participation in research. In general, the principal purpose of a teacher or professor in the United States is to teach, lecture, direct or conduct research. The person must spend most of his or her time in these duties. The normal duties of a teacher or professor include not only formal classroom work (involving regularly scheduled lectures, presentations or other student participation activities), but also less formal presentation of views in seminars or other informal groups and in laboratory collaboration. If you have previously entered the United States as a non-tax resident but have now become a tax resident, the exemption from the treaty still applies. See the section on Students, apprentices, trainees, teachers, professors and researchers who have become tax residents below.
