All treaties provide for exemptions for certain income earned by foreign government employees. However, there are differences between treaties as to who is eligible for this benefit. Under many treaties, foreigners who are U.S. residents are not eligible. Under most treaties, foreigners who are not foreign nationals or subjects are not eligible. Foreign government employees should read the relevant agreements carefully to determine whether they are eligible for the benefit. Chapter 10 of this publication also contains information applicable to foreign government employees.

Tax Code residents are usually not eligible for tax treaty benefits, because most tax treaties contain a "retention clause" that preserves or "reserved" the U.S. right to tax its citizens and residents as if the tax treaty had not yet entered into force. However, many tax treaties have exceptions to the reservation clause, which may allow tax code residents to continue claiming tax treaty benefits. Some exceptions to the reservation clause apply to all tax code residents (e.g., under the US-China agreement); others apply to tax code residents who are only legal permanent residents outside the U.S. (green card holders). In some cases, you do not need to report income on Form 1040 or Form 1040-SR because the income is exempt from U.S. tax under the treaty. However, if income is already reported as taxable income on Form W-2, 1042-S, 1099, or other information return forms, you should report it on the corresponding line of Form 1040 or 1040-SR (e.g., line 1a in the case of wages or salaries reported in column 1 of Table W-2). In the brackets on line 8z of Schedule 1 (Form 1040), enter the amount of the claimed agreement benefit. Enter "Exempt income", the name of the agreement country and the agreement clause providing the exemption. Consolidate the amounts reported on lines 8a to 8z of Schedule 1 (Form 1040) and enter this amount on line 9. Then, merge the totals of lines 1 to 7 and 9 of Schedule 1 (Form 1040) and enter the total amount on line 10. Then, attach Table 1.

Generally, you must be a non-resident foreign student, apprentice, intern, teacher, professor or researcher to apply for a treaty exemption for remittances, scholarships, grants and research grants, and salaries or other personal services compensation that you need to study and live in the United States. Once you become a tax-defined resident, you usually cannot apply for a treaty exemption for this income. However, if you enter the United States as a non-tax-defined resident, but you are now a tax-defined resident for U.S. tax purposes, the treaty exemption will continue to apply if the reservation clause of the tax treaty (described above) provides an exception to it and you still meet the requirements for the treaty exemption (including any time limits for applying for the treaty exemption, described below). This is the case even if you are a non-tax-defined resident who has chosen to file a consolidation return, as described in Chapter 1. If you meet the exception to the treaty retention clause, you can avoid withholding income tax by providing the taxpayer with a Form W-9 and a statement that explains the requirements of the Form W-9.

In some cases, you do not need to report income on Form 1040 or Form 1040-SR because it is exempt from U.S. tax under the agreement. However, if the income has been reported as taxable income on Form W-2, Form 1042-S, Form 1099, or other information returns, you should report it on the corresponding line of Form 1040 or Form 1040-SR (for example, line 1a, the amount reported in box 1 of Form W-2).

You do not have to file Form 8833 for any of the following: 1. You request a reduction in the withholding tax rate on interest, dividends, rent, royalties or other FDAP income (usually at a 30% rate) under the agreement; 2. You request an agreement to reduce or modify the taxation of income from non-independent personal services, pensions, annuities, social security and other public pensions, or income from artists, athletes, students, trainees or teachers. This includes taxable scholarships and grants; 3. You require a reduction or modification of income tax under an international social security agreement or a diplomatic or consular agreement; 4. You are a partner in a partnership or a beneficiary of an inheritance or trust, and the partnership, inheritance or trust reports the information required on its tax return; 5. The total of the additional payments or income items that must be disclosed does not exceed $10,000; 6. You are claiming an agreement benefit for an amount that: 1. is reported to you on Form 1042-S; and 2. is received by you as a: 1. affiliate of a reporting company referred to in section 6038A (referring to a U.S. company with a 25% shareholding filed on Form 5472); or 2. a beneficial owner, i.e. a direct account holder of a U.S. financial institution or a qualifying intermediary, or a direct partner, beneficiary or owner of a foreign partnership or trust with withholding tax. The exceptions in (6) above do not apply to the disclosure of an agreement-based tax return on Form 8833 that describes special requirements.

Employees of international organizations may be exempt from tax on their salaries under the provisions of the international agreements establishing the international organizations, if any, or by meeting the requirements for such exemption under U.S. tax law. International "Organization" is an organization designated by the President of the United States by executive order and eligible for the privileges, exemptions and immunities provided for in the International Organizations Immunity Act. The exemptions discussed in this chapter apply only to remuneration received for the provision of official services to a foreign government or international organization. Other U.S.-sourced income earned by persons eligible for this exemption may be taxed in full or be treated preferentially under the terms of the applicable tax treaty. The appropriate treatment of such income (interest, dividends, etc.) has been discussed earlier in this publication.

You should first check the exemptions under the Vienna Convention or bilateral consular conventions (if any) to determine whether your salary qualifies for U.S. income tax exemption under those provisions.In general, if you are a U.S. citizen or resident as defined by tax law, you are not entitled to income tax exemptions under the Vienna Convention or bilateral consular conventions.For more information on the Vienna Convention and bilateral consular conventions, please email the Office of Foreign Missions of the Department of State at: OFMAssistants@state.gov.

If you are not eligible for tax exemption under the Vienna Convention or a bilateral consular treaty, but you are from a country with a tax treaty with the United States, you should check the tax treaty to see if it provides for exemption of U.S. income tax on your salary. If you are a U.S. citizen or a resident as defined by tax law in the United States who works for a foreign government, your salary is usually not exempt from tax. For more information, see the section on "Salary and pensions paid by foreign governments" in Bulletin 901.

However, please refer to the following Aliens who retain immigrant (legal permanent resident) status for special rules that may affect your eligibility for this exemption. To claim a tax exemption, you must be able to prove that you also meet the requirements of the U.S. and international tax laws.

A State Department certificate (if issued) is the easiest way to determine that you qualify for similar services and equivalent exemptions, but do not need to qualify for exemptions under U.S. tax law. For information on whether you have obtained a certificate and whether such certificate is currently valid and applicable to you, please email the Office of Foreign Missions of the State Department at OFMAssistants@state.gov. If no valid certificate is available, you must provide other written evidence that the services you provide are of a similar nature to those provided by U.S. government employees abroad and that the country of your foreign government employer provides equivalent tax exemptions to U.S. employees providing similar services in its country.

Many treaties establishing international organizations contain a clause that exempts your salary from U.S. income tax. If you are employed in the United States by an international organization, first check whether the international treaty establishing your international organization contains such a provision and whether you meet the requirement.

If the international agreement that created the international organization you are a member of does not contain a tax exemption clause and you are not a U.S. citizen (or if you are a U.S. citizen but also a citizen of the Republic of the Philippines), you may be exempt from payroll tax under U.S. law. However, see Foreigners who retain immigrant (legal permanent resident) status below for special rules that may affect your eligibility for this exemption. The exemption under the U.S. Tax Code applies only to current employees of international organizations, not former employees. Pensions received by former employees of international organizations residing in the U.S. do not qualify for the exemption discussed here....This exemption does not apply to independent contractors. The general law rules apply to determining whether you are an employee or an independent contractor. See Bulletin 1779 and Bulletin 15-A....To apply for an exemption, you must be able to prove that you meet the requirements of the international organization agreement clauses or U.S. tax law. You should know the clause number of the international organization agreement exemption clause (if any) and the executive order number designating the organization as an international organization.

If you sign an exemption under Section 247(b) of the Immigration and Nationality Act (USCIS Form I-508) to retain your legal permanent resident status (green card), you will no longer be eligible for tax exemption under U.S. tax law as of the date of submission of the exemption.
If you are a person in the above categories (1) or (2) and have declared an exemption under section 247(b) of the Immigration and Nationality Act, you must obtain a departure or exit permit.

Foreign students, industrial interns and exchange visitors, and their spouses and children, who hold an "F-1," "F-2," "H-3," "H-4," "J-1," "J-2," or "Q" visa and who have not received income from U.S. sources (other than grants to cover travel, maintenance and tuition costs for study or training in the United States) during the period of their visa in the United States; the value of any services or accommodation received in connection with the study or training; employment income received from a U.S. Citizenship and Immigration Services (USCIS) authorized source; or interest income from deposits that are not effectively linked to U.S. trade or business. (See Interest Income in Chapter 3.)

Foreign students, including spouses and children who entered the United States only on an "M-1" or "M-2" visa and did not earn income from U.S. sources while in the United States, except for the following: Earning employment income authorized by the U.S. Citizenship and Immigration Services (USCIS), or interest income from deposits that are not effectively linked to U.S. trade or business. (See Interest Income in Chapter 3.)

The IRS may require a foreigner to obtain a departure or exit permit if it has reason to believe that the foreigner has received taxable income and that the departure will affect tax collection.Aliens in this category are: 1. Foreign military trainees who enter the United States under the sponsorship of the Department of Defense for training and leave the United States under an official military movement order; 2. Foreign visitors who hold a "B-1" visa, or hold a "B-1" or "B-2" visa and stay in the United States or U.S. territory for no more than 90 days in the tax year; 3. Foreign visitors who travel to the United States on a "B-2" visa; 4. Foreigners who have a "C-1" visa or transit the United States or its territory under a contract between the transportation route and the Attorney General, such as a deposit agreement; and 5.Aliens who enter the United States with transit identification or who do not require a passport, visa or transit identification if they: 1. are visitors for inbound travel; 2. are business visitors who do not stay in the United States or U.S. territory for more than 90 days in the tax year; or 3. transit the United States or any of its territories.

You will get your departure or exit permit faster if you bring documents and documents related to your income and time of stay in the United States to the IRS office. If applicable, please carry the following documents with you. 1. Your passport and foreigner registration certificate or visa. 2. A copy of your U.S. income tax returns for the last two years. If you have been in the United States for less than two years, bring your income tax returns for that period. 3. Income tax receipts for these returns. 4. Receipts, bank records, cancelled cheques and other documents that prove your deductions, business expenses and claimed dependants. 5. Statements of salary and withholding tax paid by each employer from January 1 of the year to the date of departure (if you are an employee). If you are self-employed, you must carry a statement of income and expenses as of the date you plan to leave. 6. Proof of estimated tax payments for the past year and the current year. 7. Statements of any gains or losses from the sale of personal property and/or real estate (including capital assets and goods). 8. A copy of the grant application and approval letter. 9. A list of any previous grants. 10. Documents that show you are eligible for any special tax treaty benefits. 11. Documents that prove your date of departure from the United States, such as airline tickets. 12. Documents that verify your U.S. tax identification number (TIN), such as a Social Security card or IRS signature.

If you are required to obtain a departure or exit permit, you must file Form 2063 or Form 1040-C. An employee at your IRS office can assist with filing these forms. Both forms have a "Compliance Certification" section. When the Compliance Certification is signed by an agent in charge of the field assistance area, it certifies that you have fulfilled your U.S. tax obligations based on the information available. Your signed copy of Form 1040-C, or the document accompanying Form 2063, is your departure or exit permit.

If you are required to obtain a departure or exit permit and you are not eligible to file Form 2063, you must file Form 1040-C. In general, all income received or reasonably expected to be received in the tax year up to and including the date of departure must be reported on Form 1040-C and the above taxes must be paid. You will receive a departure or exit permit after you have filed any taxes shown on Form 1040-C and have filed all tax returns and paid all taxes due for the previous years. However, the IRS may allow you to provide a security deposit instead of paying taxes for a particular year. See the section on Security Deposits below. A departure or exit permit issued under the terms of this section applies only to the specific departure for which it is issued.

If you have provided the IRS with information that is satisfactory to the IRS that you intend to return to the United States and that your departure will not jeopardize the collection of income tax, you may obtain a departure or exit permit by filing a Form 1040-C without paying the taxes shown on it. However, you must file all outstanding income tax returns as required and pay all income tax due on those returns. Your signed Form 1040-C must include all income received and reasonably expected to be received during the entire departure year. A departure or exit permit issued on Form 1040-C may be used for all departures in that year. However, if the IRS believes that the collection of income tax is in doubt, it may cancel the use of the departure or exit permit for any subsequent departure.

Generally, you must pay the taxes shown on Form 1040-C. However, if all of your taxes due in previous years have been paid, you may provide a security deposit in lieu of paying the income tax shown on Form 1040-C, or if the deadline on your tax return is not yet due, a tax return for the previous year. The security deposit must be equal to the tax due as calculated by the IRS on the date of the payment plus interest. Information on the security deposit and its form can be obtained from the IRS office.

If you live outside the United States, you can call TAS: +15.15.56.46.827. Depending on your location, your call will be automatically transferred to Hawaii or Puerto Rico. If you choose Spanish, your call will be transferred to the Puerto Rico office for assistance.

In no event will I apply for exemption under this treaty for income earned as a teacher or researcher for more than five years.

1. I am a Thai resident on the date of my arrival in the United States. I am not a U.S. citizen. I have not lawfully acquired the privilege of permanent residence as an immigrant in the United States. 2. I am visiting the United States for teaching or research purposes at [insert name of educational or research institution where you are teaching or researching] for a period of not more than two years. I will receive remuneration for my teaching or research activities. 3. Remuneration received for such activities is eligible for exemption from federal tax withholding under the tax treaty between the United States and Thailand for the entire tax year (or for the period from ) to. I have not previously applied for income tax exemption under the treaty for income as a teacher, researcher or student prior to the date of my arrival in the United States. 4. Any research I have conducted is for the public interest and not primarily for the benefit of a particular individual. 5. I arrived in the United States on [insert date of your last arrival in the United States prior to the commencement of teaching or research services for which you are applying for exemption]. The exemption under the treaty applies only to remuneration received within two years from that date.

1. I am a resident of Trinidad and Tobago on the date of my arrival in the United States. I am not a U.S. citizen. I have not lawfully acquired the privilege of permanent immigration to the United States. 2. I have accepted an invitation from the U.S. Government or a U.S. university or other educational institution to travel to the United States for the purpose of teaching or research at [insert name of educational institution] which is an educational institution approved by the appropriate government educational authority. There is no agreement between the U.S. Government and the Government of Trinidad and Tobago for the provision of my services. I will be remunerated for my teaching or research services. 3. Teaching or research remuneration received for the entire tax year (or the period from ) to ) is eligible for exemption from federal tax under the tax treaty between the U.S. and Trinidad and Tobago. Prior to the date of my arrival in the United States, I have not previously applied for income tax exemption under the treaty for income earned as a teacher, researcher or student. 4. Any research I have conducted is for the public interest and not primarily for the private benefit of a particular individual. 5. I have arrived in the United States on [insert date of your last arrival in the United States prior to the commencement of teaching or research services for which you are applying for exemption]. The exemption under the treaty applies only to remuneration received within two years from that date.

1. I am a British resident on the date of my arrival in the United States. I am not a U.S. citizen. I have not acquired the privilege of permanent residence in the United States as an immigrant. 2. I am a professor or teacher visiting the United States for teaching or research purposes for a period not exceeding two years at [insert name of educational institution] which is an accredited educational institution. I will receive remuneration for my teaching or research activities. 3. Teaching or research remuneration received for the entire tax year (or period from) is eligible for exemption from federal tax withholding under the tax treaty between the United States and the United Kingdom. I have not previously applied for income tax exemption under the treaty for income earned as a teacher, researcher or student prior to the date of my arrival in the United States. 4. Any research I have carried out is for the public interest and not primarily for the benefit of any private person. 5. I arrived in the United States on [insert date of your last arrival in the United States prior to the commencement of teaching or research services for which you are applying for exemption]. The exemption under the treaty applies only to remuneration received within the two years beginning on that date. If I remain in the United States for more than two years, the entire exemption under the treaty will retroactively lapse.

1. I am a resident of the People's Republic of China on the date of my arrival in the United States. I am not a U.S. citizen. 2. I am visiting the United States primarily for the purpose of teaching, teaching or research at [insert name of the educational or scientific research institution where you are teaching, teaching or researching] which is an accredited educational or scientific research institution. I will receive remuneration for my teaching, teaching or research activities. 3. Remuneration for teaching, teaching or research received for the entire tax year (or the period from ) to ) is eligible for exemption from federal tax under the tax agreement between the United States and the People's Republic of China. I have not previously applied for income tax exemption under the agreement for income earned as a teacher, lecturer, researcher or student prior to the date of my arrival in the United States. 4. Any research I have conducted is for the public interest and not primarily for the private benefit of a particular individual. 5. I have arrived in the United States on [insert date of your last arrival in the United States prior to the commencement of my teaching, teaching or research activities]. The exemption from the agreement applies only to remuneration received for a maximum of two years in a row.

The agreement with the former Soviet Socialist Republics remains in force for the following countries: Armenia, Azerbaijan, Belarus, Georgia, Kyrgyzstan, Moldova, Tajikistan, Turkmenistan and Uzbekistan. 1. I am a resident of [insert country name]. I am not a U.S. citizen. 2. I have accepted an invitation from a U.S. government agency or agency, or from a U.S. educational or scientific institution, to attend a scientific, technical or professional conference in the United States for the principal purpose of teaching, conducting research or participating in science, where the institution is a government agency or agency, educational or scientific institution, or sponsoring organization of a professional conference. I will be remunerated for my teaching, research or conference activities. 3. Teaching, research or conference remuneration received for the entire tax year (or period from ) to ) is eligible for exemption from federal tax under the tax agreement between the United States and the former Soviet Socialist Republics. Prior to the date of arrival in the United States, I have not previously claimed income tax exemption under the agreement for income earned as a teacher, researcher, conference participant or student. 4. Any research I undertake will not be conducted primarily for the benefit of a private or commercial enterprise in the United States or a foreign trade organization in [insert country name], unless the research is conducted on the basis of an intergovernmental cooperation agreement. 5. I have arrived in the United States on [insert date of your last arrival in the United States prior to the commencement of your teaching or research service for which you are applying for exemption]. The exemption from the agreement applies only to remuneration received within two years of that date.

1. I am a resident of [insert name of the country you are applying for exemption under its agreement] on the date of my arrival in the United States. I am not a U.S. citizen. I have not lawfully acquired the privilege of permanent residence as an immigrant in the United States. 2. I am visiting the United States for [insert name of the educational or scientific institution] primarily for teaching or research purposes, which is an accredited educational or research institution. I will receive remuneration for my teaching or research activities. 3. Teaching or research remuneration received for the entire tax year (or the period from ) to ) is eligible for exemption from federal tax under the tax treaty between the United States and [insert name of the country you are applying for exemption under its agreement]. Prior to the date of my arrival in the United States, I have not previously applied for income tax exemption under that treaty for income earned as a teacher, researcher or student. 4. Any research I have carried out is for the public interest and not primarily for the private benefit of a particular individual. 5. I have arrived in the United States on [insert date of your last arrival in the United States prior to the commencement of teaching, research, or conference service for which you are applying for exemption]. The exemption under the treaty applies only to remuneration received within two years from that date.

1. I am a resident of [insert name of the country you are applying for exemption under its agreement] on the date of my arrival in the United States. I am not a U.S. citizen. I have not lawfully acquired the privilege of permanent residence as an immigrant in the United States. 2. I have accepted an invitation from the U.S. Government (or its political division or local authority) or a U.S. university or other accredited educational institution to travel for the purpose of teaching or research for a period of not more than two years to [insert name of the educational institution] which is an accredited educational institution. I will be remunerated for my teaching or research activities. 3. Teaching or research remuneration received for the entire tax year (or the period from  to ) is eligible for exemption from federal tax under the tax agreement between the United States and [insert name of the country you are applying for exemption under its agreement]. Prior to the date of my arrival in the United States, I have not previously applied for income tax exemption under that agreement for income earned as a teacher, researcher or student. 4. Any research I have carried out is for the public interest and not primarily for the private benefit of a particular individual. 5. I have arrived in the United States on [insert date of your last arrival in the United States prior to the commencement of teaching or research services for which you are applying for exemption]. The exemption under the agreement applies only to remuneration received within two years from that date.

I am not a U.S. citizen. I have not lawfully acquired the privilege of permanent immigration to the United States. I have accepted an invitation from the U.S. Government or a U.S. university or other accredited educational or research institution for the primary purpose of teaching or research at [insert name of educational or research institution]. I will receive remuneration for my teaching or research activities. Teaching or research remuneration received for the entire tax year (or for the period from  to ) is eligible for exemption from federal tax under the tax agreement between the U.S. and France. I have not previously applied for income tax exemption under the agreement for income earned as a teacher, researcher or student prior to the date of my arrival in the United States. Any research I have carried out is for the public interest and not primarily for the private benefit of a particular individual. I have arrived in the United States on [insert date of your last arrival in the United States prior to the commencement of teaching or research services for which I am applying for exemption]. The exemption under the agreement applies only to remuneration received within two years of that date.

I am a resident of Germany. I am not a U.S. citizen. I have not lawfully acquired the privilege of permanent residence as an immigrant in the United States. 2. I am a professor or teacher visiting the United States for the purpose of further education, teaching or research at [insert name of accredited university, college, school or other educational institution, or public research institution or other institution engaged in public-interest research]. I will receive remuneration for my teaching, research or learning activities. 3. Remuneration received for such activities is eligible for exemption from federal taxation under the tax agreement between the United States and Germany for the entire tax year (or for the period from ) to. I have not previously applied for income tax exemption under the agreement for income earned during the immediately preceding period as a student, apprentice or trainee. (However, if after the period of claiming benefits as a student, apprentice or trainee, the foreigner returns to Germany and resumes actual residence and then returns to the United States as a teacher or researcher, the person may claim benefits under this agreement.) 4. Any research I have carried out is for the public interest and not primarily for the private benefit of a particular individual. 5. I arrived in the United States on [insert date of last arrival in the United States prior to the commencement of service for which I am applying for exemption]. The exemption under the agreement applies only to remuneration paid to me within two years from that date.

1. I am a Greek resident. I am not a U.S. citizen. I have not legally acquired the privilege of permanent residence in the United States as an immigrant (otherwise I would not be considered a resident as defined by the tax laws for the relevant tax year). 2. I am a professor or teacher visiting the United States for teaching purposes at [insert name of other educational institution where you teach] which is an educational institution. I will receive remuneration for my teaching activities. 3. Teaching remuneration received for the entire tax year (or the period from ) to ) is eligible for exemption from federal tax withholding under the tax treaty between the United States and Greece. I have not previously applied for income tax exemption under the treaty for income earned as a teacher or student prior to the date of arrival in the United States. 4. I arrived in the United States on [insert date of your last arrival in the United States prior to the commencement of teaching services for which exemption is requested]. The exemption under the treaty applies only to remuneration paid within 3 years from that date.
If you are a foreigner (non-U.S. citizen), you are considered a non-tax resident unless you pass one of two tests: The contents are listed below: Tax resident.

If you pass the Green Card test or the actual residence test in 2023 (1 January to 31 December), you are a tax-defined resident. Even if you fail either test, you can choose to be considered a resident for part of the year.

If you regularly commute from Canada or Mexico, the date you work in the United States from your residence in Canada or Mexico is not counted. If you work in the United States for more than 75% (0.75) of your working days, you are considered to be regularly commuting. For this purpose, "commute" means a 24-hour period of time between work and home. "working day" means the date you work in the United States or Canada or Mexico. "working hours" means the period of time from the first day of your actual work in the United States in the year to the last day of your actual work in the United States in the year. If your work requires you to work in the United States on a seasonal or periodic basis only, your period of work begins on the first day of the season or cycle in which you work in the United States to the last day of the season or cycle in which you work in the United States. You may have multiple periods of work in a calendar year, and your period of work may begin in a calendar year and end in the following calendar year.

Do not count the days you intend to leave the United States but are unable to leave due to a medical condition or problem that occurred during your stay in the United States. Whether you intend to leave the United States on a particular date depends on all the facts and circumstances. For example, if the purpose of your visit to the United States can be accomplished within a period of time that is not sufficient to entitle you to an actual residency test, you can be sure that you intend to leave. However, if you need more time to accomplish the purpose of your visit and that period of time entitles you to an actual residency test, you will not be able to determine your intention to leave the United States before the end of the extended period. If a person is deemed mentally incapable, evidence of the person's intention to leave the United States can be determined by analysing the person's behavior prior to the person's detection as mentally incapable. If you qualify for a health exclusion, you must report a completed Form 8843. See the contents of Form 8843 below. You cannot exclude any days of stay in the United States in the following cases: You were initially prohibited from leaving and can then leave but remain in the United States after a reasonable period of time to arrange for departure. A medical condition occurred during your stay prior to your return to the United States for treatment. The condition existed before you arrived in the United States and you were aware of it. It is not important whether you need treatment for the condition when you enter the United States.

a person (or an immediate relative of a person) who is temporarily in the United States: as a full-time employee of an international organization, by virtue of diplomatic status, or on a visa determined by the Secretary of the Treasury to represent full-time diplomatic or consular status (except for visas granting legal permanent residence); and b a person who is a permanent resident of the United States.

If you are a private employee, servant or domestic servant residing in the United States as an official of a foreign government or international organization on an "A-3" or "G-5" visa, you are not considered a foreign government associate and must count all your days in the United States on the physical presence test.

Your tax residence is the entire area of your principal place of business, place of work or work position, regardless of where your family residence is located. Your tax residence is the place where you work as an employee or self-employed person permanently or indefinitely. If, due to the nature of your work, you have no fixed or principal place of business, then your tax residence is the place where you usually live. If you do not fall into either of these categories, you will be considered a mobile person and your tax residence is where you work. In order to determine whether you have a closer connection with a foreign country, your tax residence must also exist throughout the year and must be in the same foreign country with which you claim to have a closer connection.

The steps to change your status to permanent resident include, but are not limited to, filing the following forms: Form I-508 – Application for Waiver of Certain Rights, Privileges, Immunities and Exemptions. Form I-485 – Application for Registration of Permanent Residence or Adjustment of Status. Form I-130 – Application for Foreign Relative. Form I-140 – Application for Foreign Labour Immigration. Form ETA-9089 – Application for Permanent Employment Certificate. Form ETA-9089, Appendix A. Form DS-230 – Application for Immigration Visa and Alien Registration.

If you meet the Green Card Test requirements at any time in a calendar year, but do not meet the Actual Residence Test requirements for that year, your start date of residence is the first day you are a lawful permanent resident in the United States in that year. If you meet both the Actual Residence Test and the Green Card Test requirements, your start date of residence is the first day you are a lawful permanent resident in the United States under the Actual Residence Test or the first day you are a lawful permanent resident in the United States under the Law of Laws in that year, whichever is earlier.

When calculating the number of days of residence in (1) and (2) above, do not count the number of days in the United States under any exception discussed in the previous paragraph on the number of days of residence in the United States. If you make the first year choice, your 2023 start date of residence is the first day of the initial 31-day period you used to qualify for the option (as described in (1) above). For the remainder of this year, you will be considered a U.S. resident. If you reside for more than 31 days and you meet the above conditions (2) in each period, your start date of residence is the first day of the first 31-day period. If you reside for more than 31 days but you meet the above conditions (2) only in the subsequent 31-day period, your start date of residence is the first day of the next 31-day period.

You cannot file Form 1040 or Form 1040-SR or a declaration until you pass the 2024 actual residence test. If you do not pass the 2024 test by April 15, 2024, you can request an extension of time to file Form 1040 or Form 1040-SR for 2023 for a reasonable period after you pass the test. To request an extension of time to file your return until October 15, 2024, use Form 4868. You can file the paper form or the electronic form as described in the Form 4868 instructions. You should use this extension to pay the tax you expect to owe in 2023 as if you were a non-tax resident throughout the year. You can use Form 1040-NR to calculate your tax. Enter the tax on Form 4868. If you do not pay the tax due, you will be charged interest on any tax not paid before your regular tax filing deadline, and you may be subject to late payment penalties. Once you make your first year selection, it cannot be revoked without the approval of the IRS. If you do not make your first year selection according to the procedure discussed here, you will be considered a non-tax resident throughout 2023. However, this does not apply if you can provide clear and convincing evidence that you have taken reasonable action to understand the filing process and the important steps to comply with the process.

You usually make this choice when you file your merger return. However, you can also make the choice by filing Form 1040-X or the Revised U.S. Personal Income Tax Return. Attach Form 1040 or Form 1040-SR and enter "Revised Version" at the top of the amended return. If you choose to amend your return, you and your spouse must also amend any returns you may file after the year you make the choice. You must usually file the amended merger return within 3 years of the date you filed your original U.S. income tax return, or within 2 years of the date you paid your income tax in that year, whichever is later.

If you are married and at the end of your tax year one of you is a U.S. citizen or tax resident and the other is a non-tax resident, you may elect to treat your non-resident spouse as a U.S. resident. This includes the situation where one of you is a non-tax resident at the beginning of the tax year but is a tax resident at the end of the year and the other is a non-tax resident at the end of the year. If you make this choice, you and your spouse are treated as residents for your entire tax year. Neither you nor your spouse are required to be U.S. residents under any rental tax treaty. You will both be subject to foreign income tax. You must file a combined income tax return for the year in which you make your choice, but you and your spouse may file a combined or separate tax return in subsequent years. If you file a combined return under this provision, the special remarks and restrictions for dual status taxpayers in Chapter 6 do not apply to you.

Include a statement signed by both spouses on the consolidated return for the first tax year of your choice. It should include the following information: Declare that on the last day of your tax year, one of you is a non-tax resident and the other is a U.S. citizen or tax resident, and that you elect to be treated as a U.S. resident for the entire tax year. Name, address and TIN of each spouse. (If one spouse is deceased, include the name and address of the person who made the choice for the deceased spouse.)

You usually make this choice when you file your merger return. However, you can also make your choice by filing an amended merger return on Form 1040-X. Attach Form 1040 or Form 1040-SR and enter "Amended" at the top of the amended return. If you choose to amend your return, you and your spouse must also amend any returns you may file after the year you make the choice. You must usually file the amended merger return within three years of the date you filed your original U.S. income tax return, or within two years of the date you paid your income tax in that year, whichever is later.

If both spouses are not U.S. citizens or tax-defined residents at any time in the tax year, the option to be treated as tax-defined residents is suspended for any tax year (after the tax year in which you make the choice). This means that if either spouse meets the non-tax-defined residents' reporting requirements discussed in Chapter 7, each spouse must report as a non-tax-defined resident separately for that year.

Once made, the choice to be considered resident applies to all subsequent years unless it is suspended (as described in the suspension option above) or terminated in one of the following ways. If the choice terminates in one of the following ways, neither spouse can make the choice in any subsequent tax year. 1. Revocation. Either spouse may revoke the choice for any tax year, provided it is done before the tax return filing deadline for that tax year. The spouse who revokes the choice must attach a signed statement stating that the choice is being revoked. The statement must include the names, addresses and TINs of both spouses. (If one spouse dies, please include the names and addresses of the person who revoked the choice for the deceased spouse.) The statement must also include a list of any state, foreign and property with common property law where one spouse resides or from which one spouse gains income. File the declaration as follows. 1. If the spouse who revokes the choice must file a return, please attach the statement to the first year's return to which the revocation applies. 2. If the spouse who revokes the choice does not have to file a return, but does file a return (for example, in order to receive a refund), please attach the statement to the return. 3. If the spouse who revokes the choice does not have to file a return and does not request a refund, please send the statement to the IRS service center where you filed your last combined return. 2. Death. The death of either spouse will terminate the choice, starting from the first tax year following the spouse's death. However, if the surviving spouse is a U.S. citizen or resident and is entitled to the combined tax rate as a surviving spouse, the choice will end at the end of the last year in which these combined tax rates are available.

Income of a tax resident is usually taxed in the same way as that of a U.S. citizen. If you are a tax resident, you must report all interest, dividends, wages or other service compensation, rental property or royalty income, and other types of income on your U.S. tax return. You must report these amounts from sources in the U.S. and abroad.

Non-tax residents are taxed only on their income from the United States and on certain income related to the conduct of trade or business in the United States (see Chapter 4). The general rules for determining U.S.-sourced income that apply to most non-tax residents are discussed in Table 2-1. The following discussion covers the general rules and exceptions to these rules. Not all income items from the United States are taxed. See Chapter 4, Chapter 3.

Real estate is land and buildings, and generally anything built on, grown on, or attached to land. Total income from the United States includes income, profits, and income from the sale or other disposition of real estate located in the United States.

Income from sales of products of any farm, mine, oil or gas well, other natural mineral deposit, or timber located in the United States and sold in a foreign country or located in a foreign country and sold in the United States is partly income from the United States. For information on determining that part, see section 1.863-1(b) of the U.S. Code.

Your tax residence is the entire area of your principal place of business, place of work or work position, regardless of where your family residence is located. Your tax residence is where you work as an employee or self-employed person permanently or indefinitely. If, due to the nature of your work, you have no fixed or principal place of business, then your tax residence is where you usually live. If you do not fall into either of these categories, you will be considered a mobile population and your place of work will be your tax residence.

Inventory property is personal property that is stored in trade or used primarily for sale to customers in the normal course of your trade or business. The income from the sale of inventory you purchase comes from the place where you sell the property. In general, this is where ownership of the property is transferred to the buyer. For example, income from the sale of inventory in the United States is income of U.S. origin, whether you purchased it in the United States or abroad. The income from the sale of inventory property that you produce in the United States and sell outside the United States (or vice versa) comes from the place where the property was produced. Even if you are not tax resident in the United States, these rules apply.

To determine the source of any proceeds from the sale of depreciable personal property, you must first calculate the amount of proceeds not exceeding the total depreciation adjustment of the property. You allocate that portion of the proceeds to the U.S. source in the ratio of the U.S. depreciation adjustment to the total depreciation adjustment. The remainder of the proceeds is considered to be from a source outside the U.S. For this purpose, the "U.S. depreciation adjustment item" is the depreciation adjustment on the property base allowed for the purpose of calculating taxable income of U.S. origin. However, if the property is used primarily in the U.S. in a tax year, all depreciation deductions allowed for that year are treated as U.S. depreciation adjustments. However, there are some exceptions for certain internationally used transportation, communications and other property. As noted above, the income from the sale of a depreciable asset that exceeds the total depreciation adjustment of the asset is the source of the asset being an inventory asset. The source of the loss is the same as the source of the depreciation deduction. However, if the property is used primarily in the U.S., the total loss reduces the income from the U.S. The property base is usually the cost of the property you acquired (money plus the fair market value of other property or services).

Intangible property includes patents, copyrights, secret processes or formulas, goodwill, trademarks, trade names, or other similar property. The proceeds of the sale of a displayable or depreciable intangible asset, until the previously permitted display or depreciation deduction, are of the same source as the original deduction. This is the same as the source rule for the sale of depreciable assets. See below for details on how this rule applies. If the revenue from sales depends on the productivity, use, or disposal of the property, the profits in excess of the display or depreciation deduction are from the country of use of the property. If the revenue does not depend on the productivity, use, or disposal of the property, the income is based on your tax residence (as discussed above). If the payment for goodwill does not depend on its productivity, use, or disposal, it is from the country where the goodwill originated.

Notwithstanding any earlier rule, if you are not tax resident in the United States but have an office or other fixed place of business in the United States, treat the income from the sale of any personal property (including inventory) as income from a U.S. source attributable to that office or place of business. However, this rule does not apply to the sale of inventory used, disposed of or consumed outside the United States if you are physically involved in the sale from an office or other fixed place of business outside the United States. If you are tax resident in the United States but have an office or other fixed place of business outside the United States, the income from the sale of personal property (except inventory, depreciable property or intangible assets) attributable to that foreign office or place of business may be treated as income from the United States. If the income paid to a foreign country is less than 10% of the sales income, the income will be treated as U.S. source. If the foreign country will levy less than 10% of the income tax on the sale, the rule also applies to losses.

The place or manner of payment is not relevant in determining the source of income. In a securities lending transaction or a sale-and-buy transaction, the substitute interest paid to the transferor of the securities is from the same source as the interest on the transferred securities.

Interest of U.S. origin does not include the following items. 1. Interest paid by a resident or domestic corporation as defined by the Tax Code on a debt issued before August 10, 2010, which is at least 80% (0.80) of the taxpayer's total income for the three years ended at the end of the payer's tax year prior to the payment of the interest: 1. From a source outside the U.S. and 2. Attributable to an individual or corporation active in a foreign country or in the U.S. territory. However, the interest will be treated as interest of U.S. origin if any of the following applies: 1. The recipient of the interest is related to a resident or domestic corporation as defined by the Tax Code. See the definition of a related person in section 954(d)(3) ". " 2. The duration of the obligation has been materially modified after August 9, 2010. Any extension of the duration of the obligation is considered materially modified. 2. Interest paid by an overseas branch or domestic partnership of a domestic corporation on deposits or withdrawals from savings banks, cooperative banks, credit unions, domestic building and loan associations and other savings institutions licensed and supervised as savings and loan institutions or similar associations (if the associations may deduct interest paid or withheld under federal or state law). 3. Interest on deposits in a foreign branch of a domestic corporation or domestic partnership, provided that the branch carries on commercial banking activities.

In most cases, dividend income from domestic companies is income from the United States. Foreign companies' dividend income is usually income from foreign sources. Exceptions to the second rule are discussed later. In securities lending or sale-repurchase transactions, the source of the substitute dividend paid to the transferor of the securities is the same as the source of the transferred securities.

If the taxpayer is the bid-side under the contract, the amount of the dividend equivalent amount includes any total amount of dividends of U.S. origin referred to and is used to calculate any net amount transferred to or from the taxpayer under the contract. Thus, even if the taxpayer makes a net payment or does not pay any amount because the net amount is zero, the taxpayer may be deemed to have received a payment of dividend equivalent. For the purposes of 2023, if the contract is a one-hedge transaction, the nominal principal contract or the equity linked instrument will generally be the designated nominal principal contract or the designated equity linked instrument, respectively. In general, the hedge value is the ratio of the slightest change in the fair market value of the nominal principal contract or the equity linked instrument to the fair market value of the number of shares cited in the contract. In general, the equivalent dividend amount of a particular nominal principal contract or equity linked instrument is the dividend amount per share multiplied by the number of shares cited in the contract multiplied by the hedging value of the contract. Special rules apply to complex contracts. For more information, see section 1.871-15 and Notice 2020-03.

All wages and any other compensation for services rendered in the United States are deemed to be from the United States. The only exceptions to this rule are those for foreigners, employees of organizations or offices discussed below, and the above-mentioned crew members. If you are an employee and receive compensation for labor or personal services rendered in or outside the United States, special rules apply to determining the source of compensation. Wages (except for certain additional benefits) are provided on a time basis. Certain additional benefits (such as housing and education) are calculated on a geographical basis. Or, you may be allowed to use an alternative basis to determine the source of compensation. See Alternative bases below.

In general, depending on the circumstances, the payments made by such multi-tier marketing companies to independent (non-employed) vendors (upstream vendors) are calculated on the basis of sales or purchases made by the persons they sponsor (downstream vendors), which constitute the income of the persons providing personal services for the recruitment, training and assistance of the downstream vendors.

If you are self-employed, you determine the source of remuneration for self-employment or personal services on the basis of the facts and circumstances of your particular situation, on the basis of which the appropriate source of the income is most accurately reflected. In many cases, the facts and circumstances need to be allocated over time, as described below.

The source of multiannual pay is generally determined on the time basis to which the pay is attributable. Multiannual pay is pay included in your income in one tax year but attributable to a period that includes two or more tax years. You determine the period of pay based on the facts and circumstances of the case. For example, pay specifically related to a period that includes more than one calendar year can be attributed to a full number of years. Pay from the United States is calculated by multiplying the total multiannual pay by a number. The number is the number of days (or units of time less than one day, if applicable) that you have provided labor or personal services for the project in the United States. The denominator of the number is the total number of days (or units of time less than one day, if applicable) that you have performed labor or personal services related to the project.

In addition to tax compensation and hazardous or hard work allowances, these additional benefits are based on your main place of work. Your main place of work is usually where you spend most of your working time. This can be your office, factory, store, market, or other location. If you do not spend most of your working time in one place, your main place of work is the central location of your work, such as where you report or the "base" of the work content. If you have multiple jobs at any given time, your main place of work depends on the fact of each case. More important factors to consider are: the total time you spend in each place, the amount of work you do in each place, and how much money you earn in each place.

The source of the educational supplementary benefit for the educational expenses of your dependent depends on your main place of employment. Educational supplementary benefit includes payments only for the following costs of primary or secondary education: tuition fees, miscellaneous fees, academic counseling, special needs services for students with special needs, books, supplies and other facilities, and school-related accommodation and uniforms required or provided in connection with enrolment or attendance.

The source of your local transportation supplementary benefit depends on your principal place of employment. Your local transportation supplementary benefit is the local transportation compensation you provide for yourself or your spouse or dependent at your principal place of employment. The amount considered as a local transportation supplementary benefit is limited to the actual cost of local transportation and the fair rental value of any vehicle provided by any employer that you, your spouse or your dependent use primarily for local transportation. The actual cost does not include the cost (including interest) of any vehicle purchased by you or on your behalf.

The source of relocation compensation is usually the location of your new principal place of employment. However, if you provide sufficient evidence that the facts and circumstances of your case indicate that the source is more appropriate, the source will be the location of your previous principal place of employment. Sufficient evidence usually requires an agreement between you and your employer, or a written statement of company policy, simplified into written form prior to the relocation, and made or established to encourage you or other employees to move to another country. The written statement or agreement must state that your employer will reimburse you for the relocation costs incurred by you returning to your former principal place of employment, whether or not you continue to work for your employer after returning to that location. It may contain specific conditions for determining the entitlement to compensation, provided that the criteria set forth in those conditions are clearly determined and can only be met before or after your return to your former principal place of employment.

If you are an employee, you may use the alternative basis if you can satisfy the IRS that the alternative basis is more appropriate for determining your source of compensation than the time or geographic basis based on the facts and circumstances of your case. If you use the alternative basis, you must keep (and have available for review) records to document why the alternative basis is more appropriate for determining your source of compensation. In addition, if your total remuneration from all sources is $250,000 or more, check "Yes" on both questions on line K of Annex OI (Form 1040-NR) and attach a written statement on your tax return that describes all of the following: 1. Your name and Social Security Number (SSN) (entered at the top of the statement). 2. The specific compensatory income or specific additional benefits you use for the alternative basis. 3. For each item of (2), the alternative basis used for allocating the source. 4. For each item of (2), the method of calculation that shows how the alternative allocation is calculated. 5. The comparison of the amounts of U.S. and foreign remuneration under the alternative basis and the time or geographic basis as discussed above.

Transportation income is income from the use of a ship or aircraft or from the provision of services directly related to the use of any ship or aircraft. This applies whether the ship or aircraft is owned, employed or leased. For the purposes of the term "ship or aircraft", any container associated with a ship or aircraft is defined. All transportation income that begins and ends in the United States is considered to be of United States origin. If the traffic begins or ends in the United States, 50% of transportation income is considered to be of United States origin. For transportation income from personal services, 50% of income is of United States origin if transportation is between the United States and U.S. territory. For non-tax residents, this applies only to income from aircraft or related to aircraft. For information on how transportation income of United States origin is taxed, see Chapter 4.

In general, the source of scholarships, grants, prizes and awards is the place of residence of the payer, regardless of who actually pays the funds. However, see below for activities carried out outside the United States. For example, research or experimentation expenses paid in the United States by a U.S. resident, non-corporate U.S. resident, or domestic company are of U.S. origin. Similar payments from foreign governments or foreign companies are of foreign origin, even if these funds may be paid through U.S. agents. Payments made by an entity designated as a public international organization under the International Organizations Immunity Act are of foreign origin.

Scholarships, grants, targeted grants, and achievement awards received by non-tax residents for activities that are or will be undertaken outside the United States are not income from U.S. sources. These rules do not apply to amounts received as wages or other compensation for services. See Personal Services below for the applicable source rules.

If you receive a pension from a domestic trust for services provided in or outside the United States, part of the pension is of U.S. origin. This part is the amount attributable to the pension plan and the amount that your employer has deposited for services provided in the United States. This applies whether the allocation is based on a qualifying or unqualifying stock dividend, pension, profit-sharing or annuity plan (whether funded or not). If you provide services as a U.S. employee, you may receive a distribution from the U.S. government from a plan (such as the Civil Service Pension Plan) that is considered a qualifying pension plan. Your U.S. source income is the other taxable amount of the allocation that is attributable to your total U.S. government basic salary, except for tax-exempt salary for services provided outside the U.S.

If you need to file a federal income tax return, you may be eligible for some special disaster-related provisions regarding the use of your retirement fund. For more information, see Publication 590-B. Also, visit IRS.gov/DisasterTaxRelief.

Special rules provide for tax relief on the issuance and reimbursement of certain retirement plans, including IRAs, for taxpayers who suffer financial losses as a result of certain major disasters. For information on reporting eligible disaster issuances and reimbursements, see Form 8915-F, Issuance and Reimbursement of Qualified Disaster Plans, and its explanation.

Your U.S. source income includes rents and royalties earned in the tax year from property located in the United States or from any interest in such property. Income from the United States also includes rents or royalties for the use or enjoyment of intangible assets (such as patents, copyrights, secret crafts and recipes, goodwill, trademarks, patent rights and similar property) in the United States.
In these cases, you and your spouse must report joint income as described below.
The spouse's income, except for trade or business income and the partner's allocated share in the partnership's income, is considered to be the spouse's income from his or her services.
Trade or business income is considered to be the income of the spouse engaged in trade or business, except for the share of the partner in the partnership income.
The shareholder's allocated share of the partnership's income (or loss) is treated as the shareholder's income (or loss).

Income from a spouse's separate property (not income from employment, trade or business, or shareholding income) is considered to be that spouse's income. The spouse must declare all of these on his or her separate tax return.
All other common income is treated in accordance with the applicable community property law.

Residents and non-tax residents can be deducted from total income if they meet certain conditions. What is usually excluded from total income is income you receive that is not included in your U.S. income and is not subject to U.S. tax.
The tax code defines residents as being able to exclude the following items from their total income:

If you actually stay in one or more countries for at least 330 days in any period of 12 consecutive months, you may qualify for the foreign employment income exclusion. The exclusion for 2023 is $120,000. In addition, you may exclude or deduct certain amounts for foreign housing. You may also qualify if you are a genuine resident of a foreign country and a citizen or national of a country that has an income tax treaty with the United States. For more information, see Bulletin 54.
Non-taxable residents may exclude the following items from their total income:

Interest income not related to U.S. trade or business is excluded from income if it comes from the following sources: Deposits (including deposit certificates) of bank employees; Mutual savings banks, cooperative banks, credit unions, domestic building and loan associations, and other licensed and supervised savings and loan institutions, or similar associations as prescribed by federal or state law (if interest paid or credited is deductible by the association); and amounts held by insurance companies under agreement for the payment of interest.

Interest on obligations of states or political subdivisions, the District of Columbia, or U.S. territories is usually not included in income. However, interest on certain private activity bonds, arbitrage bonds, and certain unregistered bonds are included in income.

Interest and original issue discounts (OIDs) that qualify as portfolio interest are exempt from withholding tax under Chapter 3 (Tax Code) under Sections 1441 to 1443. However, if such interest is a withholding payment, withholding may be required, including withholding under Chapter 4 (Tax Code) of Sections 1471 to 1474. For more information, see the discussion of portfolio interests in Specific Income Withholding in Bulletin 515. To qualify for portfolio interest, interest must be paid on debt issued after July 18, 1984, otherwise withholding is required. For bonds issued after March 18, 2012, portfolio interest does not include interest paid on debt in non-registration form. Prior to March 19, 2012, portfolio interest includes interest on certain registered and non-registered (nominative) bonds if the debt meets the following requirements.

If a debt can be converted to a non-registration form at any time in the future, a debt that would otherwise be considered to be in a registration form is not considered to be in a registration form at that time. For more information on whether a debt is considered to be in a registration form, see the discussion of Specific Income Retention on Portfolio Interest in IRA No. 515.

Interest on non-nominated liabilities can be considered as portfolio interest without documentation. However, in some cases, you may need to record it for the purposes of reporting on Form 1099 and providing proof of withholding tax.

Payments to a specific person and interest on such payments are not considered as portfolio interest. Unless other exceptions apply, such as treaty provisions, you must withhold such payments at the statutory rate.

Interest in a portfolio does not include or bear interest. Or interest bears interest in one of the following cases. 1. Interest determined by reference to: any income, sales or other cash flows of the debtor or a related person; 2. income or profits of the debtor or a related person; 3. any change in the value of any property of the debtor or a related person; or 4. any dividends, partnership distributions or similar payments made by the debtor or a related person. For exceptions, see section 871(h)(4)(C). 2. any other type of interest specified by the Minister of Finance in regulations.

The following are considered to be related persons: Members of a family, including only brothers, sisters, half-brothers, half-sisters, spouses, ancestors (parents, grandparents, etc.) and immediate descendants (children, grandchildren, etc.); Any person who is a party to any arrangement made to avoid or apply the interest rule; Specific corporations, partnerships and other entities. For more information, see Chapter 2, Non-deductible losses.

Contingent interest does not include interest paid or accrued on any fixed-term debt issued: on or before April 7, 1993; or after April 7, 1993, under a written binding contract in force on that date and for all time thereafter prior to the issuance of the debt.
The following dividends are exempt from 30% tax.

Interest-related dividends you receive from a mutual fund or other regulated investment corporation (RIC) in the United States are exempt from the 30% tax. The mutual fund will specify in writing which dividends are interest-related dividends.

You may not be required to pay any 30% tax on certain short-term capital gains dividends you receive from a mutual fund or other RIC from the United States. The mutual fund will specify in writing which dividends are short-term capital gains dividends. This tax exemption does not apply to you if you stay in the United States for 183 days or more in the tax year.
If your salary is paid by a foreign employer, your U.S. source income may be exempt from U.S. tax, provided you meet one of the conditions discussed below.

If you do not meet all three conditions, your income from personal services provided in the United States is income of U.S. origin and is taxed under Chapter 4. If you receive payment for these services in excess of $3,000, the entire amount is income from trade or business in the United States. To determine whether your salary exceeds $3,000, please exclude any amounts you receive from your employer for advance payment or cancellation of business travel expenses (if you are required to do so and have disclosed these expenses to your employer). If the advance payment or cancellation exceeds your expenses, include the excess in the amount you receive for those services. A "day" means a calendar day during any period of time in the United States.

For non-tax residents defined by the Act, the salary property of a person temporarily present in the United States as an official crew member of a foreign vessel (for example, a ship or ferry) engaged in transportation between the United States and a foreign country is not income of U.S. origin and is exempt from U.S. tax.

Non-resident foreign students and exchange visitors who come to the United States on an "F," "J," "M," or "Q" visa may deduct total income from a foreign employer. This group includes genuine students, scholars, interns, teachers, professors, research assistants, experts or leaders in a field of professional knowledge or skill, or persons described in a similar manner. It also includes the spouse and minor children of a foreigner if they accompany or subsequently live with the foreigner. Non-tax residents who are temporarily resident in the United States on a "J" visa include foreigners who enter the United States as exchange visitors under the Education and Cultural Exchange Act of 1961.
If you are unsure whether the annuity comes from a qualifying pension plan or a qualifying trust, ask the payer.

Any type of income that is exempt from U.S. taxation under treaties to which the United States is a party is not included in your total income. However, only income that is subject to treaty taxation is included in your total income. See Chapter 9.
You can exclude from your total income legal bet bonuses on prize pool bets on American horse or dog racing that are made outside the United States.

If you have sold your primary residence, you can deduct up to $250,000 from the proceeds of the sale of the house. If you are married and file jointly, you can exclude up to $500,000. For information on the requirement for this exclusion, see Bulletin 523. This exclusion does not apply if you comply with the abandonment tax rules discussed in Chapter 4.

If you are a degree candidate, you may deduct from your income part or all of the amount received as a qualifying scholarship. The rules discussed here apply to residents and non-tax residents. If the grant received by a non-tax resident is not from the United States, no U.S. tax is payable. Refer to the scholarships, grants, awards and rewards discussed in Chapter 2 to determine whether your gift is from the United States.... a scholarship or fellowship can only be deducted from your income if: 1. you are a degree candidate at a qualifying educational institution, and 2. you use the scholarship or fellowship to pay for your qualifying educational expenses.

You are a candidate for a degree if you meet the following conditions: 1. You are attending primary or secondary school, or are pursuing a degree at a college or university, or 2. You are attending an accredited educational institution that is entitled to offer: 1. a course that earns full credits for a bachelor's degree or higher, or 2. a training program designed to prepare students for gainful employment in a recognized profession.
A qualified educational institution is one that has regular teachers and curriculum, and usually has a regularly registered student body in the place where it conducts its educational activities.

However, in order for these to be eligible educational expenses, the terms of the scholarship or fellowship cannot require that it be used for other purposes, such as accommodation, or designate that it cannot be used for tuition or course-related expenses.

You cannot exclude from your income any scholarship, grant or fee deduction representing past, present or future expenses for teaching, research or other services. This is even true if all degree candidates are required to provide services as a condition of obtaining a degree.

Residents and non-tax residents are taxed differently. Tax residents are usually taxed in the same way as U.S. citizens. Non-tax residents are taxed on the basis of their source of income and whether their income is effectively related to a trade or business in the United States. The following discussion will help you determine whether your income in the tax year is effectively related to a U.S. trade or business and how it is taxed.

Tax-defined residents are generally taxed in the same way as U.S. citizens. This means that their global income is subject to U.S. taxation and must be reported on their U.S. tax returns. The income of tax-defined residents is subject to the progressive tax rate applicable to U.S. citizens. Tax-defined residents apply the tax form or tax calculation worksheet described in the Form 1040, which also applies to U.S. citizens.

The difference between the two categories is that effectively linked income is taxed at a progressive rate after allowance of allowable deductions. These rates apply to U.S. citizens and residents. Un-effectively linked income is taxed at the 30% (or lower agreed rate). If you were previously a U.S. citizen or resident as defined by tax law, these rules may not apply. See the explanation of the abandonment tax later in this chapter.

In general, you must have engaged in a trade or business in the tax year in order to have the income received in that year effectively related to that trade or business. Whether you engage in a trade or business in the United States depends on the nature of your activity. The following discussion will help you determine whether you engage in a trade or business in the United States.

If you provide personal services in the United States at any time during the tax year, you are generally considered to be engaged in trade or business in the United States. Specific salaries paid by a foreign employer to a non-tax resident are not included in total income. For more information, see Services provided to foreign employers in Chapter 3.

If you are a nonimmigrant holding an "F," "J," "M," or "Q" visa who is temporarily resident in the United States and does not otherwise engage in trade or business, you are considered to be engaged in trade or business in the United States if you earn taxable income from participating in a scholarship or grant described in section 1441(b). The taxable portion of any scholarship or grant that is income of U.S. origin is considered to be effectively connected to trade or business in the United States.
If you are a beneficiary of an inheritance or trust that engages in a trade or business in the United States, you will be considered to be engaged in the same trade or business.

If your sole business in the United States is to deal in stocks, securities or commodities (including hedging) through a U.S.-based broker or other agent, you do not engage in a transaction or business in the United States. For stocks or securities, this applies to any non-tax resident, including stock and securities dealers or brokers. For commodities, this applies to commodities that are normally traded on an organized commodity exchange and transactions that are normally conducted on such exchanges. This discussion does not apply if you have a U.S. office or other fixed place of business at any time in the tax year, or deal in stocks, securities or commodities based on that location.

If trading in stocks, securities or commodities for your own account is your sole business activity in the United States, you do not engage in trade or business in the United States. This applies even if the transaction occurs while you are in the United States or is performed by your employees, your brokers or other agents. If you are a trader in stocks, securities or commodities, this does not apply to your own account. However, this does not necessarily mean that as a trader you are considered to engage in trade or business in the United States. Determined on the facts and circumstances of each case or in accordance with the Rules for Trading in Stocks, Securities and Commodities as set forth above.

If you engage in U.S. trade or business, all income, gains or losses (except certain investment income) that you receive from the United States in that tax year are considered effectively connected income. This applies regardless of whether there is any connection between the income and the trade or business conducted in the U.S. in that tax year.
