The two tests described below in Investment Income determine whether a particular item of investment income (such as interest, dividends and royalties) is considered to be effectively connected to the business. In limited circumstances, certain types of income from foreign sources may be considered to be effectively connected to the trade or business in the U.S. For a discussion of these rules, see below in Foreign Income.

Use the two tests described below to determine whether income from U.S. sources received in the tax year and in one of the three categories above is effectively linked to your trade or business in the United States. If the test shows that the income item is effectively linked, you must include it with other effectively linked income. If the income item is not effectively linked, it will be calculated with all other effectively linked income discussed in the 30% tax rule later in this chapter.
In general, the shares of a company are not considered assets used or held for use in the United States trade or business.
In this test, if the conduct of US trade or business is a significant factor in generating income, that income is considered to be effectively linked.

When you provide personal services in the United States, you are usually engaged in a U.S. trade or business. Personal service income earned in the tax year in which you engage in a U.S. trade or business is effectively connected to the U.S. trade or business. If income earned in a year other than the year in which you provide the services would otherwise be effectively connected, then income earned in a year other than the year in which you provide the services is also effectively connected. Personal employment income includes wages, salaries, commissions, fees, daily allowances, and employee allowances and bonuses. Income may be paid to you in the form of cash, services, or property. If you engage in a U.S. trade or business solely as a result of providing personal services in the U.S. in the tax year, income and gains from property, and gains and losses from the sale or exchange of capital assets, are usually not effectively connected to your trade or business. However, if there is a direct economic relationship between your holding of property and the trade or business in which you engage in personal services, income, gains, or losses are effectively connected.

If you provided personal services in the United States after 1986 and received a retirement benefit or retirement distribution attributable to those services in a subsequent tax year when you were a non-tax resident, such distribution is effectively linked income to the extent that it is attributable to contributions. This is true whether or not you engaged in U.S. trade or business in the year in which you received the benefit or retirement distribution.

"Fixed place of business" generally means the place, location, structure or other similar facility where you engage in trade or business. "Regular transportation" means a ship or aircraft that travels or flies regularly between the same place as a journey or flight that begins or ends in the United States, following a published schedule. This definition applies to regular and charter air transportation. If both of these conditions are not met, there is no effective link to the income and it is taxed at a rate of 4%. See Transportation Tax later in this chapter.
For example, profits from the sale in the United States of inventory property purchased in the United States or abroad are in fact income related to trade or business income.

Gains and losses from the sale or dealing of U.S. real estate interests (whether or not they are capital assets) are taxed as if you were engaged in a trade or business in the United States. You must treat the gains or losses as effectively connected to that trade or business.

This is any interest in real property located in the United States or the U.S. Virgin Islands or any interest held by a U.S. real estate holding company (except as a creditor) in real property. Real property includes the following items. 1. Land and uncut natural products of land, such as crops and timber, and mines, wells and other natural sediments. 2. Projects built on land, including buildings, other permanent structures and structural parts thereof. 3. Personal property associated with the use of real property, such as equipment for agriculture, mining, forestry or construction or property used for accommodation or rental office space. The following personal property is excluded: 1. Personal property disposed of before or more than one year after the disposal of the real property, or 2. Separately sold to a person unrelated to the seller or buyer of the real property.
If you dispose of a U.S. real estate interest, the buyer may need to pay withholding tax. See Schedule 8, Box 1, Table 1, Real Estate Sales Withholding Tax.
Any domestic company's shares are considered to be shares of a US real estate holding company unless you are certain that the company is not a US real estate holding company.

U.S. real estate interests do not include shares of a class of companies that are regularly traded on mature securities markets, unless you hold more than 5% of the fair market value of such shares (or more than 10% of the shares in the case of a real estate investment trust (REIT)).

In most cases, any distribution made by a qualifying investment entity to a non-tax resident, foreign corporation or other qualifying investment entity is considered to be a non-tax resident, foreign corporation or other qualifying investment entity's recognized income from the sale or deal of a U.S. real estate interest if it is attributable to the gains of the qualifying investment entity from the sale or deal of the U.S. real estate interest. Exceptions to the viewing rules for distributions by qualifying investment entities. A distribution by a qualifying investment entity of a stock that is regularly traded on the U.S. mature securities market is not considered to be a sale or deal of a U.S. real estate interest if the shareholder holds 5% or less of the share (or 10% or less of the share in the case of a REIT) at any time during the one-year period as of the date of the distribution. A distribution by a real estate investment trust is generally not considered to be a sale or deal of a U.S. real estate interest if the shareholder is a qualifying shareholder (as described in section 897(k)(3)).
Shares in real estate investment trusts held directly (or indirectly through one or more associated companies) by qualifying shareholders are not considered U.S. real estate interests.

The following rules apply in determining whether a qualifying investment entity is domestically controlled. 1. A person holding less than 5 per cent of any class of shares in a qualifying investment entity shall be deemed to be a U.S. national unless the qualifying investment entity has actual knowledge that the person is not a U.S. national. 2. Any shares in a qualifying investment entity held by another qualifying investment entity shall be deemed to be held by a foreigner in the following circumstances: 1. Any class of shares in such other qualifying investment entity is traded on an established securities market on a regular basis; or 2. Such other qualifying investment entity is a regulated investment firm issuing specific redeemable securities. Notwithstanding this, if shares in such other qualifying investment entity are controlled in the U.S., shares in such other qualifying investment entity shall be deemed to be held by a U.S. person. 3. Shares in a qualifying investment entity held by any other qualifying investment entity not described above shall be deemed to be held by a U.S. person in proportion to the shares in such other qualifying investment entity held (or deemed to be held) by the U.S. person.

If this occurs, you will be deemed to have received proceeds from the sale or transaction of U.S. real estate interests, and the proceeds will be deemed to be equal to the amount that would otherwise have been considered as a distribution of such proceeds. This also applies to any alternative dividend payments. The transaction will not be deemed to be an applicable fake repurchase if: You actually obtained from a domestically controlled qualifying investment entity a distribution related to the rights disposed of or acquired in the transaction; or You disposed of any class of shares of a qualifying investment entity that is regularly traded in a mature U.S. securities market, provided that you did not hold more than 5% of the shares of that class at any time during the one-year period up to the date of the allocation.

Any income from a foreign source equivalent to any of the above income items is considered to be effectively connected to U.S. trade or business. For example, if a foreign person is actively engaged in banking, financing, or similar business in the United States to earn income, interest and dividend equivalents from a foreign source are considered to be effectively connected U.S. income.

If you receive income in a tax year that is effectively connected to your trade or business in the United States, it is taxed at the rate applicable to U.S. citizens and residents after deduction of any allowable deductions. In general, you will only receive effectively connected income if you are a non-tax resident who engages in trade or business in the United States in the tax year. However, if you receive money from the sale or dealing in property, the provision of services, or any other transaction in a tax year in which you do not engage in U.S. trade or business, but such money would be considered effectively connected income in the year in which the transaction occurred or you provided the services, it will be considered effectively connected income in the tax year in which you received it.
You can choose to treat all income from real estate as valid links. See Real Estate Income later in this chapter.
The 30% rate (or lower tax treaty) applies to certain items of income or profit from the United States, provided that these items are not effectively linked to your U.S. trade or business.

The 30% (or lower tax treaty rate) tax rate applies to the total amount of fixed, determineable, annual or periodic (FDAP) income, profits or income from the United States. Income is fixed when payments are received on a known amount in advance. Income is determined on this basis as long as there is a basis for calculating the amount to be paid. Income may be cyclical if paid on an unregulated basis. Payments do not have to be annual or periodic. Income may be determined on this basis or be cyclical even if the intervals between payments increase or decrease. Items explicitly listed as fixed or determined as such income are interest (except for the original issue discount (OID)) and dividends, dividend equivalents (defined in Chapter 2), rent, insurance premiums, annuities, salaries, wages and other salaries. Substitute dividend or interest payments received under securities borrowing or sale and buy back transactions are treated as the amounts received on transferred securities. Other income items such as royalties may also need to be subject to the 30% tax rule. Part of fixed or determined income may be exempt from U.S. tax. See Chapter 3 later in this chapter for details.

In general, the 30% tax rule applies to total gambling income earned in the United States by a non-tax resident if there is no effective link to U.S. trade or business and no treaty exemption. However, non-commercial gambling income earned by a non-tax resident in the United States from playing blackjack, baccarat, craps, roulette or six-card poker is not taxed. Net gambling income earned in the United States by a non-tax resident that is effectively linked to U.S. trade or business is taxed at a progressive rate.

Non-tax residents must include 85% of any U.S. social security benefits (and the equivalent of the Tier 1 rail pension benefits and social benefits) in their U.S. FDAP income. Social security benefits include monthly retirement, survivor, and disability benefits. This income is tax-exempt under specific tax treaties. For a list of tax treaties that exempt U.S. social security benefits from U.S. tax, see Table 1 in the Tax Treaty Tables later in this chapter, which is available at IRS.gov/TreatyTables. For more information, see Bulletin 915 of the U.S. Tax Administration.

If you choose to treat the income as having a valid link to a U.S. trade or business presence, the income under item (1) is not subject to the 30% (or lower treaty rate). See Real Estate Income later in this chapter.

If you do not conduct trade or business in the United States and have not established a tax year for the prior period, your tax year is the calendar year when the 183-day rule applies. In addition, you must file your tax returns for the calendar year. If you are in the United States for less than 183 days in the tax year, capital gains (other than earnings reported above) are tax-exempt unless they are effectively connected to the trade or business in the United States in your tax year.

Report gains and losses on capital assets you sell or deal with that have no effective connection to your trade or business in the United States on Annex NEC (Form 1040-NR). Report gains and losses on the sale or exchange of capital assets (including real estate) that have an effective connection to your U.S. trade or business on separate Annex D (Form 1040) or Form 4797, or on both. Attach them to Form 1040-NR.

If you earn income from real property located in the United States and you own or have a right to and hold that property to generate income, you may elect to treat all income from that property as having a valid connection to your trade or business in the United States. This option applies to all income from real property located in the United States and used to generate income, and any rights in such property. This includes income from rent, royalties from mines, oil or gas wells, or other natural resources. It also includes proceeds from the sale or transaction of timber, coal, or domestic iron ore where there is an economic interest. You may only make this option for real estate income that has no other valid connection to your U.S. trade or business. If you make the option, you may claim a deduction attributable to real estate income and tax only your net income from your real estate. This option does not treat residents who are not defined by non-tax law as engaging in U.S. trade or business as engaging in trade or business in the United States in the year.
Unless you cancel it, this option is valid for all subsequent tax years.

You can withdraw your choice without the approval of the IRS by filing Form 1040-X in the year you make the choice and in subsequent years. You must file Form 1040-X within three years of filing your tax return or within two years of paying your tax, whichever is later. If the period of time for the year you choose has passed, you cannot withdraw your choice for that year. However, you can only withdraw your choice for the latter tax year after receiving the IRS' approval. For information on how to obtain the IRS' approval, see Regulation 1.871-10(d)(2).

This 4% tax rate applies to your total transportation income in the United States.If the transportation begins or ends in the United States, this only includes transportation income that is deemed to originate in the United States.For transportation income from personal services, the transportation must take place between the United States and the U.S. territory.For personal services of non-tax residents, this applies only to income from or related to aircraft.

After taking into account any applicable treaty benefits, unless you apply a higher rate of tax under section 871 (the rule generally applied to income taxation of non-tax residents, as described above), you are required under this special rule to tax your gross income and gains in the United States net of the progressive rate of tax (including applicable deductions) that applied to you as a non-tax resident.

If you are required to pay this tax in any year of your period of residence defined as non-taxable, you must file a Form 1040-NR for that year. The tax return must be due before the deadline (including extensions) for filing a U.S. income tax return in the year in which you become a U.S. resident again. If you have filed a tax return for that period, you must file an amended tax return. You must include a statement on your tax return stating the source of all your total U.S. and foreign income and the income items bound by this special rule.

The waiver tax rules apply to U.S. citizens who have renounced their citizenship and to long-term residents (LTRs) who have terminated their residence. The following section describes the waiver rules under section 877A, which apply to individuals who renounced their citizenship on or after June 17, 2008. See Waiver after June 16, 2008 later in this chapter. If you moved abroad before June 17, 2008, see Waiver after June 3, 2004 and Waiver before June 17, 2008, in Chapter 4 of Bulletin 519, 2018, and the 2018 explanation of Form 8854. If you renounce your citizenship or terminate your long-term residence after June 3, 2004 and before June 17, 2008, you will still be considered a U.S. citizen or U.S. resident for tax purposes until you notify the Department of State or the Department of Homeland Security of your alienation (if applicable) and file a Form 8854 with the IRS.

If you have been a lawful permanent resident of the United States for at least eight of the last 15 tax years, you are a long-term resident. When determining whether you meet the eight-year requirement, do not count any years you are considered a foreign resident under the tax treaty, nor do you waive the benefits of the treaty.
Your renouncement date is the date you renounced your U.S. citizenship (if you were a former citizen) or ended your permanent residence (if you were a former U.S. resident).

Even if you do not qualify for a specific waiver, you must file an original Form 8854 in the year you renounce your U.S. citizenship or end your permanent residence. In addition, if you qualify for a specific waiver and you meet the following conditions, you must file a Form 8854 annually: 1.

You will be deemed to have terminated your permanent residence on the earlier of the following dates: 1. the date you voluntarily relinquish your legal permanent resident status by filing a U.S. Consular or Immigration official's Form i-407 to the Department of Homeland Security 2. the date you are bound by a final executive order for relinquishing your legal permanent resident status (or, if an appeal is filed against such an order, the date of the final judicial order relating to such an administrative order) 3. the date you are ultimately expelled from the United States under an executive order under Immigration and Nationality Act 4. the date you notify the IRS on Form 8833 and Form 8854 of a dual resident of a country with which the United States and the U.S. have an income tax treaty and are considered a resident of that country under that treaty. See the Effects of Tax Agreements in Chapter 1 for more information on dual residents.

If you moved abroad after June 16, 2008, you will be considered a specific waiver and the waiver rules under section 877A will apply to you if you meet any of the following conditions. 1. Your average annual net income tax for the five years prior to the date of your move abroad or termination of your residence exceeds: 1. $139,000 if you moved abroad or terminated your residence in 2008. 2. $145,000 if you moved abroad or terminated your residence in 2009 or 2010. 3. $147,000 if you moved abroad or terminated your residence in 2011. 4. $151,000 if you moved abroad or terminated your residence in 2012. 5. $155,000 if you moved abroad or terminated your residence in 2013. 6. $160,000 if you moved abroad or terminated your residence in 2014. 7. $162,000 if you moved abroad or terminated your residence in 2015. 8. $165,000 if you moved abroad or terminated your residence in 2016. 9. $165,000 if you moved abroad or terminated your residence in 2017. 10. $168,000 if you moved abroad or terminated your residence in 2018. 11. $171,000 if you moved abroad or terminated your residence in 2020.

If you are a U.S. citizen who was denationalized after March 18, 2010, you may be eligible for certain relief procedures that provide an alternative way to meet the taxation certification process. For more information, see the relief procedures for certain former citizens, available at IRS.gov/Individuals/International-Taxpayers/Relief-Procedures-for-Certain-Former-Citizens.

You may be eligible for the above exceptions if both of the following apply: You became a U.S. citizen at birth and a citizen of another country, and on the date of renunciation you remained a citizen of that other country and paid taxes as a resident of that other country. You have been a U.S. resident for no more than 10 years in the 15-year tax period ending in the tax year in which the renunciation occurred. When determining your right to reside in the United States, use the Actual Residence test described in Chapter 1.

In the year you abandon your citizenship, you are required to pay income tax on the unrealized net gain (or loss) of the property, as if the property had been sold at fair market value on the day before your move ("market value tax"). This applies to most types of property interests that you hold on the date you abandon your citizenship or terminate your residence. However, see the following exceptions. Gains from the sale of your citizenship must be calculated in the tax year in which the sale was made, regardless of other U.S. tax laws. Unless otherwise provided by U.S. tax law, losses from the sale must be included. However, section 1091 (the provision on losses from non-permitted false repurchase of stocks and securities) does not apply. You must include in your income the net gains reduced by the following amounts (but not less than zero): 1. $600,000 if you abandoned or terminated your citizenship before January 2009. 2. $626,000 if you abandoned or terminated your citizenship in 2009. 3. $627,000 if you abandoned or terminated your citizenship in 2010. 4. $636,000 if you abandoned or terminated your citizenship in 2011. 5. $651,000 if you abandoned or terminated your citizenship in 2012. 6. $668,000 if you abandoned or terminated your citizenship in 2013. 7. $680,000 if you abandoned or terminated your citizenship in 2014. 8. $690,000 if you abandoned or terminated your citizenship in 2015.

Once you have determined your foreign status, the source of your income, and whether and how your income is taxed in the United States, your next step is to calculate your taxes. The information in this chapter is not as comprehensive for tax residents as it is for non-tax residents. Tax residents should obtain the publications, forms, and instructions for U.S. citizens, as the information on the tax returns of tax residents is usually the same as that of U.S. citizens. If you are both a tax resident and a non-tax resident in the same tax year, see Chapter 6 for information about dual status aliens.

Non-tax residents may claim some of the same item-by-item deductions as tax residents. However, non-tax residents can only claim item-by-item deductions if their income is effectively linked to their U.S. trade or business presence. There may be some restrictions on claiming item-by-item deductions on Schedule A. See the explanation of Schedule A (Form 1040) or Schedule A, Form 1040-NR — Explanation of Item-by-Item Deductions, which is included in the explanation of Form 1040-NR.

If you receive income that is effectively linked to a U.S. trade or business presence, you may deduct certain item-by-item deductions. You can generally only include deductions and losses that are properly classified and allocated to income that is effectively linked to a U.S. trade or business presence. You cannot include deductions and/or losses related to tax-exempt income or income that is not effectively linked to a U.S. trade or business. However, you may deduct certain charitable donations and losses from injury and theft, even if they are not related to your effectively linked income. Use Schedule A (Form 1040-NR) to claim item-by-item deductions. For more information, see the Form 1040-NR notes.

A special rule applies to students and business apprentices who are eligible for the benefits under Article 21(2) of the U.S.-India Income Tax Agreement. If you do not claim a deduction per item, you can claim a standard deduction. Use Worksheet 5-1 to calculate your standard deduction for 2023. If you are married and your spouse files a tax return listing the deductions per item, you cannot claim a standard deduction.

You can deduct state and local income taxes you pay for income that is effectively linked to a commercial or business presence in the United States. Your deduction is limited to a total of $10,000 (or $5,000 if you separate after marriage). If you receive a tax refund or rebate in 2023 for tax you paid in the previous year, do not reduce that amount from your deduction. On the contrary, if you deducted tax in the previous year and the deduction reduced your tax, you must include the refund or rebate in your income. See Refunds, in Bulletin 525, for details on how to calculate the amount to be included in your income.
Residents as defined by the tax code generally apply the same rules as U.S. citizens to claim tax credits and report taxes, including withholding tax.

You can claim a credit for income tax paid or due to a foreign country on income from foreign sources, but there are limitations. You cannot claim a credit for taxes paid or due on excluded foreign income. To claim a credit for income tax paid or due to a foreign country, you usually file Form 1116 with your Form 1040 or Form 1040-SR. For more information, see Bulletin 514.

You may be eligible for this credit if you pay someone to care for your eligible dependent child under the age of 13, or your disabled dependent or spouse, so that you can work or seek employment. For more information, see Form 2441 and Bulletin 503.

You may be eligible for this credit (also known as the Saver's Credit) if you have invested eligible amounts in an employer-sponsored retirement plan or personal retirement plan (IRA) in 2023. Use Form 8880 and its instructions to calculate the credit. For more information on the requirements for claiming the credit, see Bulletin 590-A.

The Other Dependent Credit applies to dependents who cannot claim a child tax credit. Eligible dependents must be U.S. citizens, U.S. nationals, or residents as defined by U.S. tax law, and must have a Social Security Number (SSN), an Individual Tax Identification Number (ITIN), or an Adoption Tax Identification Number (ATIN) on or before your 2023 tax return deadline (including extensions).See Form 8812 (Form 1040) and its notes for more information.

The Low Income Family Benefit or Earned Income Tax Credit (EITC) is a benefit for low- and middle-income workers. To qualify for the Low Income Family Benefit, you must earn an income from working for someone or running or owning a business or farm, and meet the basic rules. In addition, you must meet the additional requirements for workers without qualifying children, or your children must meet all of the qualifying requirements. The Low Income Family Benefit reduces the tax you owe and may give you a refund. For more information, go to IRS.gov/EIC. If you (and your spouse, if you file a joint tax return) do not have a Social Security number on or before the due date of your original or amended 2023 tax return (including deferred tax returns), you cannot apply for the Low Income Family Benefit. In addition, if your child does not have a Social Security number on or before the due date of your original or amended 2023 tax return (including deferred tax returns), you cannot consider the child as a qualifying child for the calculation of the Low Income Family Benefit. If your Social Security card has a stamp that says "Not Valid for Employment" and the number was issued for you (or your spouse or your qualifying child) to receive federally funded benefits, you cannot claim the Low Income Family Benefit.

You can claim some of the credits that are also available to residents defined by the tax code. You can also report specific taxes that you have paid, are deemed to have paid, or have withheld from your income.
The credit is only available when you receive a valid linked income. You may be eligible for the following portions of the credit.

If you receive income from a foreign source that is effectively connected to a commercial or business presence in the United States, you may claim a credit for any income tax paid or accrued on any foreign or U.S. property on that income. If you do not have income from a foreign source that is effectively connected to a commercial or business presence in the United States, you cannot claim a U.S. tax credit for taxes paid or accrued on foreign or U.S. territory. If these taxes are levied solely because you are a citizen or resident of a foreign country or foreign property, you cannot receive any credits from taxes levied on your U.S. property on your income from a foreign source. If you claim a foreign tax credit, you must usually attach a Form 1116 to your tax return. See Bulletin 514 for more information.

If you pay someone to care for your eligible dependent child under the age of 13, or your disabled dependent or spouse, so that you can work or seek work, you may qualify for this credit. For definitions of these terms, see 503. Married non-tax residents can claim the credits described in How to Make the Choice in Chapter 1 only if they choose to do so together with a U.S. citizen or resident spouse, or if they meet the specific eligibility requirements for separately resident married persons (see Joint Return Test in 503). In any tax year, you may not be eligible for a child and dependent care credit in an amount greater than the amount of income you earn from the United States in that tax year.

This is a non-refundable tax credit of $500 per eligible person. Eligible dependants must be U.S. citizens, U.S. nationals, or residents as defined by U.S. tax law. See the instructions on Form 1040-NR. To claim the credit for other dependents, your dependents must have a Social Security number, Personal Tax Identification Number, or Adoption Tax Identification Number on or before the due date of their 2023 tax return (including extensions). Only non-tax residents of U.S. citizens, residents of Canada, Mexico, or South Korea, and students and business apprentices from India who are eligible for a benefit under Section 21(2) of the Income Tax Treaty with India may claim the credit for other dependents.

You may be eligible for a tax credit of up to $15,950 for qualifying expenses for adopting a qualifying child. This amount can be used for adopting a child with special needs, regardless of whether you have qualifying expenses. To claim an adoption credit, report Form 8839 with Form 1040-SR. Married non-tax residents can claim the credit only if they elect to file jointly with a citizen or resident spouse as described in Chapter 1, Non-resident spouse is considered a resident, or if they meet the requirements for certain separately resident married persons (see Post-marriage separation returns, which is described in Form 8839).

If you are a non-tax resident for any part of the tax year, you may not be able to claim an EIC. However, if you are married and choose to file with a U.S. citizen or resident spouse, such as a non-resident spouse in Chapter 1, you may be eligible for the credit. If you and your spouse do not have a Social Security number on or before the due date of your 2023 tax return (including extensions), you will not be able to claim an EIC on your original or amended 2023 tax return. In addition, if your child does not have a set of Social Security numbers on or before the due date of your 2023 tax return (including extensions), you will not be able to consider the child as a qualifying child for the purposes of calculating your original or amended 2023 low-income family benefit. If a Social Security card has a stamp that says "Not Valid for Employment" and the number was issued for you (or your spouse or qualifying child) to receive federally funded benefits, you will not be able to claim an EIC. For example, health care benefits are a federally funded benefit. If the card has this stamp and the individual's immigration status has changed, the individual is now a U.S. citizen or legal permanent resident, ask the Social Security Department to issue a new unstamped EIC. See Bulletin 596 for more information about this credit.

When you are a non-tax resident, any federal income tax withheld from your salary in the tax year can be used to pay your U.S. income tax obligations for the same year. You can claim withholding income tax regardless of whether you engaged in trade or business in the U.S. in the year and whether your salary (or any other income) was related to trade or business in the U.S.

For wages or Railway Retirement Tax Act (RRTA) benefits paid to you in excess of $200,000 in 2023, your employer is responsible for withholding an additional 0.9% (0.009) of health insurance tax. If you do not owe additional health insurance tax, you can deduct any additional health insurance tax withheld from your total tax liability reported on your tax return by filing Form 8959.

If you are a shareholder of a mutual fund (or other regulated investment corporation (RIC)) or real estate investment trust (REIT), you may claim a credit for part of the tax paid by the company on your unallocated long-term capital gains. You will receive this information on Form 2439 and need to attach it to your tax return.

You may claim any tax that has been withheld at the source of the investment and on your other FDAP income at the time of the payment to you. Fixed or determined income includes interest, dividends, rents and royalties that you have not claimed as having a valid link. Salary or payroll payments may be fixed or determined income, but are usually subject to the above withholding tax. Tax on fixed or determined income is withheld at a rate of 30% or the lower agreed rate.

If you are a foreign partner in a partnership, the partnership will withhold tax on your share of the effective link taxable income (ECTI) from the partnership. The partnership will provide you with a statement showing the withholding tax on Form 8805. A publicly traded partnership will withhold tax on the actual allocation of the effective link. In this case, the partnership will provide you with a statement on Form 1042-S. Claim the withholding tax on Line 25e or Line 25g of Form 1040-NR, as applicable.

If you are a direct or indirect foreign partner of a U.S. or foreign affiliate that engages (or is deemed to engage) in trade or business in the United States and you dispose of interests in the proceeds directly or indirectly, the assignee will typically withhold and pay the IRS a tax on your behalf equivalent to 10% of the sales income for transfers after 2017. The rules for withholding and paying over this amount are similar to those for the sale of U.S. real estate. You will receive a Form 8288-A reflecting the amount withheld, and you can then report that amount as a tax benefit on Form 1040-NR on line 25f. You may be able to provide the assignee with certain information to reduce or eliminate the withholding tax. For example, if the uncertainty clause of the U.S. tax code applies to all the proceeds from the transfer, the assignee does not need to withhold tax when you provide notice describing the application of the uncertainty clause. If you are an applicable assignee, the affiliate may allocate withholding tax to you under section 1446(f)(4). T.D. 9926 (85 FR 76910), published on November 30, 2020 (as amended by 86 FR 13191), contains final provisions (the 1446(f) provisions) regarding withholding tax and reporting on transfers of certain partnership interests under section 1446(f), including the withholding tax requirements for the agent who transfers the PTP interest.

You may claim any tax withheld from the disposal of U.S. real estate interests (or income considered to have been derived from the disposal of U.S. real estate interests). See Real Estate Gains in Chapter 4. The buyer will provide you with a statement of the amount withheld on Form 8288-A. Claim the withheld tax on line 25f of Form 1040-NR.

If you are a non-tax resident and are a genuine resident of American Samoa or Puerto Rico for the entire tax year, your tax obligations are usually the same as those of a tax resident. You should report all income from both U.S. and non-U.S. sources on Form 1040 or Form 1040-SR. However, you may exclude the income discussed in the following paragraphs. For tax purposes other than reporting income, you will be considered a non-tax resident. For example, you are not allowed to use standard deductions, you cannot file jointly, and you cannot claim dependents unless the person is a U.S. citizen or national. There are also limits on the amounts of deductions and credits that are allowed. See Tax Resident Definitions for details on deductions, item-by-item deductions, and tax credits and payments in this chapter.

If you have been a genuine resident of Puerto Rico for the entire year, you can exclude all income from Puerto Rican sources from your total income (except for the amounts earned as an employee of the United States or any of its agencies providing services). If you report income for a calendar year and you have no salary to be withheld in 2023, file your tax return and pay your taxes by June 15, 2024. You must also pay your first estimated tax for 2024 by June 15, 2024. You cannot file a joint income tax return or jointly pay estimated taxes. However, if you are married to a U.S. citizen or resident, see Chapter 1, Non-resident spouse is considered a resident. If your earned salary is subject to withholding, your U.S. income tax return should be filed by April 15, 2024. You must also pay your first estimated tax for 2024 by April 15, 2024. For information on withholding and withholding taxes, see Chapter 8.

If you are a genuine resident of American Samoa for the entire year, you may exclude from your total income all income from American Samoa (except for amounts earned for services provided as an employee of the United States Government or any of its agencies).

You must calculate your income and file your tax returns during an annual accounting period, called the tax year. If you have not previously established a fiscal tax year, your tax year is the calendar year. A calendar year is a consecutive 12 months ending on December 31. If you have previously established a regular fiscal year (a consecutive 12 months ending on the last day of the month other than December or a year of 52 to 53 weeks) and are considered a U.S. resident for any calendar year, your fiscal year will be considered a U.S. resident for any part of that calendar year.

If you do not have and are not eligible for a Social Security Number, you must apply for an Individual Tax Identification Number (ITIN). If you are engaged in a trade or business as a sole proprietor and have employees or a qualifying retirement plan, you need an Employer Identification Number (EIN). You must provide a Tax Identification Number (TIN) if you meet the following conditions: A foreigner who has income effectively related to the conduct of a U.S. trade or business at any time in the year; A foreigner who has an office or place of business in the U.S. at any time in the year; A spouse of a non-resident defined as a resident as described in Chapter 1; Or Any other foreigner who files a tax return, amended tax return or tax refund (but not an information return) or or or or or or or or or or or or or or or or or or or or or or or or or or or or or or or or or or or or or or or or or or or or or or or or or or or or or or or or or or or or or or or or or or or or or or or or or or or or or or or or or or or or or or or or or or or or or or or or or or or or or or or or or or or or or or or or or or or or or or or or or or or or or or or or or or or or or or or or or or or or or or or or or or or or or or or or or or or or or or or or or or or or or or or or or or or or or or or or or or or or or or or or or or or or or or or or or or or or or or or or or or or or or or or or or or or or or or or or or or or or or or or or or or or or or or or or or or or or or or or or or or or or or or or or or or or or or or or or or or or or or or or or or or or or or or or or or or or or or or or or or or or or or or or or or or or or or or or or or or or or or or or or or or or or or or or or or or or or or or or

If you hold an F-1, M-1 or J-1 visa, please refer to the Social Security Administration's Publication 05-10181, available at SSA.gov/Pubs/10181.html, for more information on the documents you must provide to prove your immigration status.

If you already have a set of personal tax identification numbers, fill it in anywhere on your tax return where a social security number is required. If you do not have an ITIN and are not eligible for a social security number, you must apply for a personal tax identification number. For details on how to do this, see Form W-7 and its instructions. If you qualify for a personal tax identification number and have completed your application, you will usually receive a letter from the IRS assigning you a tax number within 7 weeks. If you do not receive a personal tax identification number or other correspondence within 7 weeks of your application, call the IRS toll-free number 800-829-1040 to check your application status (if you are in the United States). If you are outside the United States, call 267-941-1000 (not a toll-free number). A personal tax identification number is for tax purposes only. Under U.S. law, you are not entitled to social security benefits or to change your employment or immigration status. Form W-7 must also be filed for spouses or dependants of foreigners who are eligible for allowable tax benefits but are not eligible for a social security number, except for those who are required to provide a tax identification number (TIN) and are not eligible for a social security number. For more information on obtaining a personal tax identification number, see the instructions for Form W-7 or go to IRS.gov/ITIN.

In general, you can only file a married joint return as described in Chapter 1 if you and your spouse are both U.S. citizens or tax-defined residents for the entire tax year, or if you choose to become a tax-defined resident spouse who is considered a resident.

Married non-tax residents who are not married to a U.S. citizen or resident are generally required to use the post-marriage separate tax return column or the tax calculation worksheet in order to determine whether there is an income tax effectively associated with the U.S. trade or business.

However, if you have lived separately from your spouse in the last 6 months of a year and you are a married resident of Canada, Mexico, or Korea, or a married U.S. citizen, you may be able to file as a single person. See the explanation of Form 1040-NR to check if you qualify. The definition of "U.S. citizen" is explained later in this section. A non-tax resident may not generally file as a married person. However, a non-tax resident who is married to a U.S. citizen or resident may elect to be treated as a resident and file jointly on Form 1040 or Form 1040-SR. For information on these options, see Chapter 1. If you do not elect to file jointly, file Form 1040-NR and use the tax returns or tax calculations sheets for married persons.

An individual who, although not a U.S. citizen, is loyal to the United States is considered a U.S. national. In addition, U.S. nationals include American Samoa and Northern Mariana Islanders who have chosen to become U.S. citizens rather than U.S. citizens.

If you are a non-tax resident at any time during the tax year, you cannot file as a head of household. However, if you are married, your spouse is eligible to be a head of household if: Your spouse has been a tax resident or a U.S. citizen throughout the tax year; You have not elected to be treated as a tax resident; and Your spouse meets the other requirements for this tax status, as set out in the Tax Residents Rules.

Resident estates or trusts defined by non-tax law using Form 1040-NR must use Schedule W of the Rates for Income Taxes effectively related to U.S. trade or business in order to determine whether there is a tax liability.

You must report each income according to the rules of Chapters 2, 3, and 4. For tax-law residents, this includes income from both U.S. and non-U.S. sources. For non-tax-law residents, this includes income that has an effective link to U.S. trade or business (applies progressive tax rate) and income from the U.S. that has no effective link (applies 30% uniform rate or lower tax treaty rate).

Residents and non-tax residents can claim similar deductions on their U.S. tax returns. However, non-tax residents can usually only claim deductions for income that is effectively related to their trade or business presence in the United States.

You can claim deductions to calculate your effectively linked taxable income (ECTI). You generally cannot claim deductions for income that is not related to your U.S. business activity. Except for the specific item-by-item deductions described below, you can only claim deductions to the extent that they relate to your effectively linked income.

You may deduct all ordinary and necessary expenses associated with your U.S. trade or business operations and income effectively related to that trade or business.For information on other business expenses, see the Guide to Business Expense Resources at IRS.gov/Pub535.

If you paid interest on a qualifying student loan in 2023, you can deduct up to $2,500 from the interest paid. In general, if all requirements are met, you can claim the deduction. The deduction is reported on line 21 of Annex 1 (Form 1040). Attach Annex 1 (Form 1040) to your Form 1040-NR. To calculate the deduction, see the instructions for Form 1040-NR. For more information, see Bulletin 970.

If your income is effectively linked to a U.S. trade or business presence, you may deduct up to 20% of your qualifying business income from your qualifying trade or business, plus 20% of your qualifying dividends from real estate investment trust shares and qualifying publicly traded partnership (PTP) income. For more information, see Line 13a in the Notes to Form 1040-NR. For more information on qualifying business income deductions, see Form 8995, Form 8995-A and its Appendices, and the Notes to the Form and Appendices.

If there is an income that is effectively related to the trade or business in the United States, you may deduct losses from transactions you have made for profit, provided that you have not received compensation for them through insurance or otherwise.

If you are a qualifying educator in 2023, you can deduct an income adjustment of up to $300 from unreported qualifying expenses paid or incurred during 2023 for specific professional development courses and books, supplies (except non-sports supplies for health or physical education courses), computer equipment (including related software and services) and other auxiliary equipment and teaching materials used in class. Refer to your tax return for more information. Eligible expenses include the amounts paid or incurred in 2023 for personal protective equipment, disinfectants and other supplies used to prevent the spread of the coronavirus.

If you have invested in a traditional personal retirement plan in 2023, you may be eligible for a personal retirement plan deduction. But you must have taxable salary that is effectively linked to U.S. trade or business to do so. You should receive Form 5498 by May 31, 2024, showing all of your contributions to a traditional personal retirement plan in 2023. If you are a member of a retirement plan while working or through self-employment (qualifying pension, profit sharing (including 401(k)), annuity, simplified employee retirement plan, employee savings bonus plan, etc.), your personal retirement plan deduction may be reduced or cancelled. However, even if you are not eligible for a deduction, you can still contribute to a traditional personal retirement plan. If you have invested in a traditional IRA for a non-deductible amount in 2023, you must report it on Form 8606. For more information, see IRA 590-A.

Please exclude the value of removal and storage services provided by the Government, as this is an event of relocation under military order and permanent change of stationing location. Similarly, please exclude the amount of income received as relocation allowance, temporary accommodation expenses, temporary accommodation allowance or relocation allowance. For more information, see Bulletin No. 3.

If you are self-employed, you may deduct from your contributions to a simplified employee pension, employee savings bonus plan, or qualifying retirement plan the amounts that provide retirement benefits for you and your CIT employees (if any). To make deductible contributions for yourself, you must have self-employed net income that is effectively associated with your trade or business presence in the United States. See U.S. 560 for more information.

You must include in your income all validly linked interest income you received or credited to your account in the year. Do not use any penalty you have to pay for early withdrawals from your deposit account to deduct it. However, if the interest income is validly linked to your trade or business presence in the United States in the year, you may deduct the amount of the early withdrawal penalty charged by the bank on line 17 of Schedule 1 (Form 1040). Attach Appendix 1 (Form 1040) to your Form 1040-NR.

If you are a taxable resident on the last day of the tax year and file your income for the calendar year, you must file by April 15 of the year following the end of the tax year (but see the Tips section below). If you do not file your income for the calendar year, file your tax return by the 15th day of the 4th month following the end of the tax year. In any case, you must send your tax return to the address for dual status aliens listed on the back of the Form 1040. If you are a non-taxable resident on the last day of the tax year and file your income for the calendar year, you must file the withholding salary by April 15 of the year following the end of the tax year. If you do not file your income for the calendar year, file your tax return by the 15th day of the 4th month following the end of the tax year. If you do not receive the withholding salary and file your income for the calendar year, you must file your tax return by June 15 of the year following the end of the tax year. If you do not file your income for the calendar year, file your tax return by the 15th day of the 6th month following the end of the tax year. In any case, mail your tax return to: Department of the Treasury Internal Revenue Service Austin, TX 73301-0215 If you want to attach a payment, mail your tax return to: Internal Revenue Service P.O.Box 1303 Charlotte, NC 28201-1303 If the normal filing deadline is on a Saturday, Sunday or a public holiday, mail your tax return by the next day (not the 15th of the month following the end of the tax year).

You must file your tax return within an annual accounting period, which is called the tax year. If you have not previously established a fiscal tax year, your tax year is the calendar year. A calendar year is a consecutive 12 months ending on December 31. If you have previously established a regular fiscal year (a consecutive 12 months ending on the last day of the month other than December or a year of 52 to 53 weeks) and are considered a U.S. resident for any calendar year, your fiscal year will be considered a U.S. resident for any part of that calendar year.

For that part of the year in which you are a tax resident, your income from all sources is taxed. If you receive income from sources outside the United States during the period in which you are a tax resident, you are taxed. Even if you earn that income during the period in which you are a non-tax resident, or if you become a non-tax resident after receiving that income and before the year in which you are a tax resident, you are taxed. For that part of the year in which you are a tax resident, you are taxed on your income from the United States and on certain foreign income that is deemed to have a valid link to a U.S. trade or business. Chapter 4 discusses the rules for treating income from foreign sources as having a valid link, which is contained in Foreign Income. If you receive income from sources outside the United States during a period in which you are a tax resident, and the income does not have a valid link to a trade or business in the United States, you are not taxed. Unless you are specifically exempt under the national tax laws or tax treaty provisions, income from the United States is taxed whether you are a tax resident or a non-tax resident. In general, tax treaty provisions apply only to the time you are a non-resident part of the year. However, in certain circumstances, when you are a tax resident, treaty provisions may apply. See Chapter 9 for more information. When determining which income is to be taxed in the United States, you must consider exemptions under U.S. tax law and the low rate and exemption provisions provided by tax treaties between the United States and certain foreign countries.

See the instructions on Form 1040-NR to check if you qualify. A U.S. citizen is a person who, although not a U.S. citizen, is loyal to the United States. U.S. citizenship includes American Samoa and Northern Mariana Islands citizens who have chosen to become U.S. citizens rather than U.S. citizens.

All income from your residence and all income from your non-residence that is effectively linked to a U.S. trade or business presence is assessed and taxed at the rate applicable to U.S. citizens and residents, after deduction of the allowable deductions. Unified tax rate of 30% or the lower agreed rate applies to income from non-residence that is not effectively linked to a U.S. trade or business presence. You cannot deduct any expenses from such income.

In a year in which you are a non-tax resident, 85% of any U.S. social security benefits (and equivalent portions of Tier 1 railway pension benefits) you receive are subject to a 30% uniform tax, unless you are exempt or subject to a lower treaty tax rate. (See the 30% tax rule in Chapter 4.) For a part of a year in which you are a tax resident, if your adjusted total income plus half of those benefits exceeds a certain base, then part of the social security benefits and equal portions of Tier 1 railway pension benefits will be taxed at a progressive rate. Use the Social Security Benefits Worksheet in the Form 1040 Notes to help you calculate the taxable portion of your social security benefits and equal portions of Tier 1 railway pension benefits for the year in which you are a tax resident. If you received U.S. social security benefits during a non-tax resident period, the Social Security Administration (SSA) will send you Form SSA-1042S showing your combined benefits and withholding tax for the year. You will not receive a separate tax return based on the benefits received during the periods of residence and non-residence in the United States. Therefore, it is important that you keep a careful record of these amounts. You will need this information to complete your tax return correctly and calculate your tax liability. If you receive a railway pension benefit during a non-tax resident period, the U.S. Railway Pension Board (RRB) will send you Form RRB-1042S — Non-Resident Foreign Recipient Tax Return for Railroad Pension Board Payments, and/or Form RRB-1099-R — Annuity or Pension Provided by the Railway Pension Board. If your country of legal residence changes or is taxed during the tax year, you will receive a Form RRB-1099-R — Annuity or Pension Provided by the Railway Pension Board.

As a dual-status foreigner, you generally apply the same tax credit claim rules as a resident as defined by the tax code. There may be specific limitations between these. These limitations are discussed here, and a summary of the amounts that are usually claimed by individuals is provided. Unless you are married and you choose to be treated as a resident for the full year 2023 through joint taxation with your U.S. citizen or resident spouse, you will not be able to claim an education credit, an EIC, or an elderly or disabled credit, as described in Chapter 1.

If you have paid or are liable to pay income tax to a foreign country on income from a foreign source, you may claim a foreign tax credit. If you claim a foreign tax credit, you will usually have to file Form 1116 with your income tax return. For more information, see the Form 1116 explanation and Bulletin 514.

If you pay someone to care for your eligible dependent child under 13, or your disabled dependent or spouse, so that you can work or seek work, you may qualify for this credit. Married foreigners with dual status can claim the credit only when they elect to file jointly, as described in Chapter 1, or if they qualify for a specific separated married person. In any tax year, you are not eligible for more than your income in that tax year for the amount of the child and dependent care credit. For more information, see Bulletin 503 and Form 2441.

The Other Dependent Credit applies to dependents who cannot claim a child tax credit. Eligible dependents must be U.S. citizens, U.S. nationals, or residents as defined by U.S. tax law, and must have a set of Social Security numbers, Personal Tax Identification Numbers, or Adoption Tax Identification Numbers on or before your 2023 tax return deadline (including extensions).

You may be eligible for a tax credit of up to $15,950 for qualifying expenses for adopting a qualifying child. This amount can be used for adopting a child with special needs, regardless of whether you have qualifying expenses. To claim an adoption credit, please include Form 8839 with your U.S. income tax return. Married foreigners with dual status can only claim the credit if they have elected to treat their non-resident spouse as a resident under Chapter 1 or if they meet the requirements for certain separated married persons (see the explanation for Form 8839).

You can also report specific taxes that you have paid, are deemed to have paid, or have withheld from your income as payments to your U.S. income tax obligations.This includes: Taxes deducted from wages earned in the U.S. Taxes withheld from all U.S. income sources (other than wages) Estimated taxes paid using Form 1040-ES or Form 1040-ES(NR) Taxes paid when leaving the U.S. using Form 1040-C.

If you are a dual-status taxpayer who became a resident in the year and is a U.S. resident on the last day of the tax year, you must file a Form 1040 or Form 1040-SR. Enter "Dual-Status Return" at the top of your tax return. Attach a statement to your tax return showing your income for the period of time you were a non-resident. You can use Form 1040-NR as a statement, but be sure to enter "Dual-Status Statement" at the top of your tax return.

If you are a dual-status taxpayer who renounced U.S. resident status in the year and are not a U.S. resident on the last day of the tax year, you must file a Form 1040-NR. Enter "Dual-Status Return" at the top of your tax return. Attach a statement to your tax return showing your income for the time you were a resident. You can use either Form 1040 or Form 1040-SR as a statement, but be sure to enter "Dual-Status Statement" at the top. If you renounce or cease residence in 2023, you may need to file a declaration of renouncement (Form 8854) on your tax return. For more information, see Chapter 4, Renouncement Taxes.

Any declaration must contain your name, address and tax identification number (TIN). You do not need to sign a separate declaration or annex on the tax return, as your signature on the tax return applies equally to the auxiliary declaration and annex.

A resident as defined by the tax code must file Form 1040 or Form 1040-SR at the address shown in the instructions for Form 1040. The deadline for filing the tax return and paying any taxes due is April 15 of the year following the year you filed your tax return (but see the description in the Tip above). Under U.S. immigration law, a lawful permanent resident who is required to file a tax return as a resident is considered to have given up his or her status and may lose permanent resident status if he or she does not do so.

If you file Form 4868 and do not file your tax return by the deadline, you may automatically receive an extension of 6 months (15 October for taxpayers filing for a calendar year). For more information, see Form 4868. The automatic extension of 6 months will not extend your tax return. If you do not file your tax return by the original deadline, you will incur interest on the outstanding tax and may be required to pay a penalty. If your main place of business and residence is outside the United States and Puerto Rico on April 15, you may automatically receive an extension to June 15. If you need more time before the end of the 2-month period and file Form 4868 by June 15, you may receive an additional 4-month extension until October 15. In addition to the 6-month extension, you must send a letter to the IRS stating the reasons for your additional 2-month extension (15 December for taxpayers filing for a calendar year).

You must also file if you want to: Claim a refund for excess withholding or overpayment of tax, or claim any deduction or credit. For example, if you do not conduct business in the United States but have real estate income that you choose to treat as Effectively Linked Income (as described in Chapter 4), you must file a true and accurate tax return on time so that any allowable deductions can be deducted from that income. For information on what is timely, see When to claim deductions and credits and When to file.

Even if you have left the United States and filed a Form 1040-C on departure, you must still file an annual U.S. income tax return. If you are married and you and your spouse are required to file, you must file separate tax returns.

If a foreigner wholly owns a domestic negligible entity (DE), the DE is considered a separate domestic company from its owner (a foreigner) for the purposes of the requirements for 25% foreign-owned domestic companies under section 6038A. A DE must file a substitute form for Form 1120 and Form 5472 before the reporting deadline (including extensions). The only information required to be entered on Form 1120 is the name and address of the DE and items B and E of Part I. If a DE has a reportable U.S. trade or business or other activity prior to 2017, it may have a reporting requirement. See the Form 5472 notes for more information and how to work with Form 5472 for the DE. In addition, note that since a DE is usually a transparent entity, a foreigner will not include (or continue to include) any taxes that a DE must report on Form 1040-NR.

If you are unable to file your tax return by the deadline, file Form 4868 or use one of the electronic filing options described in the Form 4868 instructions. For the calendar year 2023, the due date will be extended to October 15, 2024. If your normal due date is June 17, 2024, this will extend the due date to December 15, 2024. You must file the extension before the normal due date of your tax return. The automatic extension of 6 months of filing time will not extend your tax filing time. If you do not pay your tax by the original due date, you will incur interest on the unpaid tax and may be required to pay a penalty. See Form 4868.

The following credits are not affected by this time requirement: Credits for withholding tax Credits for excise tax on gasoline and special fuels for specific uses Tax credits for relocation of undistributed long-term capital gains by mutual funds (or other regulated investment companies) or real estate investment trusts

If your activity in the United States is restricted and you believe that you have no total income that is effectively linked to your U.S. trade or business in the year, you can file a protective tax return (Form 1040-NR) before the above deadline. By filing a protective tax return, you protect your right to deductions and credits if it is later determined that some or all of your income is effectively linked. You do not have to file any effectively linked income or any deductions on a protective tax return, but you must state the reason for filing the tax return. If you believe that you have effectively linked income from a particular activity, file a tax return before the regular due date, declaring that income and the amount of the deductions. To protect your right to claim deductions or credits from other activities, attach a statement to that tax return stating that you wish to protect your right to claim deductions and credits if it is later determined that other activities have generated effectively linked income. If you believe that you are not subject to U.S. tax obligations as a result of a U.S. tax treaty, you can follow the same procedure. Be sure to also enter item L on Annex OI (Form 1040-NR).

Report all income from the United States on your tax return, as well as income from other sources. For information on filing a U.S. Virgin Islands tax return, contact the U.S. Virgin Islands Revenue Service. If you are a true resident of the U.S. Virgin Islands for the entire tax year and work temporarily in the United States, you must pay taxes to the U.S. Virgin Islands and file your income tax return at: Virgin Islands Bureau of Internal Revenue 6115 Estate Smith Bay Suite 225 St. Thomas, VI 00802.

If you are a genuine resident of Guam or the Commonwealth of the Northern Mariana Islands (CNMI) for the entire tax year, you must file a tax return to Guam or the Northern Mariana Islands and pay any taxes payable to Guam or the Northern Mariana Islands. Report all income, including income from the United States, on your tax return. You do not need to file a separate U.S. income tax return. Genuine Guam residents should file their Guam tax returns at the following addresses: Department of Revenue and Taxation Government of Guam P.O.Box 23607 Barrigada, GU 96921. Genuine residents of the Commonwealth of the Northern Mariana Islands should file their Commonwealth of the Northern Mariana Islands income tax returns at the following addresses: Department of Finance Division of Revenue and Taxation Commonwealth of the Northern Mariana Islands P.O.Box 5234 CHRB Saipan, MP 96950. If you are not a genuine resident of Guam or the Commonwealth of the Northern Mariana Islands, please refer to Bulletin 570 for information on where to file your tax returns.

If you notice that you need to change your income, deductions, or credits after you mail your tax return, file Form 1040-X. If you should file Form 1040 or Form 1040-SR instead of Form 1040-NR, use Form 1040-X, and vice versa. If you amend Form 1040-NR or file the correct tax return, enter "Amended" at the top and attach the amended tax return (Form 1040, Form 1040-SR, or Form 1040-NR) to Form 1040-X. Generally, amended tax returns for tax refund must be filed within 3 years of the date you filed your tax return or within 2 years of the tax date, whichever is later. Tax returns filed before the final deadline are deemed to have been filed before the deadline.
You may need to report a certain foreign income or asset or currency transaction on a declaration form.

Non-declaration, reporting containing material omissions or misstatements, or reporting false or fraudulent information are subject to civil and criminal penalties. In addition, the entire amount of money or monetary instruments may be seized and confiscated.

If the total value of these assets exceeds the applicable s-value (the "reporting threshold"), you must report on Form 8938. The reporting threshold varies depending on whether you are resident in the United States, married, or filing jointly with your spouse. Specific foreign financial assets include any financial account held by a foreign financial institution, and for any investment holdings, any stock, securities, or any other interest in an offshore entity, and any financial instrument or contract with a non-U.S. issuer or counterparty. If you are required to report on Form 8938 but do not do so, or if you underreport any transaction involving undisclosed foreign financial assets, you may be required to pay a penalty. For more information on reporting on Form 8938, see the Form 8938 notes.

If you fail to file your tax return and pay your taxes by the deadline, you may have to pay a fine. You may also have to pay a fine if you have seriously underreported, filed a meaningless tax return, or failed to provide a tax identification number (TIN). If you provide fraudulent information on your tax return, you may have to pay a civil fraud fine.

If you want to disclose the facts about your tax treatment of an item, please use Form 8275 to disclose. You must also have a reasonable basis for treating the item in your way. In the case of a serious underreporting, the required item (or its successor) is deemed to be fully disclosed on your tax return. The 2023-40 tax clause does not take into account the impact of tax changes that come into effect after December 31, 2023. If the content of this tax clause is affected by such changes and requires additional reporting, a taxpayer may be required to report a Form 8275 or a Form 8275-R, a Regulation Disclosure, until the requirements of the regulations or other published guidelines are met.
If you provide a sufficient justification (a reasonable reason) for the way you handle the item, you will not have to pay the penalty. You must also demonstrate that you acted in good faith.

If you file an incorrect tax return to claim a refund or credit, you may be required to pay a penalty. The penalty is equal to 20% of the amount of the refused refund or credit, unless you can prove that you have a reasonable reason to claim it. However, the amount of the refusal due to a lack of economic substantiality of the transaction will not be considered a reasonable reason. Any amount of the refused refund or credit that is subject to an accuracy-related or fraudulent penalty will not be included in the calculation.

If you file a meaningless tax return or file other meaningless items, you may be required to pay a fine of $5,000. A meaningless tax return is one that does not contain enough information to calculate the correct tax, or that contains information that clearly indicates that the tax you filed was materially incorrect. For more information on meaningless tax returns, meaningless returns, and a list of conduct that is deemed meaningless, see IRS.gov/irb/2010-17_IRB#NOT-2010-33 (or its successor). If you file such a tax return in a reckless manner or in an attempt to delay or disrupt the enforcement of federal tax law, you will be required to pay a fine. This includes changing or deleting the pre-printed language above the space provided for your signature. This penalty is in addition to any other penalties prescribed by law and may be increased by the amount of the penalty.

If you do not include your Social Security Number (SSN) or Personal Tax Identification Number (ITIN) or someone else's Social Security Number or Personal Tax Identification Number on your tax return, statement or other document, you may be fined $50 per missing item. You may also be fined $50 if you fail to provide your Social Security Number or Personal Tax Identification Number to someone else when requested on your tax return, statement or other document. For example, if you have an interest-bearing bank account, you must provide your Social Security Number or Personal Tax Identification Number to your bank. The number must appear on Form 1099-INT or on another statement sent to you by your bank. If you do not provide your Social Security Number or Personal Tax Identification Number to your bank, you will face a $50 fine. (You may also be required to pay a backup withholding tax.) If you can prove that the missing item was due to reasonable cause and not intentional negligence, you do not have to pay the penalty.
If you fail to file your tax return due to fraud, you will be fined 15% for each month you are late (a month for any part of the month) up to a maximum of 75%.

If you fail to pay your taxes on time, you will be liable to pay ½ (0.005) of the outstanding tax for each month you have not paid (one month for any part of the month that is overdue). If you pay at least 90% of your actual tax obligation by the due date of your tax return and pay the balance when you file your tax return, there will be no penalty for the period of 6 months automatically extended by the filing deadline. If a instalment agreement takes effect in that month, the monthly interest rate on outstanding penalty is half the general rate, 1/4% (0.0025, not ½% (0.005)). You must file your tax return by the due date (including extensions) to qualify for the penalty relief. If a notice of intent to collect is given, the rate will be increased to 1% starting from the first month at least 10 days after the date of the notice. If a notice and request for immediate payment is given, the rate will increase to 1% starting from the first month following the date of the notice and request. The penalty may not exceed 25% of your outstanding tax. You will not be liable to pay the penalty if you can prove that you have a good reason for not paying your tax on time.

The fine is equal to 20% of the shortfall. The fine is equal to 40% of the shortfall attributable to an undisclosed non-economically material transaction or an undisclosed offshore financial asset transaction. As discussed below, the fine is not counted towards the collection of the shortfall of the fraudulent fine.

This chapter discusses how to pay U.S. income tax when you earn or receive income in a year. Generally, federal income tax is payable as you earn. Payable as you earn is done in two ways. 1. Withholding tax. If you are an employee, your employer may withhold income tax from your salary. Certain other incomes may also be taxed, including retirement benefits, bonuses, commissions, and gambling winnings. In each case, the amount withheld will be paid in your name to the U.S. Treasury. 2. Estimating tax. If you have not paid withholding tax, or have not paid enough tax in this way, you may have to pay estimated tax. People who do their own business are usually taxed in this way. If you receive income from dividends, interest, rent, and royalties, you may have to pay estimated tax. Estimated tax is used not only to pay income tax, but also to pay self-employment tax and alternative minimum tax.

You must let your employer know whether you are a resident or a non-tax resident so that your employer can deduct the correct tax from your salary. If you are a tax resident as defined under Rule 1, you must report to your employer on Form W-9 or a similar return. If you are a non-tax resident as defined under Rule 1, you must provide your employer with Form 8233 or Form W-8BEN, proving that you are a foreigner, or Form W-4, proving that your salary is withheld at the same rate as a tax resident or U.S. citizen. If you are a tax resident and you have income other than salary from sources in the United States (such as dividends and royalties), report to the withholding agent (usually the payer of the income) on Form W-9 or a similar return so that the agent will not withhold tax on the income at the 30% (or lower treaty rate). If you have such income as a non-tax resident, report to the withholding agent on Form W-8BEN so that the agent will withhold tax at the 30% (or lower treaty rate). However, if the income is effectively connected to U.S. trade or business, report on Form W-8ECI.

If you are an employee and your salary is subject to withholding tax, you will need to complete Form W-4. If the scholarship or grant is for past, present or future service and you do not claim tax treaty exemption (such as income entitled to tax treaty benefits) on Form 8233, you will also need to complete Form W-4. These are services you need to provide as an employee and are also conditions for receiving the scholarship or grant (or tuition fee relief). Non-tax residents must comply with special instructions in Notice 1392 when filling out Form W-4 for compensation received as an employee for providing personal services in the United States. Remuneration for reliance on personal services includes amounts paid as wages, salaries, fees, bonuses, commissions, compensatory scholarships, scholarship income and similar amounts paid to employees. To see if you need to increase or decrease withholding tax, use the IRS's Scholarship and Grant Withholding Tax Calculator. See Scholarship and Grant Withholding Tax to learn how to complete Form W-4 for non-service scholarships or scholarship grants from the United States.

If you are a domestic worker, your employer does not have to withhold income tax. However, you can voluntarily agree to withhold income tax by filing a Form W-4 with your employer. The agreement takes effect when your employer begins withholding tax. You or your employer can terminate the agreement by giving each other written notice.

If you are an agricultural worker with an H-2A visa, your employer will not be required to withhold income tax. However, your employer will only withhold income tax if you and your employer agree to do so. In this case, you must provide your employer with a properly completed Form W-4.

For information on how to claim this withholding tax exemption, see Income Eligible for Tax Treaty Advantages below. Salary paid to foreigners in American Samoa, Canada, Mexico, Puerto Rico or residents of the United States is exempt from withholding tax in the Virgin Islands. These exemptions are described in the following paragraphs.

Non-tax residents who are genuine residents of the U.S. Virgin Islands are not required to pay U.S. withholding tax on employment income during their temporary employment in the United States. This is because they pay income tax to the U.S. Virgin Islands. To avoid taxation on income in the United States, genuine residents of the U.S. Virgin Islands should write a letter in two copies to their employer stating that they are genuine residents of the U.S. Virgin Islands and expect to pay taxes on all income to the U.S. Virgin Islands.

If you receive a pension allocation from the United States, the amount is usually subject to a withholding tax rate of 30% (or a lower treaty rate).
