However, for the portion of the pension that accrues from services rendered in the United States after 1986, you may withhold tax at the progressive rate. You must complete Form W-8BEN or Form 8233 and hand it over to the withholding agent or payer before the income is paid or credited to your account.

You are liable to pay U.S. income tax on tips you receive for services provided in the United States during a year. You count them as taxable income. In addition, a grade-based deduction is made if the cumulative amount of tips received in a month while working for one employer exceeds $20 or more.

If there is no employee-employer relationship between you and the person you provide services to, your remuneration is subject to a 30% (or a lower treaty rate) withholding tax. However, if you engage in trade or business in the United States during the tax year, your personal services remuneration as an independent contractor (independent personal service) may be exempt from the necessary amount of withholding tax, in whole or in part, if you agree with the IRS.

If you are a non-resident foreign artist or athlete performing or participating in a sports event in the United States, you may enter into a central withholding agreement with the IRS to reduce your withholding tax. In any case, such an agreement will not reduce your withholding tax to less than your expected income tax liability. Use Form 13930 For non-resident foreign artists or athletes whose total U.S. income from the beginning of the year to the present date is at least $10,000, apply for a central withholding agreement. Form 13930 must be mailed to: Internal Revenue Service 24000 Avila Road, MS 6040 Laguna Niguel, CA 92677 For more information on how to apply for a central withholding agreement, see Form 13930.

If satisfied with this information, the IRS will determine a provisional amount of income tax for the current tax year on the total income effectively linked to your trade or business in the United States. If satisfied with the evidence, the Director or the Director's representative may consider ordinary and necessary business expenses. The Director or the Director's representative will send you a letter to the withholding tax agent stating the final amount of wages exempt from withholding tax and the amount that may be paid to you as a result of the exemption. You must provide two copies of the letter to the withholding tax agent and attach a copy of the letter to your income tax return for the tax year in which the exemption takes effect. For more information, see Bulletin 515.

If you are a salesperson for a multi-level marketing company whose withholding tax was wrong, submit a U.S. income tax return (Form 1040-NR or Form 1120-F); or, if you have filed a tax return, file a tax refund claim (Form 1040-X or amended Form 1120-F) to recover the amount wrongly withheld. You must also include supporting information in your U.S. income tax return or tax refund claim, including but not limited to the following items. A copy of Form W-2, Form 1042-S or Form 1099 to prove the amount of withholding tax. A statement that income declared on Form W-2, Form 1042-S or Form 1099 is not subject to U.S. tax. A statement that lists all dates of entry and exit from the U.S. during the tax year. If the salary is a multi-year salary, the statement must list all dates of entry and exit from the U.S. in each tax year to which the remuneration is attributed. A copy of any document or record showing the number of days you actually stayed in the U.S. during the year listed. A statement that includes: (a) the total number of days (or less than one day, if applicable) of personal services performed in the U.S. related to recruiting, training and supporting lower-level salespersons; and (b) the total number of days (or less than one day, if applicable) of personal services performed globally related to recruiting, training and supporting lower-level salespersons. Any other relevant documents or records that prove your withholding tax claim was wrong.

If you are a green card holder and your withholding tax on social security benefits is wrong because you have an address abroad, you can get a refund from the IRS. To receive a refund, you must file Form 1040 or 1040-SR. To determine if you are eligible for a refund, please send your tax return to: Department of the Treasury Internal Revenue Service Center Austin, TX 73301 You must also include the following on Form 1040 or 1040-SR. Form SSA-1042S, Social Security Statement. Green Card Copy. Signed statement containing the following: "The SSA should not have withheld income tax from my social security benefits because I am a lawful U.S. permanent resident and my green card has been neither revoked nor administratively or judicially determined to have been abandoned. I am filing a U.S. income tax return for the tax year as a resident alien reporting all of my worldwide income. I have not claimed benefits for the tax year under an income tax treaty as the resident of a country other than the United States. I will file a U.S. income tax return for the current tax year as a resident under the tax law. I have not claimed benefits under an income tax treaty as the resident of a country other than the United States.

Other income subject to a 30% withholding tax usually includes fixed or determined income such as interest (except for interest on portfolios), dividends, pensions and annuities, and the proceeds of certain sales and transactions, as discussed in Chapter 4.
The following are special rules for withholding tax on income from joint ventures, scholarships and grants.

If you are a foreign partner in a U.S. or foreign associate, the associate will withhold tax on your share of effectively linked taxable income (ECTI) from the associate. Your associate may be able to reduce your withholding tax on your ECTI share by taking into account certain partner-level deductions. Generally, you must file Form 8804-C for this purpose. For more information, see the explanation on Form 8804-C. The withholding tax rate on your effectively linked income share is usually the maximum tax rate (37%) under Section 1. However, if you provide the associate with the appropriate documentation, the associate will withhold tax at the maximum rate applicable to the particular type of income allocated to you. Long-term capital gains are an example of a particular type of income to which the maximum tax rate applies. Withholding tax is reported as a tax benefit on Form 1040-NR in 2023. The associate will provide you with a statement on Form 8805 showing the withholding tax. A publicly traded associate will withhold tax on the actual allocation of the effective link. In this case, the associate will provide you with a statement on Form 1042-S.

If you are a direct or indirect foreign partner of a U.S. or foreign affiliate that engages (or is deemed to engage) in trade or business in the United States and you dispose of interests in the proceeds directly or indirectly, the assignee will normally withhold and pay to the IRS a tax on your behalf equivalent to 10% of the sales income for transfers after 2017. The rules for withholding and paying over this amount are similar to those for the sale of U.S. real estate. You will receive a Form 8288-A reflecting the amount withheld, and you can then report that amount as a tax benefit on Form 1040-NR as you owe tax on the proceeds. You may be able to provide the assignee with certain information to reduce or eliminate the withholding tax. For example, if the uncertainty clause of the U.S. tax code applies to all the proceeds of the transfer, the assignee does not need to withhold tax when you provide notice describing the application of the uncertainty clause. If you are an assignee who failed to withhold tax, the joint venture must withhold tax under section 1446(f)(4) on the basis of the amount of the tax you did not withhold (plus interest, if applicable).

If you are a non-resident foreign student, or hold an F, J, M, or Q visa, and you receive a grant or scholarship from the United States that is not fully tax-exempt, the withholding tax agent (usually the scholarship taxpayer) will withhold tax at 14% (or the lower agreed rate) of the taxable portion of the grant or scholarship as a non-service payment. However, if you are not a degree candidate and the grant does not meet certain requirements, withholding tax will be at 30% (or the lower agreed rate). Any portion of the scholarship or scholarship as a service payment is subject to progressive withholding tax, as discussed in the section on Salary Withholding Tax above.
Your withholding agent may opt to use an alternative procedure by asking you to complete Form W-4. See below for information on items that may reduce withholding tax.

Fill out the corresponding line of Form W-4. Sign and date the form and then give it to the withholding tax agent. If you file Form W-4 to reduce or eliminate withholding tax on your scholarship or major, you must file an annual U.S. income tax return to receive any deductions declared on that form. If you reside in the U.S. for more than one tax year, you must attach a statement to your annual Form W-4 stating that you have filed a U.S. income tax return for the previous year. If you have not been in the U.S. long enough to meet the requirement to file a tax return, you must attach a statement to your Form W-4 stating that you will file a U.S. income tax return as required. Once the withholding tax agent has accepted your Form W-4, the scholarship or grant will be withheld at the progressive rate of taxation applicable to your salary. The total income will be reduced by the amount applicable on Form W-4 and the remaining withholding tax will be calculated. You will receive a Form 1042-S from the withholding tax agent (usually the scholarship taxpayer) showing the total amount of taxable scholarship or grant less any withholding tax benefits, rates and amounts of withholding tax. Use this form to complete your annual U.S. income tax return. For more information, go to IRS.gov/FormW4.

If a tax treaty between the United States and your country of residence provides an exemption or lower rate of taxation for certain income items, you should notify the payer of the income (the withholding tax agent) of your foreign status for the exemption from withholding tax. In general, you can do this by filing Form W-8BEN or Form 8233 with the withholding tax agent.

If you are performing personal services as an employee or independent contractor and you are entitled to a withholding tax exemption under a tax treaty, give Form 8233 to the withholding tax agents who provide the amount. When you file Form 8233, the withholding tax agent still has to withhold tax from your income. This is because the factors on which the exemption is based may not be determined until after the end of the tax year. In this case, you must file Form 1040-NR to recover any withholding tax and provide the IRS with proof that you are entitled to the exemption.

Students, teachers and researchers must attach the appropriate declaration as shown in Appendix A (for students) or Appendix B (for teachers and researchers) at the end of this publication to Form 8233 and submit it to the withholding tax agent. For the agreements listed in the Appendix, add a declaration in the same format as for other agreements. If you receive a scholarship or grant from the same withholding tax agent as well as income from personal services, use Form 8233 to apply for withholding tax exemption under the tax agreement for both types of income.

Income from concerts, boxing promotions and other entertainment or sports events paid to non-tax residents or foreign companies (or television or other income) is subject to withholding tax at the maximum rate of 30%, unless the IRS has been specifically notified otherwise by the withholding tax agent. Depending on the calendar year in which the total U.S. income is earned, a withholding tax deduction can be applied for using Form 13930. Even if the tax treaty provides that the income is tax-exempt, a withholding tax may still be required. One reason for this is that partial or total tax exemption is usually based on factors that are not determined until the end of the tax year. We temporarily exempt the income requirement for applying for CWA. Form 13930-A is currently unavailable. Individuals whose income is less than $10,000 can apply for CWA using Form 13930. For more information on how to apply for CWA, see Form 13930. For more information, see IRS.gov/Individuals/International-Taxpayers/Central-Withholding-Agreements..

If the buyer or a qualified substitute actually knows, or is notified by the seller or the buyer's agent (or substitute) that the evidence under (3) and (4) is false, the buyer must disregard it. This also applies to the statements of the qualified substitute under (4).

The buyer must report and pay the withholding tax within 20 days of the transfer. The form is filed with the IRS together with copies A and B of the Form 8288-A. If the statement is complete and contains your tax identification number (TIN), copy B of the statement will be returned to you (the seller) after being stamped by the IRS. You must submit copy B with your tax return to receive the withholding tax benefit.

If you are an employee working in the United States, in most cases you must pay social security and health insurance taxes. Your tax payments contribute to your insurance under the social security system. Social security provides retirement, survivor and disability benefits, and Medicare benefits for individuals who meet certain eligibility requirements. In most cases, the first $160,200 of your taxable salary received for services rendered in the United States in 2023 is subject to social security taxes. All taxable salaries are subject to health insurance taxes. Your employer deducts these taxes from each payroll payment. Even if you are not expected to qualify for social security or health insurance benefits, your employer must deduct these taxes. If you have multiple employers and the amount deducted from your total salary in 2023 exceeds $9,932.40, you can claim a tax benefit for excess social security taxes on your income tax return. If any of the employers deducts more than $9,932.40, you cannot claim a tax benefit for that amount. Invite your employer to refund the excess. If your employer does not refund the excess, you can file a tax refund using Form 843. In general, U.S. social security and health insurance taxes apply to wages earned for services rendered in the United States as an employee, regardless of the employee's or employer's citizenship or place of residence. In limited circumstances, these taxes apply to wages rendered outside the United States. Your employer should be able to tell you whether social security and health insurance taxes apply to your salary. If there is no tax payable, you cannot voluntarily pay.

There are no special provisions for non-tax residents regarding additional health insurance taxes. Additional health insurance taxes are payable on wages, RRTA benefits and self-employment income that exceed the applicable threshold. Your employer is responsible for withholding an additional 0.9% (0.009) of health insurance taxes on wages or RRTA benefits paid to you in excess of $200,000 in the calendar year. If you intend to file a consolidated return and you expect your and your spouse's individual wages to not exceed $200,000, but your wages and self-employment income will total more than $250,000, you may need to apply for additional withholding and/or estimated tax payments on Form W-4. If you file Form 1040-NR, you must pay additional health insurance taxes if: if you are married, your total wages and self-employment income exceeds $125,000 (you ticked the box for separate taxation after marriage at the top of page 1 of Form 1040-NR); if you are single or a qualifying surviving spouse, your total wages and self-employment income exceeds $200,000 (you ticked the single or qualifying surviving spouse box at the top of page 1 of Form 1040-NR).

Generally, services that you provide temporarily in the United States as a non-tax resident under section 101(a)(15)(F), (J), (M) or (Q) of the Immigration and Nationality Act are not covered by a social security program if the services are provided for the purpose of your entry into the United States. This means that no social security or health insurance tax is deducted from the wages you earn for providing these services. These types of services are very limited and generally only include school work, practice training, and economically difficult employment. If you are considered a tax resident as discussed in Chapter 1, even if your non-immigrant classification ("F," "J," "M," or "Q") remains unchanged, social security or health insurance tax is deducted from the wages you earn for providing these services. Services provided by the spouse or minor child of a non-immigrant alien with a "F-2," "J-2," "M-2," or "Q-3" classification are not covered by social security.

If you are a non-tax resident who enters the United States temporarily as a student, you are generally not allowed to work for wages or salaries or to engage in professional activities in the United States. In some cases, students who enter the United States as "F-1," "M-1," or "J-1" are entitled to work. Social Security and Health Insurance taxes are not deducted from wages unless the student is considered a tax resident. Any student who is enrolled in a school and attends regular classes is exempt from Social Security and Health Insurance taxes for services provided by the school. The U.S. Citizenship and Immigration Services (USCIS) allows students with "F-1" status to work on campus without replacing a U.S. resident. "Work on campus" means work performed on campus. Work performed on campus includes work at an educationally related location outside the campus. Work on campus under the terms of a scholarship, grant or assistantship grant is considered part of the student's full-time study program and is authorized by USCIS. Unless the student is considered a tax resident, social security and health insurance taxes are not deducted from wages.

The exchange visitor is temporarily entering the United States under section 101(a)(15)(J) of the Immigration and Nationality Act. Unless the exchange visitor is considered a tax-defined resident, no social security and health insurance tax is withheld from the exchange visitor's remuneration for services that have been granted a work permit and have or received a sponsorship authorization. If the services provided by the exchange visitor are not considered to be for the purpose of the visitor's entry into the United States, then social security and health insurance taxes are withheld from the salary unless the salary is exempt from tax under the national taxation regulations. Under section 101(a)(15)(Q) of the Immigration and Nationality Act, non-tax-defined residents who are temporarily entering the United States as participants in an international cultural exchange program are exempt from social security and health insurance taxes. The employer must be a foreigner who is an applicant for a "Q" visa. Unless the foreigner is considered a tax-defined resident, no social security and health insurance taxes are withheld from the salary.

Agricultural workers who enter the United States temporarily on an H-2A visa are exempt from social security and health insurance taxes on the remuneration they receive for the provision of services related to the H-2A visa.

The United States has social security agreements (commonly referred to as totalization agreements) with foreign countries to coordinate social security coverage and taxation for workers who have completed part or all of their careers in one of these countries. Under these agreements, double coverage and double contribution (taxation) for the same work is eliminated. These agreements usually ensure that social security taxes (including self-employment taxes) are paid to only one country. For a list of current international social security agreements, see SSA.gov/international/status.html. As agreements with other countries come into effect, they will be published on this website. For more information on international social security agreements, see SSA.gov/international/totalization_agreements.html.

Generally, under these agreements, you are only required to pay social security taxes in the country where you work. However, if you are temporarily posted to the United States for the same employer and your salary is usually subject to social security taxes in both countries, most agreements provide that you are only covered by the social security system of the country from which you are posted. To ensure that your salary is subject only to foreign social security taxes and is exempt from U.S. social security taxes (including health insurance taxes) under the agreement, you or your employer should obtain a certificate of insurance from the appropriate foreign agency. This is usually the same agency to which you or your employer pay foreign social security taxes. The foreign agency will be able to tell you what information they require to issue the certificate. Your employer should keep a copy of the certificate, as it may be required to explain why you are exempt from U.S. social security taxes. Only wages paid on or after the effective date of the agreement are exempt from U.S. social security taxes.

Under most agreements, self-employed persons are covered by the social security system of their country of residence. However, under some agreements, you may be exempt from paying U.S. self-employment taxes if you temporarily transfer your business to or from the United States. If you believe that your self-employment income is only subject to U.S. self-employment tax and is exempt from foreign social security taxes, you should obtain insurance proof from the Social Security Administration. Please refer to the link in the note above. This proof will confirm that you are exempt from paying foreign social security taxes. To confirm that your self-employment income is only subject to foreign social security tax and is exempt from U.S. self-employment tax, you should obtain insurance proof from the foreign equivalent.

If your adjusted total income in 2023 exceeds $150,000 (or $75,000 if you filed as married separately in 2024), and you are not a farmer or fisherman, use 110% (1.10) instead of 100% (1.00) in (2) above. If you do not file a 2023 return, item (2) does not apply.

If you filed your 2023 return on Form 1040-NR and anticipate that your 2024 income and total deductions will be nearly the same, you should use your 2023 return as a guide to fill out the Estimated Taxes worksheet in the Form 1040-ES (NR) Notes. If you do not file your 2023 return, or if your income, deductions, or credits will be different in 2024, you must estimate these amounts.

If your tax return is not filed in a calendar year, your deadline is the 15th of the 4th, 6th and 9th month of your fiscal year, and the 1st month of the following fiscal year. If any date is a Saturday, Sunday or a public holiday, use the next day (not Saturday, Sunday or a public holiday).

Even if you do not have to pay estimated tax in April or June, your circumstances may change and you will have to pay estimated tax at a later date. This will happen if you earn additional income, or if any of your deductions are reduced or eliminated.

If, after you have paid your estimated tax, you find that your estimated tax has increased or decreased significantly due to changes in income or exemptions, you should adjust the remaining estimated tax. For this, see the explanation of Form 1040-ES (NR) and Bulletin 505.

The Taxpayer Certainty and Disaster Tax Relief Act of 2019 and the Taxpayer Certainty and Disaster Tax Relief Act of 2020 extend the special rules and tax provisions for reporting disaster-related qualifying personal accident losses. Qualifying disaster losses for these tax years can be reported on Form 4684. See Qualifying Disaster Losses below for more information. If applicable, you may be required to file Form 1040-X, a modified tax return, to report these benefits on your 2018, 2019 and/or 2020 tax returns. Form 1040-X can be found at IRS.gov/Form1040X. Amendments prior to Form 4684 can be found at IRS.gov/Form4684. See How to Report Losses on Form 1040-X below. Limitations on Personal Accident and Theft Losses. In the 2018 to 2025 tax years, for individuals, personal accident or theft losses to property not related to trade or business or transactions are deductible only if the loss is caused by a federally declared disaster. Theft losses in transactions for profit are still deductible. Unless a qualifying disaster loss, personal accident and theft losses caused by a federally declared disaster are subject to a maximum of $100 per accident.

This booklet explains the tax treatment of accidents, thefts and losses of deposits. An accident occurs when your property is damaged by a disaster such as a storm, fire, car accident or similar event. Theft occurs when someone steals your property. Loss of deposits occurs when your financial institution becomes insolvent or bankrupt. This booklet covers the following topics. Definitions of accidents, thefts and losses of deposits. How to calculate the amount of your gains or losses. How to treat insurance and other compensation funds you receive. Deduction limits. When and how to report accidents or thefts. Special provisions for disaster losses.

Federal accident loss is a loss of personal injury or theft of personal property caused by a federally declared disaster. The accident must have occurred in the state that received the federal disaster declaration. If you suffered a federal accident, you are eligible to claim the accident loss deduction. If you suffered an accident or theft of personal property caused by a non-federally declared disaster, it is not a federal accident loss and you cannot claim the accident loss deduction unless an exception applies. Theft losses from transactions made for profit are still deductible. See the Warning section below for details.

Eligible disaster losses include losses of personal property caused by: major disasters declared by the President under section 401 of the Stafford Act of 2016; Hurricane Harvey; Tropical Storm Harvey; Hurricane Elma; and the California wildfires of 2017 and 2018; major disasters declared by the President under section 401 of the Stafford Act of 2018 that occurred before December 21, 2019 and continued until January 19, 2020 (except those losses attributable to the California wildfires of January 2018 that have been exempted); and major disasters declared by the President that occurred between January 1, 2020 and February 10, 2025.

Property losses due to gradual deterioration cannot be deducted as accidental losses. This is because the damage is caused by a cause or normal process that occurs steadily, rather than by an unexpected event. Examples of damage due to gradual deterioration are: Continuous damage to buildings due to normal wind and weather conditions. Deterioration and damage to water heaters resulting in cracks. However, rust and water-logged damage to carpets and curtains due to cracks in water heaters do indeed constitute accidents. Most accidents are caused by drought. To be deductible, drought-related losses must usually occur in the course of trade or business or in a transaction for profit. Damage to rice or wheat by ants or moths. Damage or destruction of trees, shrubs or other plants by fungi, diseases, insects, worms or similar pests. However, sudden damage to rice due to accidental or unusual beetle or other insect infestation may result in accidental losses.

If you choose not to follow this special follow-up guide, you must comply with all the rules applicable to accidental loss deductions and you must complete lines 1 to 9 as described in Form 4684. For example, this means that you must prove that the damage, destruction or loss of property was caused by an identifiable event as defined in Accidents above. In addition, you must have evidence that shows that the loss is appropriately deductible in the tax year you report and not in other years. See When to Report Profits and Losses below. The amount of the loss reported. See What to include in the proof of loss below. There is no claim with a reasonable expectation of recovery of any part of the loss. See When to Report Profits and Losses below.

If you choose to follow this special provision, please complete Part A of Form 4684 as described below. If you determine and report the loss as described below, the IRS will not object to you treating the damage caused by corrosive drywall as an accidental loss or loss of profit.
Enter insurance or other compensation you received (including amounts obtained through lawsuits). If not, enter -0-.

Enter the amount you paid to repair the damage to your home and appliances caused by the corrosive drywall. Enter only the amount you paid to restore the house to its pre-damage state. Do not enter the cost of repairs or additions to your home that increased the value of your home beyond the value before the loss of the house. If you replaced appliances rather than repairing them, enter the lesser of the following: The current cost of replacing the original appliances, or the base value of the original appliances (usually the cost).

If line 8 is less than or equal to line 3, you cannot report the accident loss deduction using this special follow-up guide. If you have a pending compensation claim (or you intend to seek compensation), you may have income or additional deductions in a later tax year based on the actual compensation received. See the section below on the compensation received after deduction of losses and the deductions for compensation.

If the losses incurred on your business property or income-generating property exceed the gains from such property, set off your business accident loss against the total gains from your business and income-generating property. Report the net gain or loss as ordinary gain or loss on Form 4797. If you do not need to file Form 4797, on your tax return, simply enter the net loss on the line determined from Form 4797 (for individuals filing Form 1040 or Form 1040-SR, Schedule 1 (Form 1040) line 4). Next to that line, enter "Form 4684" (Form 4684). The individual reports the loss of income-generating property on Schedule A (Form 1040). If the loss of business and income-generating property is less than or equal to the gains from such property, report the net amount on Form 4797. Depending on whether you have other transactions, you may also need to report the gains on Schedule D (Form 1040).

If the damaged or stolen property is depreciable property held for more than one year, you may have to treat all or part of the proceeds as ordinary income within the allowed or permissible depreciation limits. You will use Part Three of Form 4797 to calculate the ordinary income portion of the proceeds. For more information on the rules for recovery, see Depreciation Recovery in Chapter 3 of Bulletin 544.

If you have an accident or theft loss, you must reduce your property base through any insurance or other compensation you receive and any deductible losses. The result is the adjusted base of your property. If you make any of the above adjustments to the base, the cost of repairing the property to its pre-accident condition increases your adjusted base. You cannot use any eligible relief payments to increase the adjusted base of your property (discussed in the section on Disaster Area Losses above). See the Adjusted Base amount in Bulletin 551 for more information on adjusted bases.

If your accident or theft loss deduction results in your deduction for the year exceeding your income for the year, you may have a net operating loss (NOL). Usually, you can use the NOL to reduce your tax for the following year. You may not have to leave business and still have a net operating loss from accident or theft loss. For more information, see the explanation on Form 172.

Once you have received all your payroll and income statements (Form W-2, Form W-2G, Form 1099-R, Form 1099-MISC, Form 1099-NEC, etc.), unemployment benefit statements (in mail or digital format) or other government payment statements (Form 1099-G), and interest, dividend and pension statements from banks and investment companies (Form 1099), you have several options for filling out and filing your tax return. You can complete your tax return yourself, check if you qualify for free tax return services, or hire a tax professional to file your tax return for you.

For accessibility information, please call 833-690-0598. The Accessibility Helpline can answer questions about current and future accessible products and services, which can be provided in alternative media formats (e.g., Braille, large print, audio, etc.).

Through your online account, you can access a variety of information to help you through the tax filing season. You can get your rss, view your most recently filed returns, and get your total adjusted income. Go to IRS.gov/Account to create or access your online account.

This means that your refund is transferred directly to your financial account, securely and electronically. Direct deposits also avoid the risk of a lost, stolen, damaged or cancelled check being returned to IRS. 80% of taxpayers use direct deposits to get their refund. If you do not have a bank account, visit IRS.gov/DirectDeposit for more information on where to find a bank or credit union that can open an online account.

Check out your options for filling and filing your tax returns online or in your local community (if you are eligible) and see what they include. Direct File. Direct File is a permanent option for filing your personal federal tax return directly and securely online for free. Direct File is an option for taxpayers with relatively simple tax returns in participating states to file certain types of income and claim certain credits and deductions. While Direct File is not used for filing state taxes, if you reside in a participating state, Direct File will guide you through the use of state-supported tools that can be used to complete and file state taxes for free. For more information, program updates and frequently asked questions, visit IRS.gov/DirectFile. Free File. The program allows you to use software or free file forms to complete and file federal personal income tax for free. However, free file may not provide state tax returns. Visit IRS.gov/FreeFile to see if you qualify for the free online federal tax return, electronic tax return and direct deposit or payment options. Go to IRS.gov/VITA to download the IRS2Go app for free, or call 800-906-9887 for information about free tax return services. TCE. Tax Counseling Services for Seniors (TCE) program provides free tax assistance for all taxpayers, especially taxpayers over 60. TCE volunteers are dedicated to answering questions about pensions and retirement specific to seniors.

IRS does not contact taxpayers via email, text messages (including shortened links), telephone or social media channels to request or verify personal or financial information. This includes requests for personal identification numbers (PINs), passwords or similar information for credit cards, bank or other financial accounts. Visit IRS.gov/IdentityTheft, the IRS Identity Theft Center website, for information on identity theft and data security for taxpayers, tax professionals and businesses. If your Social Security Number is lost or stolen, or you suspect you are a victim of tax-related identity theft, you can learn what steps to take. Obtain an Identity Protecting Personal Identification Number (IP PIN). An IP PIN is a set of six digit numbers assigned to a taxpayer to help prevent fraudulent use of their Social Security Number on federal income tax returns. When you have an IP PIN, you can prevent others from using your Social Security Number to file a tax return. For more information, visit IRS.gov/IPPIN.

U.S. taxes must be paid to the IRS in U.S. dollars. Digital assets are not accepted. Go to IRS.gov/Payments for information on making payments using any of the following methods. IRS Direct Pay: Pay your personal tax bill or tax assessment directly from your check or savings account, without additional charges. Debit or credit card or digital wallet: Choose an approved payment processor, pay online or over the phone. Electronic Withdrawal: Provides payment arrangements when filing federal taxes using tax filing software or through a tax professional. Electronic Federal Tax Payment System (EFTPS): This is the best option for businesses. Registration is required. Check or money order: Mail your payment to the address listed on the notice or notice. Cash: You can pay your taxes in cash at participating retailers. On-the-day wire transfer: You may be able to make on-the-day wire transfers from your financial institution. Contact your financial institution for the feasibility, cost and timeframe.

Visit IRS.gov/Payments to learn more about your options. Apply for an Online Payment Agreement (IRS.gov/OPA) to meet your tax obligations in monthly instalments (if you are unable to pay your taxes in full on the day). You will receive a notification of approval of your agreement immediately after completing the online process. Use the Tax Offering Pre-qualification to see if you can settle your tax obligations at a lower amount than your accrued tax. For more information on tax offer pre-qualification, visit IRS.gov/OIC.

You can use the attached form LEP (Form 1040), Request for Change of Language Preference, to indicate that you would like to receive notices, letters, or other written communications from the IRS in another language. You may not immediately receive written communications in the language you requested. The IRS' commitment to LEP taxpayers is part of a multi-year schedule to provide translations starting in 2023. You will continue to receive communications, including notices and letters in English, until they are translated into your preferred language.

TAS can help you solve problems that you cannot solve with the IRS. Be sure to try to solve your problem with the IRS first, but if you can't, go to TAS. Our service is free. TAS helps all taxpayers (and their representatives), including individuals, corporations and tax-exempt organizations. If your IRS problem is causing you financial difficulties, if you have tried but failed to solve your problem with the IRS, or if you feel that the IRS system, process or procedure is not working properly, you may be eligible for TAS assistance. For assistance on general tax topics at any time, visit www.TaxpayerAdvocate.IRS.gov. This website can help you solve common tax issues and situations, such as what to do if you make an error on your tax return or receive an IRS notification. TAS is dedicated to solving large-scale (systemic) problems that affect many taxpayers. You can report system problems at www.IRS.gov/SAMS. (Please make sure you do not include any personally identifiable information.)
If the receipt of money or property by fraud or false statement is illegal under state or local law, the act is not considered theft.

If the shares were purchased on the open market and the market value of the shares fell as a result of accounting fraud or other unlawful misconduct by the senior officer or director who issued the shares, you cannot deduct the fall in the market value of the shares as a theft loss. However, if the shares are sold or exchanged or become completely worthless, you can deduct it as a capital loss on Schedule D (Form 1040). For more information on the sale of shares, worthless shares and capital losses, see Chapter 4 of Bulletin 550.

You can choose to deduct your deposit losses as accidental losses in any year, as long as you can reasonably estimate how much you lost in that year at an insolvent or bankrupt financial institution. Usually, this option is made on your tax return for that year and applies to all your deposit losses in that particular financial institution in that year. If you treat the loss as an accidental loss, you cannot treat the equivalent loss as a non-business bad debt when it becomes actually worthless. However, you can deduct a non-business bad debt for any amount in excess of the estimated amount you deduct as an accidental or ordinary debt. Once you have made your choice, you cannot change it without the permission of the IRS.
The deductions you choose for your deposit losses determine how you report your losses. See Table 1.
For more information, see Regulation on Deposits in Insolvent or Bankrupt Financial Institutions in Law No. 550.

If you recovered an amount deducted as a loss in a previous year, you may have to include the recovered amount in your income for that year. If any part of the original deduction did not reduce your tax payments in the previous year, you do not have to include the recovered amount in your income. For more information, see the section on Recovery Matters in Law 525.

For accidental losses, you should be able to provide all of the following proofs: that you own the property, or if you rent the property from someone else, that you are contractually liable for the owner's damages; the type of accident (car accident, fire, storm, etc.) and the time it occurred; the loss is a direct result of the accident; there is a reasonable expectation of compensation; and there is a claim for compensation.

If you receive insurance compensation or other types of compensation, you must deduct that amount when calculating your loss. To the extent that you receive the money, you have not suffered an accident or theft loss. If a claim is made in the year the accident occurred and there is a reasonable prospect of compensation, the loss does not exist until you are reasonably certain that you will receive such compensation. If you expect to receive compensation for part or all of your loss, you must deduct the expected compensation when calculating your loss. Even if you receive the money only in the next tax year, you must reduce the amount of the loss. See above for the content of compensation money received after deduction of loss.

If your property is insured, you should file a claim for your loss with the insurance company in a timely manner. If you do not file an insurance claim, you cannot deduct the entire amount not recovered as accident or theft loss, and you can only deduct for the part of the loss that is outside the coverage. Parts of the loss that are not usually covered (for example, the exemption) are not bound by this rule.

The most common type of compensation is insurance compensation for your property that has been stolen or damaged. Other types of compensation are discussed below. In addition, see the explanation of Form 4684.

If you receive cash gifts as a victim of a disaster that do not count as income and you have no restrictions on how you use the money, you do not have to deduct these non-income cash gifts from your accidental loss. This applies even if you use the money to pay for repairs to property damaged in the disaster.
You do not have to deduct the insurance premiums received to cover your living expenses from your accident loss in any of the following cases: You are unable to use your main home due to an accident.

Include the taxable portion of the insurance payments in your income in the year you can reuse the main home, or later, include the taxable portion of the insurance payments in your income in the year you receive the insurance payments.

Do not deduct loan funds used to repair or replace property for which you have declared an accident deduction from your accident loss. If your federal loan is cancelled (full relief), see Full Relief Federal Loans below, which is discussed in Disaster Losses.

If you use the expected compensation amount to calculate your accident or theft loss, you may need to make adjustments in the tax year in which you actually received the compensation. This section describes the adjustments you may need to make. If you have made a payment to repair damage to a private home caused by a deteriorated concrete foundation, and have applied for a deduction on your original or amended federal personal income tax return, and the Connecticut Foundation Solutions Incentive Corporation (CFSIC) has paid you (or a contractor on your behalf) a compensation, you must include some or all of the payments in your total income. See also Announcement 2020-5, 2020-19 I.R.B.796 (available at IRS.gov/irb/2020-19IRB#ANN-2020-5).

If you subsequently receive compensation in excess of your expectations, you may need to include the additional compensation in your income for the year in which you received it after you filed the deduction for loss. However, if any part of the original deduction did not reduce your tax for the previous year, do not include the portion of the compensation in your income. You do not need to recalculate your tax for the year in which you filed the deduction. Refer to the Refunds section of Bulletin 525 for information on how much of the additional compensation to include in your income.
If the compensation you receive in the future is exactly what you expected, you do not have to include any compensation in your income, nor can you deduct any additional losses.

You can deduct accidental or theft losses of inventory, including items you hold for sale to customers, in two ways: by correctly reporting your inventory at the beginning and end of the period, and by deducting the loss by increasing the cost of the goods sold. Do not report this loss again as an accidental or theft loss. If you suffer a loss due to the increase in the cost of the goods sold, include any insurance or other compensation you receive for the loss in total income. Alternatively, deduct the loss individually. If you do this individually, exclude the affected inventory item from the cost of sales by adjusting downward the inventory or purchases at the beginning of the period. Reduce the loss by the compensation you receive. Do not include the compensation in total income. If you do not receive compensation before the end of the year, you must not report the loss.

If you are held liable for accidental damage to the rental property, your loss is the amount you have to pay to repair the property less any insurance or other compensation you have received or are expected to receive.

The recovery of stolen property means that your property is returned to you after it has been stolen. If you recover the property after deducting the loss from theft, you must recalculate your loss using the lesser of the following: the adjusted base value of the property (as described below) or the amount of the FMV decreased between the time the property was stolen and the time it was recovered. Use this amount to recalculate the total loss in the year of the loss. If your recalculated loss is less than the loss you have deducted, you generally need to report the difference as income in the year of the recovery. However, report only the amount of the loss that reduces your taxable income. For more information on reporting amounts, see the section on Recovery Matters in Bulletin 525.
You can use the valuation you used to obtain federal loans (or federal loan guarantees) due to a federally declared disaster to determine the amount of your disaster losses.

The cost of repairing damaged property is not part of the accident loss. The cost of cleaning up after an accident is not included. However, you can use the cost of cleaning up or repairing after an accident as a basis for calculating the fair market value decrease if you meet all of the following conditions. Repairs have actually been completed. Repairs are necessary to restore the property to its pre-accident state. Repairs are not expensive. Repairs only deal with the damaged part. The value of the repaired property does not decrease as a result of repairs compared to its pre-accident value.

The cost of restoring the landscape to its original state after an accident may indicate a decrease in fair market value. You may be able to calculate your loss by calculating your expenses for: removal of destroyed or damaged trees and shrubs, minus any residual value you receive; pruning and other measures taken to protect damaged trees and shrubs; replanting to restore the property to its approximate value before the accident; and the cost of rebuilding the property.

You can use the retail values listed in the book, adjusted for factors such as mileage and condition, to determine the value of your car. These prices are not official, but they may help determine the value and suggest relative prices to compare with current sales and products in your area.

Losses determined through the safe harbor method must be deducted from the value of any repairs provided to you by a third party free of charge (for example, work done by volunteers or through donations). In addition, any insurance, compensation or other compensation you receive must be deducted from your loss.
Include a statement on Form 4684 stating that you used the 2018-08 Tax Follow-up Guide to determine the amount of your accidental loss.

Residential property for personal use is usually property owned by an individual who has suffered accidental loss, including improvements, and includes at least one personal residence. If any part of the personal residence is used as rental property or includes a home office for trade or business or for profit transactions, it is not a personal residence. For more detailed information, see Tax Follow-up Guide 2018-08. The following is a list of safe harbor approaches for personal residential property, provided through Tax Follow-up Guide 2018-08. Estimate repair cost law. Minimum law. Insurance law. Federally Declared Disaster Act — Contractor Safe Harbor. Federally Declared Disaster Act — Disaster Loan Valuation.

The Safe Harbor method allows you to calculate the decrease in the fair market value of your personal home property based on the estimated loss described in reports prepared by the homeowner or the flood insurance company. These reports must list the estimated loss you suffered as a result of damage or destruction of your property.

If the loss occurred in a disaster area and was caused by a federally declared disaster, you can use the Contractor Safe Harbor method or the Disaster Loan Assessment method. Under the Contractor Safe Harbor method, you can use the repair contract price specified in a contract prepared by an independent and licensed contractor to determine the amount of the fair market value decrease of your personal residential property. The Safe Harbor method does not apply to you unless you are bound by a binding contract signed by you and the contractor, and the contractor has set out an item-by-item cost for restoring your personal residential property to the pre-accident state.

Under the disaster loan assessment safe harbor method, you can use an assessment of your estimated loss in a federally declared disaster to determine the amount of the decrease in the fair market value of your personal residential property, if you are prepared to obtain a federally funded loan or loan guarantee from the federal government.

Personal property generally includes tangible personal property owned by a person and not used for trade or business that is lost in an accident or theft. Personal property does not include items that maintain or increase their value over time or certain other types of property. For more detailed information, see Tax Follow-up Guide 2018-08.

The cost of protecting your property against accidents or theft is not part of your loss from accidents or theft. The amount you spend on insurance or the cost of a house to resist storms is not part of your loss. If the property is a business property, these costs can be deducted as business expenses. If you make permanent improvements to your property to protect it from accidents or theft, add the cost of these improvements to your property base. The cost of building a dike to prevent flooding is an example.

Do not consider emotional value when determining your loss. If your family goods, heirlooms or souvenirs are damaged, destroyed or stolen, your loss must be calculated on the basis of their FMV, and limited to the amount of your adjusted property base.

Your property is not taken into account for depreciation due to its location in or near an area where an accident occurred or is likely to occur again. Your property is only considered lost if it has actually suffered accidental damage. However, if your home is located in a federally declared disaster area, see the discussion below on disaster area losses.

Photos taken after an accident will help to show the condition and value of the property after it was damaged. Photos showing the condition of the house after it has been repaired, repaired or replaced may also be helpful. Valuation is used to calculate the amount of decrease in fair market value due to an accident or theft. For information on valuation, see Valuation above, which is listed under Calculating decrease in fair market value – items to consider. Photographs and valuation costs used to prove the value and condition of property damaged by an accident are not part of your loss. They are costs for determining your tax liability. In the tax years 2018 to 2025, they will no longer be deducted as a miscellaneous item.

If you have accrued a profit that exceeds your loss, deduct your loss from your profit. The difference is considered a capital gain and must be reported on Schedule D (Form 1040). The 10% rule does not apply to your profit. If your loss is not due to a federally declared disaster, see the Notes on Form 4684 for the explanation of Row 14.
When calculating the loss of your personal property, all repairs (e.g., building and garden trees and repaired buildings) must be taken into account, as well as the land on which they are located.

When the property is used partly for personal purposes and partly for business or income-generating purposes, the deduction for accidental loss or theft of the personal use part and the business or income-generating part must be calculated separately. You must calculate each loss separately, because the loss attributable to these two uses is calculated in two different ways. When calculating each loss, allocate the total cost or base, the fair market value before and after the accidental loss or theft, and the insurance or other compensation between the business and the personal use property. The $100 rule and the 10% rule apply only to accidental loss or theft of the property used for personal purposes.

The amount you receive includes any funds plus the value of any property you receive, less any costs you incur in obtaining compensation. It also includes any compensation for mortgages or other lien rights used to pay for damaged, destroyed or stolen property.

If you earn income from the destruction of your primary residence, you can usually deduct it from your income, just as you would from the sale or purchase of your home. You can deduct up to $250,000 from your income (up to $500,000 if you are a post-marriage joint taxpayer). To deduct income, you must usually own the home and have lived in it as your primary residence for at least two years within the five years following the date of the destruction. For information on this deduction, see Bulletin 523. If your income exceeds the amount you can deduct, but you purchase a replacement property, you can defer filing the excess income. See Deferred Income below.

Generally, you must report your earnings as income in the year in which you received the compensation. However, you do not have to report your earnings if you meet certain requirements and choose to defer reporting according to the rules explained below in Deferred earnings. For information on how to report your earnings, see How to report losses below. If you have accidental or theft earnings from personal property that you have chosen to defer reporting (explained below) and you also have other accidental or theft earnings from personal property, your deferred earnings are not taken into account in calculating your accidental loss or theft loss deduction. See the 10% rule for the deduction limits above.

If you receive property in compensation that is similar to or related to the property that was stolen or destroyed, do not report the income. The base of your new property is usually the same as the adjusted base of the property it replaces. If you receive money or different property in compensation, you usually have to report the income from your stolen or destroyed property. However, if you purchase property similar to or related to the property that was stolen or destroyed within the specified replacement period, you may choose to defer reporting of the income, as discussed below. If you purchase a controlling interest (at least 80%) in a company that owns property that is similar to or related to the property that is stolen or destroyed, you may also choose to defer reporting of the income. To defer reporting of the entire income, the cost of your replacement property must be at least equal to the compensation you received. If the cost of the replacement property is less than the compensation amount, you must include the income in your income, but only to the extent of the unused compensation.

Parents and children, siblings, individuals holding more than 50% of the issued shares of the company, and two joint ventures holding more than 50% of the capital or profits of a Type C company are related persons under this rule. For more information on related persons, see Undeductible losses and Sales and transactions between related persons in Chapter 2 of Bulletin 544.

You must purchase a replacement property for the specific purpose of replacing the property that was destroyed or stolen. Property that you acquired as a gift or inheritance is not eligible. You do not have to use the compensation you received for the old property to purchase a replacement property. If you spend the money you received from an insurance company on other purposes and then borrow to purchase a replacement property, you can still defer your income, provided that other conditions are met.

If you receive compensatory income from the destruction of your main home that exceeds the amount that you can exclude from your income (see Destruction of your main home, above, in Calculating income ), you can defer the surplus income by purchasing a substitute property that is similar or related in service or use. To defer all surplus income, the cost of the substitute property must be at least equal to the amount you received from the damage less the excluded income. Furthermore, if you defer any portion of your income under these rules, you will be deemed to have owned and used the substitute property as your main home for the period of time that you owned and used the destroyed property as your main home.

If you sell timber that fell in an accident (such as a strong wind, earthquake, or volcanic eruption) and use the proceeds to buy standing timber (rather than land), you qualify for replacement property. If you purchase standing timber within the specified replacement period, you can delay the return of the proceeds.

You can replace your property by acquiring a controlling interest in a company that owns property similar to or related to your damaged, destroyed or stolen property in terms of service or use. You can delay your full return if the cost of the shares that provide you with the controlling interest is at least as much as the amount (compensation) received for your property.

Extensions are usually limited to no more than one year. High market value or scarcity of replacement property is not a reason for granting an extension. If your replacement property is under construction and you clearly indicate that it will not be completed within the replacement period, you may be granted an extension.

You can defer the filing of your income from accidents or theft by declaring your option on your tax return in the year in which you made the income. You have income in the year in which you received insurance payments or other compensation that led to the income. If the stolen or destroyed property belonged to a joint venture or company, only the joint venture or company can defer the filing of the income.

You should include a statement on your tax return for the year in which you received the income. This statement should include the following: the date and details of the accident or theft; the insurance claims or other compensation you received from the accident or theft; and how you calculated your income.

If you file your return in the year in which you acquired the income after purchasing a replacement property, your return should also include details of all of the following: the replacement property; the deferred income; the base adjustment reflecting the deferred income; any income you report as income; and the amount of the deferred income.

You must file an amended return (Form 1040-X for personal use) for the tax year in which you received the income in any of the following cases: You did not acquire replacement property within the prescribed replacement period and extension. On this amended return, you must report the income and pay any additional tax payable. You acquired replacement property within the prescribed replacement period and extension, but at a cost lower than the amount you received as a result of the accident or theft. On this amended return, you must report the non-deferred portion of the income and pay any additional tax payable.

If you receive insurance or other compensation that exceeds the base amount adjusted for your damaged or stolen property, you will earn a profit from the accident or theft. You must include this profit in your income for the year in which you receive the compensation, unless you choose to defer reporting of the profit as described above.

If you rent property from another person, you may deduct the loss of that property in the year in which the liability for the loss is established. This is the case even if the year in which the loss occurred or the year in which the obligation was fulfilled is a different year. You are not entitled to the deduction until your obligation under the lease can be determined with reasonable accuracy. Your obligation may be determined when the claim is settled, awarded or waived.

This section discusses the special rules that apply to federally declared disaster losses. It includes information on when losses can be deducted, how to claim, how to deal with your home in the disaster area, and what tax extensions are available. It also lists the telephone numbers of the Federal Emergency Management Agency (FEMA). (See Contacting FEMA below.) Disaster losses are losses that occur in areas that are determined by the President of the United States under the Stafford Act to require federal assistance and that are attributable to a disaster declared by the Federal Government. A disaster area is an area that requires public or private assistance (or both) or a declaration of emergency. A federally declared disaster is a major disaster or an emergency declaration. A list of areas that require public or private assistance (or both) under the Stafford Act is available at FEMA.gov/Disasters or on the website of the Department of the Interior.
If part of your federal disaster loan is exempted under the Stafford Act, it is considered compensation for loss.

If the disaster relief benefit received under the Stafford Act is used to help you meet essential or serious needs in terms of medical, dental, housing, personal property, transportation or funeral expenses, do not include it in your income. Do not deduct accident losses or medical expenses that are specifically compensated for under these relief benefits. If accident losses are specifically compensated for by the benefit and you receive the benefit after the year in which the accident loss was deducted, see the previous section on the content of compensation funds received after deduction of losses. Unemployment benefits under the Stafford Act are taxable unemployment benefits.

Subsidies received by a business under a state plan and used to compensate for losses suffered by the business as a result of damage or destruction to property caused by a disaster cannot be excluded from income as general benefits, gifts, eligible relief payments (discussed below), or as investments in capital. However, if the business purchases eligible replacement property within a period, the business may choose to defer reporting of gains realized from the subsidy. See the section on Deferred Gains above for the rules that apply.

Eligible relief payments also include amounts paid by the federal, state, or local government to affected individuals in connection with a federally declared disaster. These payments must be made from government funds, based on the needs of the individual or family, not as compensation for services.

Eligible disaster relief payments under the Stafford Act or the National Flood Insurance Act (effective April 15, 2005) are not included in income. These are payments you receive as an owner to reduce the risk of future damage to your property.

In general, if you sell or otherwise transfer property, unless the property is your primary residence, you must recognize any gains or losses for tax purposes. You report the gains or deduct the losses on the tax return for the year in which the gains or losses occur. (You cannot deduct losses of personal property unless the loss is caused by an accident as described above.) However, if you sell or otherwise transfer property to the federal, state, or local government or Indian tribal government under a disaster relief plan and purchase eligible replacement property within a specified period, you may elect to defer filing of the gains for a specified period. See Deferred Gains earlier in this chapter for the rules that apply.

If the IRS extends the tax deadline, the following taxpayers are eligible for an extension: any person whose principal residence is in the affected area (defined below); any corporate entity or sole proprietorship with a principal place of business in the affected area; any person who is a member of a recognized government or charitable organization and provides assistance in the affected area; any person, corporate entity or sole proprietorship whose records are required to meet the deadline for tax deferral, provided that those records are kept in the affected area; any estate or trust with tax records required to meet the deadline for tax deferral, provided that those records are kept in the affected area; a spouse who is filing jointly with a taxpayer who is eligible for an extension; any person, corporate entity or sole proprietorship who is not in the affected area but whose records are required to meet the deadline for tax deferral, provided that those records are kept in the affected area; any person who has visited the affected area and has been injured as a result of the disaster; any other person who is determined to have been affected by a federally declared disaster.
• The IRS may reduce interest and fines on underpaid income tax during the deferred tax deadline.

The disaster year is the tax year in which you suffered a loss as a result of a federally declared disaster. In general, a disaster loss continues in the year in which the disaster occurred. However, a disaster loss may also continue one year after the disaster occurred. For example, if there is a reasonable prospect of compensation for a claim, no part of the loss for which compensation may be received is established until it is determined with reasonable certainty that you will receive compensation.

You must generally deduct accidents in the disaster year. However, if you suffer an accident as a result of a federally declared disaster in an area that requires public or private assistance (or both), you can choose to deduct the loss on your tax return or amended tax return for the tax year immediately preceding the disaster year. If you make this choice, the loss will be considered to have occurred in the previous year. A list of areas that receive public or private assistance (or both) is available on the Federal Emergency Management Agency website at FEMA.gov/Disasters. You must elect to deduct accident losses caused by disaster in the previous year on or before the date of 6 months after the normal due date of your original disaster year return (without extension). If you are a calendar year taxpayer, you must amend your 2023 return by October 15, 2025 to include accident losses that occurred in 2024.

If you have already filed a tax return for the previous year, you can choose to file an amended tax return to claim the disaster loss to offset your income for that year. You can file an amended tax return on Form 1040-X for individuals. (See How to Report a Loss on Form 1040-X below.) To do so, complete Part 1 of Form 4684-D for 2023 and attach it to your 2023 or amended tax return for which you claim the disaster loss deduction. You must make the choice to deduct the loss in the previous year within 6 months of the normal due date of the original tax return (without extension) for the disaster year. For individual taxpayers in calendar years, the deadline for filing a 2024 disaster loss on the 2023 tax return is October 15, 2025. See the instructions on Form 4684 for 2023 for more details on how to file these losses on the original or amended 2023 tax return. If you have deducted disaster losses on your tax return for the disaster year and you wish to deduct the loss in the previous year, you must file a modified tax return for the disaster year on or before the date of filing the previous year's tax return including the disaster loss deduction or amended tax return.

If you wish to withdraw your 2024 Disaster Year option to deduct federally declared disaster losses in the previous tax year, please complete the second part of Part D of Form 4684 for 2023. Attach the completed Part D to your amended return for the previous year (i.e., the amended return for 2023 completed in order to withdraw the 2024 Disaster Year option). You must file your amended return to withdraw the option within 90 days of the deadline for making the choice and before you file any return or amended return for the year in which the disaster loss occurred. Your amended return (the disaster loss option prior to the withdrawal) will recalculate your tax liability after the withdrawal of the option. You must pay or arrange to pay any taxes and interests due as a result of the withdrawal.

Eligible disaster losses also include losses of personal accidents or theft of personal property caused by: major disasters declared by the President under section 401 of the Stafford Act of 2016; Hurricane Harvey; Tropical Storm Harvey; Hurricane Elma; Hurricane Maria; the 2017 and 2018 California wildfires; major disasters declared by the President under section 401 of the Stafford Act of 2018 that occurred before December 21, 2019 and continued until January 19, 2020 (except those losses attributable to the California wildfires of January 2018 that have been exempted); and major disasters declared by the President between January 1, 2020 and February 10, 2025.

If your home is located in a federally declared disaster area, your state or local government may order you to demolish or relocate it because the disaster has made it unsafe to live in. If this happens, treat the loss of value as an accidental loss caused by the disaster. Your state or local government must issue an order requiring you to demolish or relocate your home within 120 days of the area being declared a disaster area. Your loss is calculated in the same way as accidental loss of personal property. (See Calculating loss above.) When determining the amount of the fair market value decrease, use the value of your home before you moved or demolished it and its fair market value after the accident.
An EIC is a tax credit for certain people who earn less than $66,819. A tax credit usually means more money in your pocket.

No, if you are at least 25 years old but under 65 years old and your earned income is less than $18,591 (or $25,511 if you are married and jointly taxable), you can get an EIC without a qualifying child.

Your adjusted gross income (AGI) must also be less than the amount that applies to you. For details, see Rule 1 ("Limit") and Rule 15. Amount of investment income. The maximum amount of investment income that you can have and still receive a credit is $11,600. See Rule 6—Your investment income must be $11,600 or less.

In addition, when determining eligibility, a tax refund may not count as a resource for at least 12 months after you receive it. Consult your local welfare coordinator to find out if your refund will affect your benefits. Healthcare exemption payments.. For more information on how to process healthcare exemption payments for EIC, see Labour earnings. Don't miss out on your state credits.. If you can claim an EIC on your federal income tax return, you may be eligible for a similar credit on your state or local income tax return. For a list of all states that provide state EICs, visit IRS.gov/EITC. EICs contested by the IRS.. The IRS may ask you to provide documents to prove your eligibility for an EIC. We will tell you what documents you need to submit. These documents may include: Birth certificates, school records, etc. The process of determining your eligibility will delay your refund. Spanish version of Publication 596.. Publication 596(SP), Crédito por Ingreso del Trabajo, the Spanish translation of Publication 596. Go to IRS.gov/Pub596SP. Or see Order Forms and Publications or How to Get Tax Help below to learn how to order this and other IRS forms and publications. Photos of Missing Children.. The IRS is a proud partner of the National Center for Missing and Exploited Children (NCMEC). The photos of missing children selected by the Center may appear on blank pages in this publication. If you know one of the children, you can view the photos and call 800-THE-LOST (800-843-5678) to help get them home. Comments and suggestions..

Your adjusted gross income (AGI) must be less than: $59,899 if you have two qualifying children with a valid SSN, $55,768 if you have two qualifying children with a valid SSN, or $18,591 if you have no qualifying child with a valid SSN.

If you are married but are eligible to file as head of household or married separately under the special rules for married taxpayers living separately (see Rule 3) and reside in a state with community property law, your adjusted total income includes the portion of your and your spouse's wages that must be included in the total income.

To file for an EIC, you (and your spouse, if you are filing jointly) must have a valid Social Security number issued by the Social Security Administration (SSA) by the due date of your 2024 tax return (including deferral). Your eligible child must have a valid SSN on or before the due date of your 2024 tax return (including deferral) in order for you to apply for a higher EIC benefit for that child. If you have at least one child who qualifies for an EIC but does not have a valid SSN on or before the due date of your 2024 tax return (including deferral), you may be eligible for your own EIC only if you meet other conditions. If one or more of your children do not have a valid SSN on or before your tax return due date, see the Form EIC for information on how to fill out a Form EIC. An SSN is valid for an EIC unless it was issued after the due date of your 2024 tax return (including deferral) or it was issued solely for the purpose of applying for or receiving federally funded benefits without authorizing you to work. Health care is an example of a federally funded benefit. If you, your spouse or your child hold a Social Security card that is marked "Not valid for employment" and there is a change in your, your spouse's or your child's immigration status and the person is now a U.S. citizen or permanent resident, request a Social Security card without the mark from the SSA.
If you are a U.S. citizen at the time you receive your Social Security Number, you have a valid Social Security Number.
If your social security card says "Valid for work only with INS authorization" (only for work with a DHS authorization), then your SSN is valid only while that authorization is still valid.
If you are married, you usually have to file a joint tax return in order to claim an EIC.

If you are a non-tax resident at any time during the year, you cannot file an EIC unless your tax status is a married joint tax return. You can only use that tax status if your spouse is a U.S. citizen or tax resident and you elect to be treated as a U.S. resident. If you make this choice, you and your spouse will be taxed globally. If you need more information on how to make this choice, please see Bulletin 519. If you are a non-tax resident all year round and your tax status is not a married joint tax return, enter "No" on the dotted line next to line 27 (Form 1040 or 1040-SR).

If you file Form 2555, Foreign Labour Income, you cannot file an EIC. You file these forms to exclude income earned abroad from your total income, or to deduct or exclude the amount of your foreign housing. U.S. territories are not considered overseas. See Bulletin 54 for more information.
This benefit is called an EIC, because to qualify, you must work and have an income. If you are an employee, your earned income includes all taxable income you receive from your employer.

Employment income includes all of the following types of income: 1. Wages, salaries, tips and other remuneration of taxable employees. Employee remuneration is employment income only when taxable. Non-taxable employee remuneration, such as care and adoption benefits for certain dependents, is not employment income. There is one exception, non-taxable combat remuneration, which you can choose to include in employment income, as discussed later in this chapter. 2. Self-employed net income. 3. Gross income earned as a statutory employee or in a non-taxable position.
Wages, salaries and tips received in connection with your work are reported to you in box 1a of Form W-2.

Other types of employment income not reported in box 1 of Form W-2 include wages of domestic workers, tips not reported to your employer, certain exempted payments of federal health benefits (if you choose to include non-taxable amounts in your income) and taxable dependents benefits.

Housing rent or housing allowance provided to a pastor as part of his salary is usually exempt from income tax but included in net self-employment income.For this reason, it is included in the EIC's employment income (except as described in Form 4361 or Form 4029 approved below).
